name: Reuven Rivlin
text: President of the State of Israel. – Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union, honourable Members, my wife Nechama, ladies and gentlemen, with your permission I will speak my words in Hebrew. (Official translation of President Rivlin’s speech, which was delivered in Hebrew) A mere four hours: that is the flight time from Tel-Aviv to Brussels. I could say that four hours, and light years, separate Brussels and Tel-Aviv, but in truth there is not much difference between them, be it in awareness or in essence: two cosmopolitan cities, practically neighbours, not far from each other, both recently struck by a wave of terrorism. Seated here are many delegates from numerous European countries. Some share the Mediterranean Sea with us, all share a rich and painful history with the Jewish People. About a month ago, the leaders of Europe marked 100 years since the Battle of Verdun, the longest battle of World War I, with 900 000 casualties, including 300 000 fatalities. Some half a million Jewish soldiers served in the armies of the countries at war, often poised against each other, firing upon each other. But this ‘patriotic bloodletting’ did not bestow any privilege on the Jewish People. Quite the contrary: Jews in every country were accused of spying and treason. Germany started a ‘head-count’ of Jewish soldiers. In Eastern Europe, Jews were accused of Bolshevism and of Anti-Bolshevism. It is estimated that more than 170 000 Jewish soldiers were killed in World War I, and around 100 000 more were murdered in post-war pogroms. That horrible war, World War I, was the herald of the ‘Exodus’ of the Jewish People from Europe. Many Jews saw in the United States of America their new home. Others, Zionist leaders, shaken and shocked from having had to face their own Jewish brothers as foes on the battlefield, took action to fulfil the dream of a national home for the Jewish People, in its ancient and eternal homeland, the Land of Israel. From where we stand today, the Great War was but a promo to a much more horrendous war that followed suit: World War II. In World War II, the annihilation of the Jewish People was a defined target of the Axis powers headed by Nazi Germany. The second ‘European Exodus’ of the Jewish People occurred upon the defeat of the Third Reich. This was a traumatic emigration: one of refugees and agony, of a culture destroyed, of a people which lost one third of its sons and daughters. Distinguished audience, even the wildest of imaginations could not have foreseen a course of events in which an ancient people returned from years of exile and rebuilt its historic homeland. A wild imagination could neither have foreseen such a convoluted historic course of events in which an utterly torn and bleeding continent, awash with the blood of war and strife, would have paved the way to a joint European parliament. And yes, no less important are the solid, steadfast ties created between us: ties embodied today in a wide array of joint ventures and cooperation, in research and innovation, in health and the environment, education and culture and many more areas. Regardless of the perspective from which we look at this – our past, our present or the future we are awaiting – we intrinsically linked, Israel and Europe, in an unbreakable bond. Just as humanity could not be what it is without Europe, so Europe could not be what it is without the Jewish People. It would be difficult to imagine what humanity would have been like without Plato, Thomas Aquinas, Galileo Galilei, Martin Luther or Marie Curie, just as it would be difficult to imagine what Europe would be without Maimonides, Spinoza, Freud or Einstein. Our common interests – and, moreover, our common values – dictate our present and shape our future. Liberty, equality, justice, pluralism and religious tolerance, democracy: these are the basic tenets inscribed in Israel’s Declaration of Independence. These are the constitutive values of the European Union. The European Union, and within it this distinguished Parliament, is an audacious endeavour of politics and statehood. Tomorrow this endeavour will be put to a complex test in the United Kingdom, while, day in day out, it stands the test of refugees and migration on a historic scale. The State of Israel too is an audacious endeavour of statehood, of a people returning to its land after two thousand years of exile. And, just like you, Israel faces difficult and complex challenges. But unlike Europe, which embarked upon a process of removing partitions between nations and states, Israel wishes, and indeed must, remain first and foremost a national homeland, a safe haven for the Jewish People. The State of Israel is by no means a compensation for the Holocaust, but the Holocaust has posited as a basic tenet the necessity and vitality of the return of the Jewish People to history, as a nation taking its fate in its own hands. I feel that the massive criticism aimed at Israel in Europe stems from, inter alia, a misunderstanding and an impatience toward this existential need of the Jewish nation and the State of Israel. On the other hand, and much to my regret, Israel has a growing sense of impatience when it comes to Europe. There are those who feel anger and frustration toward certain European actions, vis-à-vis what they perceive as sometimes unfair criticism, sometimes even contaminated by elements of condescension and, some would say, double standards. My European friends, we cannot agree on everything, but, as friends and as true allies, I call upon you and ask you: let us be patient. Please respect the Israeli considerations, even when different from your own. Respect Israel’s sovereignty and the democratic process of its decision-making. Respect Israel’s staunch commitment, indeed its very duty, to protect its citizens. For us it is the most sacred commandment of all. A few years ago, a French friend turned to me and said: ‘If we and the Germans have made peace and put an end to conflict once and for all – and, believe me, what happened between us and them overshadows any other conflict I can think of – then there is no reason for you not to succeed.’ He continued: ‘How long have you and the Arabs been fighting, all in all? One hundred years? Fifty years? We have been fighting for a thousand years, and now it is over, forever.’ This is what he said to me. I am standing here today and saying in no uncertain manner: from 1993, the year in which the Oslo Accords were signed, the elected Israeli leadership has been – as it still is – in support of the solution of ‘two-states for two peoples’. Furthermore, being well versed in the Israeli Parliament, I know that any political agreement brought before the Israeli Knesset by an elected government will be approved. Nevertheless, and with all the difficulty and pain involved, we must look reality straight in the eye and tell the truth. Currently the practical conditions, the political and regional circumstances, which would enable us to reach a permanent agreement between us – the Israelis and the Palestinians – are failing to materialise. First, in order to achieve a comprehensive permanent agreement, an effective leadership is required. However, the Palestinian leadership today is divided in (at least) two: the Palestinian Authority ruling over Judea and Samaria and, on the other hand, Hamas, which rules Gaza and is ideologically committed – in both its political and its military leadership – to the annihilation of Israel. Second, in order to achieve a stable and viable agreement, a reasonable regional and economic infrastructure is required. But we are living in a reality where the plague of murderous Jihadi fundamentalism, religious fanaticism and incitement – embodied in the Islamic State and Hezbollah – are at our very borders and have not missed out Gaza and the West Bank either. We live in a reality of a chaos-stricken Middle East in which uncertainty is the only certainty. To this worrisome picture, add the dire economic straits, poverty and lack of infrastructure in Gaza and Judea and Samaria, which in turn will continue the destabilisation and nurture violence. In this respect, Israel is making, and will continue to make, vast efforts: more than any other actor in the region, and even at the price of complex security risk-taking. But Israeli intervention alone will not suffice. Finally, one should bear in mind the most fundamental trait of Israeli-Palestinian relations today, which is, to my deep regret, a total lack of trust between the parties on all levels; between the leaderships and the peoples. I am afraid that, for years, the international community has been acting as a mediator between the parties based on one inflexible paradigm, that of striving to renew negotiations toward a permanent agreement. This paradigm leads to a dichotomy: ‘Two states or a bi-national state’, ‘All or nothing’, ‘Here and now or nevermore’. It is, by the way, by virtue of that same paradigm that various European states opposed the peace agreement between Israel and Egypt, claiming that it does not provide a solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Had that concept been accepted then, imagine where we would be today. This paradigm relies on the assumption that the problem which is the crux of the matter in this bloody and painful conflict is simply the lack of good faith on both sides, and that, if only pressure is exerted on ‘them’ and on ‘us’, they will adhere to a permanent agreement and to a state of peace. However, as years go by and rounds of negotiations fail one by one, bringing in their wake waves of murderous violence and terror, it seems that this assumption of a ‘lack of good will’ is proving not only to be fundamentally erroneous but also to ignore the circumstances, the capabilities, and the present situation on the ground. And that, by definition, would lead to the failure of any attempt to negotiate a permanent agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, I speak before you today in the name of the citizens of Israel, grandfathers and grandmothers, fathers and mothers, sick and tired of this bloody vicious cycle which soaks up the blood of our loved ones, the blood of our sons and daughters. I speak before you in the name of these young men and women who wish to live in their country, and not die in their homeland. I speak to you today in the name of a nation that abhors war and desires life and peace. And, I must say, one cannot hope to achieve better results while resorting to the same outlooks and tools that have previously failed time after time. The French initiative, adopted by the EU institutions only a few days ago, suffers from those very fundamental faults. The attempt to return to negotiations for negotiations’ sake not only does not bring us near the long-awaited solution, but rather drags us further away from it. This striving for a permanent agreement ‘now’, is the chronicle of a predictable failure, which will only push the two peoples deeper into despair. This despair is the hottest bed for extremism, and undermines the endeavours of moderates. And this despair, ladies and gentlemen, today seizes not just members of my generation but also boys and girls growing up in this part of the world, whose worldview and awareness are shaped by the violent present. This despair is the gravest danger looming over us, Israelis and Palestinians alike. If the international community really wishes and truly aspires to be a constructive player, it must divert its efforts away from the renewal of negotiations for negotiations’ sake, and toward building trust between the parties and creating the necessary terms for the success of negotiations in the future. In the current circumstances, we must all ask ourselves ‘What can be done today?’ rather than ‘What cannot be done?’ And things can be done. This mission of creating the terms for a future agreement, creating an infrastructure for trust, and for a life of dignity for both peoples, demands of us today – the international community and Israel alike – that we invest tremendous efforts in four main avenues. The first is harnessing the moderate powers in the region. The cooperation with Jordan and Egypt is a supreme common interest of Israel and the international community as well, with the aim of preventing military build-ups beyond our borders, and in order to eradicate extremism and preserve the stability of the region. Similarly, the involvement and effective guaranties of friendly states in the region may also reduce the violent friction and serve as a warranty for future action. The second avenue is developing Palestinian economy and infrastructures for quality of life. One cannot speak about a future agreement when people live with a basic existential feeling of having no future, no opportunities, no hope and no horizon. With the backdrop of economic difficulties in Judea and Samaria, and the situation in Gaza, a broad economic course of action is called for. Infrastructures must be developed – gas, electricity, water, sewerage and housing – in Gaza and Judea and Samaria. At the same time, a solution must be found to the human tragedy in Gaza – whereby around 1.5 million Palestinians are held hostage by a Jihadist terrorist organisation, Hamas – just as solutions must be found to the movement of residents, the transfer of trade and the enabling the appropriate security. On this issue, the State of Israel has repeatedly stated its willingness to join hands with the international community in a joint endeavour. Israel considers the rehabilitation of Gaza and the economic development and equalising of standards of life on both the Palestinian and Israeli sides to be both an ethical and a security interest. Sources of livelihood and employment must be developed too, as Israeli and international companies that identify the potential of investing in the human capital between the Jordan and the sea, have already begun to do. The development of a stable Palestinian economy must be carried out, laying the emphasis on developing a real, independent and vital private sector as a stabilising factor free of political interests. Furthermore, developing the economy must take into account the need for developing infrastructures for quality of life, for a life of dignity and wellbeing. Rawabi, the first planned Palestinian city ever built in the Palestinian Authority, is a model of the power and significance of basic wellbeing in creating a breathing space and a feeling of movement and progress.  The third avenue is investing in joint ventures aimed at creating joint interests. Whether we wish it or not, we – Israelis and Palestinians – share a small and common area, with common regional resources and assets, and common regional challenges. Together, we live on what is equal to one third of Austria. In such small and crowded space, creating common interests is a crucial factor in strengthening stability, and in creating the terms needed to replace the next war with programmes benefiting both parties. We should foster and promote joint Israeli-Palestinian development ventures in the fields of renewable energy, infrastructure and the environment, joint industrial and tourism ventures and cultural and social ventures: between Israeli and Palestinian local authorities, and between private corporations and business people on both sides. For instance, the ecological park being developed through cooperation between the regional council of Gilboa and the Palestinian city of Jenin, with the support of the international community, in which the shared Kishon River is undergoing cleaning and purification processes, with the aim of providing a solution to one of the most complex issues of the conflict – the water problem. You, ladies and gentlemen, know better than I do how joint ventures create a horizon for another reality. Fourthly and ultimately there is the avenue of education. Increasing stability, developing infrastructures and strategic terms are essential conditions, but are not enough. Creating the conditions for any future agreement requires conditioning hearts on both sides for the possibility of living with mutual respect. Peace is made between leaders but peace is also made between peoples. Changing present trends requires addressing deep-rooted hatred and fear. Otherwise fear will have the upper hand, if only because it is, to our regret, much more tangible than hope. Building trust demands an investment in the creation of wide channels of communication, not only in security contexts but also in academic, cultural, and governance contexts – and, at the same time, educating future generations to become acquainted with our neighbours, their culture and language. Distinguished audience, the State of Israel values the efforts invested by the international community in general, and by the European Union in particular, in seeking a peaceful future between the parties. The responsibility for building trust between us and our neighbours rests, first and foremost, on the shoulders of the two parties. But if Europe is interested in serving as a constructive factor in striving for a future agreement it will be incumbent upon you, its leaders, to focus efforts at this time in a patient and methodical building of trust: not through divestments, but through investment; not by boycotts, but by cooperation. It is no easy task for me to stand here before you today and say that, at this time, a permanent agreement for peace between us and the Palestinians cannot be achieved – because, first and foremost, I stand before the Israeli people, before my children and grandchildren, before the Israeli and Palestinian children wherever they are. It is to them that I and we, and all of us, are to be held accountable: to ask ourselves what we have actually done to promise them, someday, another future? I believe in the capability of both these peoples to live with each other, for the simple reason that we have no other choice. If we desire life, we must, today, invest our utmost efforts in what can be achieved, not in that which cannot – for the sake of our future, and that of our children. I would like to thank my friend, the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, for the invitation to come here, in the same week as the President of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas. There can be no substitute for direct and joint conversation. In this act you have taken a step, albeit small, to bolster trust between the parties. Distinguished audience, 100 years ago the thought of a joint European Parliament was inconceivable. Cooperation in the fields of electricity, gas and coal started this miracle of a Europe living in peace with itself. Small steps created a great reality. Help us step forward, step together with us, for the sake of the possibility that one day, an Israeli President will tell another world leader: ‘If we and the Palestinians have made peace and put an end to conflict once and for all, there is really no reason whatsoever that you cannot succeed. We fought for many dozens of years and now it is over, forever.’ On behalf of the people in Israel, I wish all Europe’s Muslims, and the Muslim believers throughout the entire world, Ramadan Karim, Kul Am Wa Antum Bikhair. Ladies and gentlemen, ‘Pray for the peace of Jerusalem, may all who love her prosper. Peace be within thy walls and prosperity within thy palaces. For my brethren and companions’ sake, I will now say, Peace be within thee.’ (Psalm 122, 6-8). God bless you all. (Applause)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, the minutes, in point 4.6, show the adoption of the regulation for an open, efficient and independent administration on the project of our excellent colleagues, Mr Swoboda and Mrs Hautala.  This is an excellent text which, unfortunately, does not yet have a completely binding value for all the eu's institutions since the regulation is not adopted. But I hope that it has a binding value for this Parliament and that it will impose itself on the administration of this Parliament, which believes itself to be entitled to tax substantial sums of Parliament without even having heard them, without even having heard them, which sometimes seems to me to be quite contrary to the independence that Members must retain from the administration.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Referring to the speech we have just heard, I would like to remind you that last week it was twenty-five years since the signing of the Treaty on Good Neighbourly Relations between Poland and Germany. This was the fruit of a difficult reconciliation that began as early as 1965, through a letter from the Polish Bishops to the German bishops, which famously said: "We forgive and ask forgiveness." The signing of the Treaty in 1991 was also made possible by the creation and victory of Solidarity, thanks to the unification of Germany, thanks to the efforts of the German Chancellors, as well as the prime ministers and ministers of the Polish free government, but above all thanks to the efforts of citizens on both sides of the border on the Oder and Nysa, who clearly believed that agreement, cooperation and mutual trust were essential for them. That is why what was already announced here in the European Parliament in 1988 was in a way announced by Pope John Paul II, who said at the time: "May Europe breathe again with two lungs."  And one more thing. This treaty of 1992 translated the common destiny of Poles and Germans, neighbours for centuries, into joint action in Europe, and now poses a new task for both nations: what can we Poles and Germans do today for a common Europe?

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues and friends. It is an honour and a pleasure to remind you that Slovenia celebrates this week 25 years of its independence. 25 years ago, on the basis of a plebiscite and democratically expressed will, we realised the dream of the Slovenian people of our own and democratic state. Let me also remind you of the tragic fact that the proclamation of independence in June 1991 was followed by an attack by the Yugoslav People's Army on Slovenia, even though the Yugoslav Constitution guaranteed us the right to self-decision and secession. Because we were ready, we won the war for Slovenia and brought down our part of the Iron Curtain with a united Europe. At that time, the European and global democratic public sided with Slovenia and supported the process of international recognition of the new country. A key seal for this process was given by the European Community by the recognition of Slovenia on 15 January 1992. I would like to express my special thanks to those who understood and supported us at the time, thus supporting the European perspective of Slovenia. We have experienced a divided and united Europe, we have reasons to celebrate together and we are working decisively for a better Europe.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this House has adopted a number of resolutions on the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and more specifically on the situation in the eastern border areas, including the Kivus. We are all aware of the shocking violence which has been reported since last autumn, especially in North Kivu. Some localities have been especially badly affected. The number of dead in Beni territory alone is estimated by civil society sources at over 550 since September 2014. In addition, tens of thousands of people have been displaced. Naturally, the EU’s immediate priority is humanitarian access, and we call once again for a stop to the targeting and kidnapping of humanitarian workers. I recall, of course, that when serving the needs of afflicted populations, the European Commission Humanitarian Aid Office (ECHO) acts in accordance with the principles laid down in Council Regulation (EC) No 1257/96, notably those of impartiality and non-discrimination.  The recent violence has been made possible by an ongoing absence of state control. Institutions and services to deal with the prevention and elimination of violence, and legal action against those responsible, are missing. Regrettably, state-building activities in DRC are also held back by the current uncertainty over the organisation of elections, which are due this year under the constitution. Another aspect which continues to be relevant is the exploitation by armed groups of both wildlife and mineral natural resources. The recent report by the United Nations group of experts on the DRC underlines the ongoing involvement of the Lord’s Resistance Army in poaching, and also draws particular attention to the laundering by armed groups of gold into the supply chain and onto the international market. It is of some consolation that armed groups have had fewer opportunities to benefit from illegal involvement in tin, tungsten and tantalum, thanks to due diligence and traceability systems.  The EU will continue its effort to address the natural resources dimension of the Great Lake region stabilisation effort. While understanding the root causes of violence and instability is important, it does not excuse perpetrators, who must submit to the rule of law. This applies equally to incitement of violence and hate speech. It is individuals, not entire communities or ethnic groups, who must account for their actions. As has been stated many times before in this House, the activities of armed groups in eastern DRC are an affront to citizens, undermining their human and legal rights, holding back development, destroying peace of mind and, in short, making it difficult to plan ahead or to think of the future. For armed groups to be put out of action, an effective and operational level of cooperation between the Congolese Armed Forces and the UN Stabilisation Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Monusco) is needed, and it is needed quickly. An agreement in principle was realised in February, but it needs to be put into practice. The justice angle is also important. As a supporter of both civil and military justice reform in DRC, the EU insists that those found to be assisting or conspiring with armed groups must be prosecuted. As regards serious atrocities committed in eastern DRC, we encourage the exploration of all legal options for the investigation and prosecution of those crimes. The primary responsibility for investigating and prosecuting lies with the state where the crime took place or the state where the perpetrator is a national. The EU will continue to offer assistance to the DRC to assure structures are established and backed up with strong legislative frameworks in order to enable this.  I want to turn now to the broader but critical issue of governance. With elections due in only a few months, DRC finds itself at a key moment. UN Security Council Resolution 2277 (2016) is a starting point for all of us. This resolution was adopted unanimously in March. It underlines the primary responsibility of the DRC authorities to prepare and organise elections in respect of their relevant constitutional provisions. Naturally, the EU has noted the decision of the Constitutional Court of the DRC in May this year. The EU also fully respects the sovereignty of the DRC. At the same time, and within the framework not only of the Cotonou Agreement but also the African Union Charter of democracy elections and governance, we underline that a democratic government builds its legitimacy on regular elections within the deadline set out in the constitution. To achieve a consensus leading to elections, a political dialogue is urgently needed, but time is of the essence and the dialogue should be focused. All representative political actors should be involved. Such a dialogue can produce, as its main deliverable, a clear road map, based on a calendar and financing plan, for what needs to be done to deliver elections respecting the constitution. In this context, the EU, together with the UN, the AU and the OIF, again repeated on 6 June 2016 its support for the mission of His Excellency Edem Kodjo, the EU facilitator supported by the United Nations, to implement a successful dialogue. Let me end by saying that successful elections will depend not only on technicalities, but also on their achieving the right climate in terms of respect for rights and freedoms. Freedom of expression and peaceful assembly are the cornerstones of any democratic society. Ensuring and protecting an open political space are essential to allowing the political dialogue I have mentioned earlier to take place.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, I may try to start with the words 'democratisation' and 'democratic process' when talking about the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), unfortunately the words that come to mind are 'fragility', 'volatility' and this leads to vigilance and responsibility. First, we must condemn the massacres in eastern DRC as such, but also place them in a more general context. I would like to emphasize three things. First, all light must be shed on the massacres committed in eastern DRC, and their perpetrators must be brought to justice. There is an urgent need for renewed cooperation between the DRC's armed forces and Monusco's full use of its expanded mandate. As for the Union, we must not lose sight of the fight against impunity and ensure that security sector reforms finally lead to results. Let us also stand firm on the necessary results in the justice system. Second, with regard to the electoral process, let us ensure that the deterioration of the security environment is not used to further challenge the electoral process, which should be conducted directly and vice versa. In the crisis of legitimacy of power that followed the 2011 elections, any event is essential. In this context, the holding of a genuine dialogue between opposition and the government must also not omit the essential role of civil society, because the political blockade of the country has direct consequences on the citizens. We are waiting for a clear statement from the CENI on the election deadlines, the files that should not exclude young people, and the budget. Finally, the African Union has an important role to play, and I am referring in particular to the role of the Ombudsman Mr Kodjo. The European Union and the rest of the international community have already expressed their support for this mediation. We now need a more active presence in the public space. Every word weighs. In addition, the African Union must remind all stakeholders of their commitments in the Addis Ababa Framework Agreement for Peace and Security in the Great Lakes Region. Today, therefore, coordination, clear message, respect for the current Constitution, this may allow us not to face a humanitarian and security crisis on the scale of the Congolese giant.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I must confess that I have often heard military experts and analysts repeat a definition that gave me chills, namely that there is a conflict in North Kivu, but it is a 'low-tension' conflict. A low tension that has resulted in six million deaths and one and a half million displaced persons over the last twenty years. If we did a cold calculation, we'd talk about 300,000 deaths a year, 800 deaths a day, and these experts talk about low voltage. I think that instead of saying 'low voltage' we should say 'low attention', that is, little attention from the international community to a tragedy that is of appalling proportions. That is why we are addressing above all the High Representative Federica Mogherini, who I know and know is sensitive to these issues. Together we want to stop the escalation of violence against the helpless population by militias which have every interest in controlling one of the richest territory in the world in terms of mineral resources. We have concrete proposals, very clear proposals. One, we call for the establishment of an independent international commission of inquiry to shed light on the causes and perpetrators of the massacre. Two: we are calling for the Involvement of the International Criminal Court in relation to what happened in Beni. Three: we want a United Nations evaluation report on the results of the MONUSCO mission and, above all, we call on the UN contingent to make full use of the mandate assigned to it, namely to intervene to protect civilians. Four: we call on the African Union to do its part and to invest more energy in resolving this conflict. My group, as an autonomous action of the Socialists and Democrats, will send my colleague Elena Valenciano, chairman of the Subcommittee on Human Rights, to the Kivu region so that she can meet and listen to the representatives of Congolese civil society and all the actors present on the ground, gathering information which, on her return, we will share with colleagues in Parliament and with european institutional leaders , starting with the President of this Assembly and the High Representative Federica Mogherini. The international community wake up! Wake up! Do not abandon the Congolese in Kivu to their fate and act to stop a violence that has been going on non-stop for twenty years.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – "Congo is the greatest human tragedy on earth". Words from British journalist Tim Butcher who knows the country through and through and describes it in his book as the broken heart of Africa. I reread an interview from a few years ago in which he complains that there is so little attention to Congo and in which he describes the political elite there as predators. Unfortunately, the message is still up-to-date. The east of drc is today again a humanitarian battlefield. Villagers are slaughtered with machetes, women are raped, children kidnapped, houses looted. And President Kabila doesn't seem to be awake to that. He's busy securing his power. It has only been three months since we denounced the political and human rights situation in Congo, but not a millimetre of progress has been made in the meantime. On the contrary, the bogus trial of opposition leader and presidential candidate Katumbi shows that DRC is sinking further into a political crisis. We have a duty to use all possible tools to avoid another bloody civil war. We must not lose sight of the fact that the crisis has a regional dimension and is about raw materials, about minerals. The Commissioner said it. "Congo's greatest curse is its wealth," Tim Butcher rightly says in the same interview. It is a step forward that the EU recognises the trade in minerals as one of the causes of the conflict. From now on, companies that import certain raw materials must be able to demonstrate that they do not indirectly contribute to violence. But we need to do more. The Union must, among other things, work towards the resumption of joint operations by Monusco, the UN mission and the Congolese army to neutralise the armed militias.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, we support this resolution which aims to put an end to the indifference and drama that regularly occurs in north-eastern Congo. The five groups that signed it call for diplomacy, DRC politicians, and conflicting parties to end the barbarity of civilians and, first and foremost, women and children.  Yesterday's ruling by the International Criminal Court in The Hague in the Bemba case justifies that we also call on all those responsible to gather sufficient evidence to bring to international justice the real perpetrators of the massacres in question. The united Nations Security Council should therefore address recent events in North Kivu, including the extent to which Monusco could help to better restore a situation that respects the rights of the most basic civilian populations. The continuing deterioration of the situation in the DRC is also challenging companies that acquire raw materials and, in particular, rare minerals. Only a speedy introduction of regulations on minerals from conflict zones can help put an end to the organized crime committed by predators, particularly in North Kivu province, which do not back down from any lows. The principle of non-indifference, so dear to Africans, should guide us in the search for a solution to this tragedy.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, once again in this Parliament we have to address, in order to reject, the situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. This time, our strongest condemnation of the massacres in the eastern zone. I would like to express our support for political and peaceful solutions to the conflict. Military solutions bring more death, more pain and more violence to the population. We would also like to express our concern at strengthening america's military command in Africa and its role of destabilization in different countries and also in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. We call for the dismantling and withdrawal of Africom. The European Union should also launch an independent investigation into the role of European multinationals in violating social and environmental rights and also their ties to the financing of armed groups in order to continue the exploitation of the Congolese subsoil. The Deputy Executive Director of the United Nations Environment Programme in 2015 stated that 2% of the annual benefits of exploiting natural resources went to finance these internal armed groups. We also believe that non-interference and sovereignty of the Democratic Republic of the Congo must be ensured. And, Commissioner, respecting this political sovereignty means that people can benefit from their natural resources, for which it is necessary to establish control over the activities of multinationals by reviewing and repealing all mining and forestry contracts, as well as respecting the right to food sovereignty and debt cancellation, which, we understand, are essential measures to meet the most basic and urgent needs of the population.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we meet again here in this House to condemn a terrible situation in Congo — in this case, the massacres in the eastern part — and the representative of the Commission will understand that we are feeling a little frustrated, because we have not long ago approved another and yet it seems that this has no impact on the terrible situation in a large part of the people of Congo.  We welcome this Joint Resolution; a resolution that we signed for the sake of consensus, but which we would have liked to make somewhere more forceful, especially when we criticize the role that the Monusco is playing— the United Nations Stabilization Mission in the Democratic Republic of the Congo — a mission that has been accused by independent actors of passivity, of not playing the role it has assigned, which is to defend the civilian population precisely against these massacres.  We hope that this investigation that we are also asking for in this Resolution will be carried out and that it will be clarified exactly whether the mission is not being fulfilled and who is responsible.  We welcome the fact that some of the key points of the situation in Congo are. First, the fact that women are preferred victims and that rape of women and girls is being used as a weapon of mass warfare; that child soldiers are being recruited, who will have no chance in life plunged into that horror. And above all, let us talk about the conflict of illegal mineral extraction.  And, there, the Commission has a role to play, because European companies have a lot of responsibility for this and it would be important if we went beyond the declarations and took active sanctions, research measures, to know which European multinationals are involved in that trade which, in the end, is the last justification for the terrible situation that this territory is experiencing.  At one of the points in the Resolution is the possibility of sanctioning those who are directly responsible for these massacres. Don't let our hands tremble! Let us also go for this European responsibility and give an example that the European Union is not abandoning the people of Congo.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since 1960, since Belgium's independence, Congo has in fact always been in a spiral of violence. The situation has certainly not improved in recent years, when President Kabila, rather than thinking about solving the problems of human rights violations, seems to be thinking solely about how to maintain power in the run-up to the next elections. A number of members have already said that the situation is tragic in the eastern provinces, in the north and south of Kivu, in Katanga. The cause is always the same, it is the wealth of this country, the exploitation of resources, raw materials and minerals. I believe that, for our part, the thing we can probably do is to try to be more rigid towards the European multinationals operating in those regions, to try precisely to carry out independent investigations and to ask the United Nations for account and reason on this mission – MONUSCO – which has had a very ambiguous mandate and the results that are difficult to establish. It seems strange not to be able to understand from the United Nations mission, and we cannot find any reports on the mines and mineral trafficking that they should be aware of. This is the third resolution we are making in a short time on congo. I believe that the time has come to find concrete results, to make some progress, if not to find ourselves talking systematically about nothing.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, I would first like to thank my colleagues, once not customary, for their relevance in the analysis of the Congo and, in particular, Mr Pittella.  This is a country that I love very much. I myself have been with Vice-President Zahidi Ngoma during the transition period and I have followed this transition by being one of the actors. The difficulty of the Democratic Republic of Congo is its wealth. May I recall that Laurent-Desiré Kabila was picked up because Uganda and Rwanda had decided, on the orders of an external power - I can give clarification - to invade the country. May I recall that, while Laurent-Desiré Kabila invaded the country, a number of companies were signing contracts. They were American companies. May I also recall that when Laurent-Desiré Kabila turned around as a patriot for his country, it was decided here in Brussels - I had the information, I can say of whom because he has since died - of his elimination and we also went to Washington to seek order. And he was eliminated a fortnight later! May I also recall that then we went to get Joseph Kabila and said that we would manipulate this young man because he was a Rwandan national, and that we were going to make him a president. This is all manipulation. What is needed for the Democratic Republic of Congo is a newfound sovereignty, an army that is effectively fighting, a Monusco in the service of peace and that predators linked to organized crime are stopped with hypocritical states linked to multinationals.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, as already stated, the conflicts and instability in the Congo are largely linked to the struggle for great wealth of minerals that the country has. It is the mineral resources that are supposed to make congo's population rich, what should be salvation, that has become the curse of that country. More than 63% of Congo's population lives below the poverty line, about 43% of children under 5 are chronically malnourished. That is why, on this occasion, I would like to welcome the EU regulation process by establishing a mandatory certification system for responsible exporters of tin, tantanium and tungsten, their ores and gold originating from conflict-affected areas, and in an effort to break the link between conflict and the illegal exploitation of minerals, as a key element in ensuring peace, sustainable development and stability. But it is not only the fight for minerals that is the source of conflict, but there are also weak institutions, corruption, lack of good rule. That is why it is important not to manipulate and delay congo's presidential election. That is why I also welcome the fact that the national indicative programme for Congo under 11 The European Development Fund focuses precisely on strengthening good rule, the rule of law, including reform of the judiciary, police and military, and I call for an equal strategy to be applied to other African countries where perhaps the direct link between corruption and the democratic deficit as the main cause of poverty and instability is not as obvious as in the Congo, but it certainly exists.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, we are here, once again, for a resolution on the Democratic Republic of Congo and, as has been said, it is not the first and I fear it will not be the last. Today, what brings us is the Beni massacres. Beni massacres which, as Mr. Pittella said, add to the millions of deaths. In Beni, more than 1,000 people were massacred in the space of a year and a half, in addition to kidnappings, burned houses, rapes, threats, massively displaced populations... This is the tragedy we are experiencing today in Kivu.  So, as we said, this area is coveted because there is gold, because there is coltan. I welcome the fact that in this Parliament we have taken positions on the traceability of minerals, but I must say that we have done so by dragging our feet somewhat. I must also say that the Council has not always been very attentive to what we have asked for. Clearly, today, everyone agrees that our multinationals need to pay more attention to what is happening in this country. But today, this instability is also due to the Congolese authorities. It is unacceptable because it gives rise to crimes. Therefore, we ask that these crimes not go unpunished, that there be national and international investigations, which allow to identify those responsible and to apply sanctions against them.  In a pre-election context, it will be difficult, as we know, and human rights crimes are increasingly important in the Democratic Republic of Congo. We must therefore, as the European Union, in partnership with the African Union and with the United Nations, unite so that the elections in that country can take place in peace, in transparency, in respect of the Constitution, not only because we want to respect the Constitution, but simply because it will be the only guarantee to achieve stability. , avoid crises that are humanitarian crises and avoid, of course, that the people, who are the first on the front line, suffer from this situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the people of Congo have to endure once more unbelievable atrocities perpetrated by armed militias in the eastern part of the country. This was made possible by the period of political uncertainty concerning the transition of power. The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) constitution should be enacted as soon as possible, the free elections maintained within the country in terms of international involvement, the implementation of the March UN resolution is necessary as well as the deployment of an enhanced mandate for MONUSCO as soon as possible. I also think that in order to eradicate impunity the ICC should be involved once more.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: – We have been talking about the war in Congo for so many years that we have almost forgotten how beautiful it is in times of peace. Entire villages are being executed. Women are brutally slaughtered at the gates of the army posts. Mothers desperately throw their children over the fences of the Monusco camps before they are mowed down. Since 1996, sexual violence has been used as a tactic of war. Every minute a woman is raped in Congo. We can almost speak of a sexual genocide, even though the international community has been present for 16 years. Can the Congolese still rely on us, on Monusco? 10 000 troops pass through and leave no peace but trauma. We need to think about the mandate and the impact. And we all know it: Congo is in demand. As it has already been said here, the natural resources keep the fight burning. President Kabila casts doubt on his ambitions for a third term in office. Only free and fair elections are part of the solution. We have a role to play. Four points: we must continue to support the peace process, take a hard look at the mandate and impact of Monusco, punish impunity and punish the perpetrators, and above all make democracy play a real role. Please give Eastern Congo another future.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, for years the DRC has been experiencing a dramatic situation: the proliferation of armed groups, poverty, destabilization, massacres, and the exploitation of the ethnic issue against the background of the grabbing of resources by the government, neighbouring countries and multinationals, especially European ones. As a result, at least 400,000 Congolese in exile, 1.5 million internally displaced people, or 7% of the population, and several million people died in almost general indifference. It is indeed genocide, which has been recognized by the United Nations since 2010, one of the longest genocides in history, even if it is low-voltage as Mr Pittella would say. The upsurge in violence in recent months shows that nothing is settled. So the question is: when will the international community finally react to what is happening in Congo? The responsibility of both is heavy. Yes, we must stabilize the country and bring Mr. Kabila to his l'raison. Yes, there needs to be independent investigations, including the role of Monusco. Yes, we must end the financing of armed groups and the use of blood minerals. As long as we turn a blind eye to what is happening in the DRC, the massacres will continue. There's an emergency.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the atrocities committed in Congo are getting worse. We were, remember, awarded Dr. Mukwege the Sakharov Prize in 2014 for his work with women who are victims of rape and sexual violence. But today, it is not only women but also children and babies who are the victims of armed groups.  Sexual violence has been used throughout the ages because it is a weapon of mass destruction. Last year, the UN revealed a damning report and called for the creation of new mechanisms to break the cycle of impunity. It is a step forward to learn that some executioners have been convicted, but this is not enough because the power in place is complicit, because this barbarity is a direct consequence of the lack of rule of law and the denial of justice in Congo. It is also and above all the consequence of illegal mining activities carried out and protected by armed militias.  We must do more and better to combat these crimes because we are all responsible for these blood minerals that end up in our phones and other computer equipment. That is why I appreciate That Europe is doing this with the recent agreement on the blood ore regulation.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, good news for Central Africa: Jean-Pierre Bemba, former Vice-President of the DRC, was sentenced a few days ago by the International Criminal Court in The Hague to 18 years in prison for war crimes and crimes against humanity. This brings a little justice to the many women, children and men who have been cruelly tortured, raped, mutilated and murdered by their militias. Moreover, there is nothing positive to report on the current situation in the DRC. Political tensions within the country have been rising since incumbent President Kabila tried all his tricks to postpone the November election date indefinitely, artificially extending his term, which was supposed to end at the end of the year. There are attacks on opposition politicians, bans on demonstrations, and deaths again. To top it all off, a yellow fever epidemic has also broken out, exacerbating the humanitarian crisis in the country. In the east of the country, however, fighting between government forces and armed so-called rebels has resumed in intensity and cruelty. The main reason for this is and remains the struggle for access to valuable minerals such as gold, tin, cobalt and tantalum, which are extracted in this region. Some people who live there are expelled and murdered or forced into forced labour. The EU, including this Parliament, could have set an important signal with the new regulation on the import and use of these minerals from conflict zones. Unfortunately, however, we have negotiated a text of the regulation which is very vague and, for example, far behind the US-American Dodd-Frank Act, which is already having an effect in banning the import and use of these minerals. We can all save ourselves good speeches if we are not prepared to draw conclusions here and act accordingly.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today it is Beni. Why did I go beyond my usual path this morning, instead of being quiet at home with my children? Why didn't I ask my husband to accompany me? Why did I not decide to do like those more than 400 000 compatriots who left the country precisely to escape this violence? yes, but to go where? In Europe? South Africa? What if they sent us back and said we're not holders of international protection, where would we go back? To Beni? Yet I felt safe here. Monusco's headquarters are not far away. They have a mandate to protect us, it is the international community that wanted them. But after all, it's good that I was alone, so my family is safe, at least for the time being. And then I spared them the inhuman spectacle. These beasts didn't just rape me, they raged with blades and rakes and then completed the work, burning me. I was still conscious, but I wasn't afraid, I thought of you and my children and it all ended in a moment. Despite everything, I'm happy. I am happy because I did not recognize well-known faces among the spectators of the village, forced to witness those massacres. I am happy because in this last dragnet we were mainly adults, very few children fortunately. In that hell they couldn't resist much, they left almost immediately. Also, I am happy because no one will see the ruptures of my body, my body after hours and hours of torture. It is fortunate that the international community has little interest in what is happening here in eastern Congo, and that the media have more to deal with. Ladies and gentlemen, from October 2014 to March 2016, 1 200 people were massacred in the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo in general indifference. The risk is genocide. It's a disgrace. No impunity for those responsible for these massacres. When justice for Beni?

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The statement by my speaker representing Italy was very moving. Well, I will say this: we should do everything we can to ensure that the UN resolution is implemented. It must not be the case that an organisation bringing together all the countries of the world issues a resolution, which then in practice becomes a whizz of paper. The UN has a calm conscience, but nothing happens. We must do everything we can to ensure that the International Criminal Court makes an exemplary judgment on the perpetrators of these crimes. Europe cannot remain silent on this issue, it is a question of our honour, of our duty, especially of those countries that once had colonies in areas where crimes and atrocities are being carried out today.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I pay tribute to Kashetu. The Democratic Republic of congo is mired in one of the longest humanitarian crises in its history. Massacres and attacks, especially in the eastern part, are causing more than three million displaced people, half a million of whom have already fled to neighbouring countries. Constant abductions, disappearances, sexual abuse of women and children and more than a thousand rapes daily: I am talking about indiscriminate assaults, forced recruitment of children. I want to condemn the terrible acts that took place in Beni, Lubero and Butembo, who claimed the lives of 1,160 people. I would like to express my solidarity and support to the victims and their families. I would like to stress, madam, the need for the resumption of joint operations between the armed forces of the Republic of the Congo and monusco because it is the only way, in my view, to counter the abominable actions of armed groups, such as the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda or the Allied Democratic Forces, among others. In addition, it is necessary for the Congolese authorities to deal as soon as possible with the illegal exploitation of resources, such as wolframium, tin or tungsten, in order to definitively cut off the source of funding of armed groups. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the need for the holding of the next presidential and legislative elections, which would be decisive in advancing stability and progress. It is necessary to provide the country with institutionality as soon as possible and to reform military and civil justice in order to end criminal impunity and effectively protect citizens. The Court's conviction of The Hague to Bemba must also be exemplary.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the eastern province of Congo is quite clear and the answers given to this crisis to date have been inadequate. I have to say very sincerely that I have heard crocodile tears in this House from those who, among other things, have obstructed the regulation which makes it possible to avoid trade in minerals from conflict zones, and many have sideways, in the Council and the Commission. The Council and the Commission are a mixture of hypocrisy and schizophrenia in this respect and perhaps they should be in the least consistent with what they are saying here. That is clear. There are a number of points that should be defined in a platform to essentially prevent the European Union from showing that it is powerless in the face of what is happening. It has to be said that President Kabila must leave. The conditions must be built for a political transition. It has to be said that there is a lack of response from the regular army in Congo, where soldiers would have been helpless on several occasions. It must be said that there is an inadequacy of the UN mission operating in the country and that, despite being one of the largest deployed, it is not proving to be able to stop the crisis. It is also remarkable that two states which are part of the mission, Uganda and Rwanda, are suspected of providing military support to those same rebels that are being fought against. So, we should say this, we should say that we need an international commission, that the UN must launch an investigation precisely in order to achieve the objectives that it has set itself. We need a strong signal and, above all, we need the European Union to get out of this kind of powerlessness and inability to decide.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) lives in a constant state of superficial peace and superficial security. The latest outbreak of violence in the north of the country has left everyone shocked. We saw hundreds of murders, disappearances, rapes and the wiping out of crucial infrastructure. Unfortunately, we also saw only mild and slow international reaction to such armed violence. I extend my sincere condolences to the families of the victims. In this situation, immediate violence must be ended, and all armed groups must lay down their arms. The international community, including the EU, should be more present, more vocal and more instrumental, and offer support to disarmament. MONUSCO also needs to be able to react faster in order to protect civilians. Furthermore, due investigation into these crimes must be carried out and the perpetrators must be brought to justice. Without drawing clear responsibility for these crimes, the atmosphere of impunity will continue to poison the country and we can expect repeated outbursts of violence. I am sure that citizens of the DRC deserve better after 20 years of violence and armed conflicts.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am extremely concerned about the deteriorating security situation in the northeastern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), by the numerous reports of massacres, the recruitment and use of children by armed groups, and widespread violence. I strongly support the call on the DRC Government and the UN peacekeeping mission, MONUSCO, to conduct an investigation into the failures of the Congolese and MONUSCO forces to protect civilians in the region of Beni. A thorough, independent and transparent investigation should be launched urgently by the international community into the massacres in order to find out who is behind these attacks, besides the allied democratic forces. The neutralisation of all armed forces, safety for all citizens and stability in the territories of Beni, Lubero and Butembo has to be our priority. Perpetrators of human rights violence, war crimes, crimes against humanity and sexual violence must be reported, identified, prosecuted and punished in accordance with national and international criminal law.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in recent decades the Democratic Republic of Congo has been marked by a history of violence that has already charged millions of people with their lives. The scenario is very worrying. A few days ago, a group of UN experts warned of the possibility of a process similar to the one that followed the elections in Burundi, with pro- and former government guerrillas clashing in the event of a postponement of the 2017 presidential elections, as it unfortunately looks likely to happen. Now we are news of massacres that have killed army soldiers and former rebel fighters at demilitarization centers in the southeast of the country. In the face of this scenario, the European Union must do everything in its power to prevent the situation from derailing. The carnage that occurred in Rwanda in 1994, in the face of the inaction of the rest of the world, as well as the two devastating wars of the Congo, must always be present in our memory.  In recent years, the European Union has provided valuable aid to Congo, both in combating poverty and in the direction of stabilising the country and the region. The European Union can and must now use its support to pressure the Congolese authorities to respect the process of reintegration of former rebels and opposition rights, to comply with the electoral calendar and to engage in dialogue sponsored by the African Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Six million deaths in the last year, millions on the run: this shows that the fight against regional terror, but also Islamic terror in the region, the fight against Boko Haram and al-Shabaab has obviously failed. So the axis of Islamic terror extends from Somalia to, apparently, West Africa. Our words of regret today are anointing, but they bring relatively little and are therefore hypocritical. Europe will have to wake up from the great blah blah, and we must take note of the fact that it will obviously continue until resources and raw materials such as coltan are finally in the wrong hands, and then industry in Europe will also wake up, and then we will have to cry out and ultimately take action. I therefore believe that we are talking a lot today, but we are obviously not prepared to take clear steps. However, I am already predicting that the industry will tell us that if we have to take action, also in the interests of our mobile phone production.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the third time that we have dealt with Congo. The situation remains dramatic in that country. Recently, common pits have been discovered with hundreds of bodies. Since 2014, more than 850 men, women and children have been killed by machetes, darks and knives, and others have been tortured of all kinds. Every minute a woman is raped. There are also more than 1 500 people kidnapped. The population is being massacred, caused by invasions by armed gangs which are carrying out a real genocide. The missionaries and religious, together with the Peace Network for congo, are calling for an international investigation into what is happening in North Kivu, the region bordering Rwanda. Now, more than ever, the international community and the European Union need to intervene to put an end to the massacres, we must respond to the appeal of the associations in the air and the UN must set up an international commission of inquiry to put an end to this tragedy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the Democratic Republic of Congo is the largest country in Central Africa and at the same time one of the richest in minerals. Unfortunately, however, this is largely due to the outbreak of violence that this country is aware of. Last December we voted in favour of a proposal condemning illegal mining activities under way in Virunga National Park, a park with the highest biodiversity in Africa and UNESCO World Heritage.  The violence in the North Kivu region begins around the same time that the first seismological surveys are being conducted at the end of 2014. Almost two years later we are already counting more than six hundred dead. Horrific massacres in the Benny area in May, with victims of pregnant women, young children and the elderly.  The European Union must not only condemn these inhumane acts, but also take strict measures to stop any involvement of European multinationals in the illegal activities taking place in eastern Congo. In particular, it must examine complaints of multinational companies working with armed groups with the aim of terrorised and persecuting local people.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, unfortunately the Democratic Republic of congo is one of the best examples when wealth becomes a curse, when the wealth that one state has does not reach its citizens, but remains limited in the political elite, in that narrow circle of people who manage the wealth of that state. Therefore, I want to make it absolutely clear that in this case we should do at least two things. True, this is already the third resolution we are discussing with some of the results that have been achieved, but we need to do two things. The Hague tribunal needs to make clear decisions like it did recently because it's a great way to finally end some things. I also speak with some experience from the former Yugoslavia where wars were fought and where criminals ended up in The Hague tribunal. And secondly, we should punish those multinational companies, especially European ones, that continue to violate those regulations that we have enacted, which is not to use minerals and ore riches from areas that are in war conflicts.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I think it has been a very useful exchange and I thank the honourable Members for the clarity of their interventions. Some of the honourable Members of the European Parliament missed the repercussions of the EP Resolutions and the Commission’s measures, how the EU adopted at the Foreign Affairs Council on 23 May Council conclusions on the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) that show a remarkable convergence with the EP resolution on the DRC of 10 March, including language on the individual responsibility of those responsible for the security and justice sector. In the Council conclusion of 23 May we made it clear that we will react to any downturn in the political situation and we will review the use of all the tools at our disposal.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The situation in Congo, despite the efforts of the government, remains dramatic. Serious human rights violations, war crimes and crimes against humanity are being committed. The ongoing conflict is also forcing the population to flee, threatened by an increasing number of armed groups controlling several villages. The north-east of the country, in particular, continues to be the hardest hit. Massacres, child recruitment and sexual violence have been reported on several occasions. In some areas there are restrictions on access even for humanitarian aid. Furthermore, this is taking place in the indifference of the international community and the almost total silence of the media. We need to launch a thorough investigation and put in place targeted and effective sanctions, putting an end to the indifference that has characterised the conflict so far.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. We are all protected by the dramatic fact that the situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo continues to deteriorate in the north-east of the country, where dozens of armed groups remain active and massacres and all kinds of war crimes, including sexual and gender-related crimes, as well as recruitment and use of children by armed groups, are systematically reported. The European Union must make concrete efforts to put an end to the escalation of violence against the helpless population by militias that have an interest in controlling one of the richest territory in the world. Firstly, through the immediate establishment of an independent international commission of inquiry to work in practice to implement the principle that no violation of rights can go unpunished, let alone the commission of real war crimes. Furthermore, we want a United Nations evaluation report on the results of the MONUSCO mission and, above all, we call on the UN contingent to make full use of the mandate assigned to it, namely to intervene to protect civilians. This mission has had a very ambiguous mandate and results that are difficult to establish.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Political tensions, internal armed conflicts, corruption, human rights violations, abysmal disparities between rich and poor and the absence of the middle class, all linked to hunger and a lack of basic needs for the majority of the population, form today's image of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Paradoxically, it is a country where huge reserves of mineral wealth are located. At the same time, 75% of the population live on less than $1 a day in income. 60% of all minerals in the world are minerals from the Congo. At the same time, only 30% of the diamond and tantala are exported in regular commercial terms, with the rest traded illegally, which then also finances the arming of various mutually fighting groups. I support the proposal that the European Union should use all diplomatic and commercial efforts to achieve and ensure internal stability in the Congo, the establishment and development of democracy and the rule of law, and development cooperation policies to help eradicate corruption and the illegal trade in the country's mineral wealth.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In less than two years more than 1 160 people have been killed. That is two people per day. Almost the same number of people have been abducted. Over 400 000 people have had to flee the country, 1.5 million are internally displaced and 7.5 million people are in need of assistance. Rape and sexual violence is widely used by both armed groups and government forces. Humanitarian workers can only offer limited help, since they and their convoys are being attacked themselves. And the security situation in the north-eastern part of DRC continues to deteriorate: massacres occur and children are recruited by the armed groups. To stop this horror, all parties to the conflict must be brought together to try to work out a solution. Abuses must be examined and, where needed, must be brought to the ICC. MONUSCO must become more effective in protecting the civilians and must be more rapid in its reactions where needed. The safety of humanitarian workers must be guaranteed.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, President, Mr Commissioner, honourable Members, I think we all felt the same sorrow and outrage when we learned about the attack on the nightclub in Orlando or the killing of a police chief and his wife in their home in Paris. Once more, innocent people have become victims of an act of terrorism in a place no one expected. Of course, we have seen this kind of horrendous violence before in our European cities, in Turkey, in Lebanon, in Tunisia, the United States, the Middle East and all over the world. It is a most distressing fact that these attacks were aimed at innocent civilians while they were having a drink in their neighbourhood bar, ready to go on a well-deserved holiday, buying their daily groceries, when they were at home with their family. The attack against a nightclub bringing together homosexuals was the last shocking event that took place in the United States. Another worrying fact is that most of these atrocities were executed by citizens who grew up in our own cities, among us, in our midst, sometimes in a process of self-radicalisation. We are faced with individuals who turned their back on our societies and the universal values of freedom, equality and free speech. It is no use talking only about foreign terrorist fighters. Foreign is now also in our own society, and if we truly want to stop terrorism in its tracks we need to show persons on the brink of radicalisation that their society, our society, offers better alternatives. So we are faced with a tremendous task to step up our efforts to prevent radicalisation, to counter violent extremism, to stop hate speech and fight discrimination. Of course we are fully committed to that cause. The European Union, its Member States, we are engaged in a balancing act between repression and prevention and to ensure that we understand really what is going on. The Heads of State and Government already highlighted the importance of preventing radicalisation and safeguarding our values in their statements of February 2015. Since then the European Union has not been sitting on its hands, how could we? We are currently implementing a range of measures to prevent radicalisation with a specific focus on detecting and removing internet content promoting terrorism, for instance. Let me give you a number of examples. The Europol Internet Referral Unit works together with internet companies to remove terrorist material from the internet, very important. Second, the European Union Internet Forum facilitates a dialogue with the private sector to combat illegal online hate speech. I think we cannot do without this cooperation of all actors, including the private sector. Certainly we work on the development of communication strategies to promote tolerance, non-discrimination, fundamental freedoms and solidarity throughout the Union. Then we have the Radicalisation Awareness Network supporting Member States with expertise and helping them to develop prevention programmes. We have the Syria Strategic Communication Advisory Team which is helping, assisting, working with Member States, to develop counter narratives against Da’esh. Another example that the EU is working on is rehabilitation for foreign fighter returnees and the prevention of radicalisation in prisons. A ministerial conference took place in October 2015 and is now being followed up with the support of funding from the Commission. Next to countering the hateful narratives of extremists, our efforts on prevention are also directed at strengthening the resilience of our communities. Maybe that is even the most important. That requires a much more holistic but at the same time effective approach involving different policy areas and many different actors. Educational citizenship, universal values and mutual respect must start at an early stage. Our young people are the ones most vulnerable and the ones who need to stay on board and it is our responsibility to give them the civic, social and cultural competence they need in our societies. This was also underlined in a joint declaration of the EU Ministers for Education and yourself, Mr Commissioner. Very important, building on this declaration, the Council adopted conclusions on developing media literacy and critical thinking and the role of youth policy in the fight against radicalisation. Following the first fundamental rights colloquium last year the Commission has appointed coordinators on anti-Islam hatred, on anti-Semitism and on tolerance to engage with all the relevant stakeholders. An advisor on religious freedom has also been appointed. Also, this is important in the context of promoting intra- and interfaith dialogue. Honourable Members, terrorism is in nature global and it does not stop at the EU borders. In complementarity with the work we are doing within the European Union, there is of course a continuous need to work together with our international partners to combat and prevent radicalism and terrorism. Let me give you also a few examples of our activities. In the Middle East and North Africa the European Union is supporting several projects on prevention of radicalisation, countering terrorism financing and working on judicial capacity. The European Union has developed on the Slovenian lead a so-called Western Balkans Counterterrorism Initiative and we also work with the Radicalisation Awareness Network in third countries like Tunisia, like Turkey, with first-line practitioners to prevent radicalisation. Also the global Counterterrorism Forum is an excellent example of a multilateral effort of countries around the world coming together and joining their efforts to combat and prevent terrorism in a very concrete plan of action. We have expended the network of our security and CT experts in the European Union delegations to work in the field and with civil society on preventing radicalisation and countering threats of terrorism. So, to summarise, combating and preventing terrorism is at the top of the European agenda. We are and we will remain fully committed to preventing radicalisation, countering violent extremism, stopping hate speech and fighting discrimination. I know there is a very strong will also among you and in this Parliament to make progress on de-radicalisation and countering violent extremism measures. We welcome in particular your Resolution of November 2015 as an important contribution. We share this determination and we look forward to working with you in order to advance as quickly as we can.

name: Tibor Navracsics
