text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the recent horrendous attacks in Europe remind us that terrorism is global and yet extremely local, as a majority of recent perpetrators have been our own citizens: born and raised on our territories, educated in our schools, now radicalised and inspired by an ideology of destruction, given into propaganda of hate and turning against their own fellow citizens and our common values. The fact that these Europeans were radicalised into violent extremism on our soil says something about the social fabric of our societies and the need to strengthen its resilience. Our response needs to be holistic. This is the approach you expressed in the reports prepared by your colleagues Julia Ward and Rachida Dati, and we have taken in our most recent communication on supporting the prevention of radicalisation leading to violent extremism. It is part of our larger Commission effort to implement the European agenda on security and it builds on existing capabilities and efforts. We have put forward an ambitious set of initiatives ranging from research and evidence-building to countering terrorist propaganda and hate speech online, addressing prison radicalistion, promoting inclusive education and reaching out to young people in general. And since violent extremism has no borders and several third countries face very similar challenges, we also foresaw measures to support third countries in their endeavour. We have several operational as well as security tools at hand. While prevention has to be our first priority, our security approach needs to be reinforced at the same time. We need to enhance our capability to disrupt terrorist activity, stem the flow of finance, prevent access to weapons and disrupt terrorist travel. Those returning to Europe from conflict areas are a particular concern. That is why we will propose a review of the Schengen Information System and why we have proposed systematic checks at the external borders for everyone entering and exiting the EU whether they are EU or non-EU citizens. Then there is the internet, which certainly appears to be accelerating the radicalisation process and where our young people are exposed to the poisonous and barbaric rhetoric of violent extremists. Recent investigations also demonstrate how the internet is playing a more prominent role in attacks themselves. This is precisely why we launched the EU Internet Forum in December 2015. We brought together ministers, Europol and high-level representatives of major internet companies. We agreed on two key objectives: that we must reduce accessibility to terrorist content online; and that we must empower civil society partners to increase the volume of positive alternative narratives online. In addressing the first objective an Internet Referral Unit has been established at Europol. In addition to providing substantive operational support to Member States, in just under a year it has referred over 8 000 pieces of terrorist content to the companies. In the vast majority of cases the material has been swiftly removed. We are now taking this one step further through a joint referral mechanism which is being developed by the internet companies to improve the speed and volume of referrals and prevent removed material from being re-uploaded elsewhere. In addressing the second objective, namely to create positive alternative narratives to that of the violent and divisive terrorist narrative, we have committed EUR 10 million to help equip civil society partners with the technical skills and training that they require to ensure their voices are seen and heard online. Those efforts start primarily at local level. Police officers, youth counsellors, prison and probation staff, and teachers are the practitioners best placed to identify the early warning signs of radicalisation. But they are also brought together at the European level through the Radicalisation Awareness Network Centre of Excellence. Through this network of networks more than 2 400 local practitioners from all over Europe are working together. We committed a budget of EUR 25 million for the next four years to help the network fulfil its mission, while under our internal security funds over EUR 314 million is available for anti-radicalisation projects for the period 2014-2020. Let me now turn to another key pillar of prevention – education. Education, both inside and outside the classroom, and youth activities in general, are crucial for this comprehensive approach. Education plays a vital role in the socialisation of children, in developing social and emotional skills. Fundamental values can be best internalised from an early age. We need solid foundations which help young people to be resilient against extremist ideologies and violence, and have a common sense of belonging. That is why, in cooperation with France, I called for an extraordinary meeting of the education ministers in Paris in March 2015 and we together adopted the Paris Declaration. On that basis we proposed a series of concrete measures to reach out to teachers, educators, youth workers and, most importantly, young people on the ground. We are working towards a comprehensive policy framework in the form of a Council recommendation to promote inclusion and fundamental values in education. It will offer policymakers and practitioners concrete policy guidance and facilitate mutual learning, building on research evidence of what works. We are mobilising the Erasmus+ programme where we are making available this year EUR 400 million for transnational cooperation projects. Projects aiming at inclusion and fundamental values will be given priority. In addition, with EUR 13 million we will upscale and disseminate successful grassroots initiatives. Horizon 2020 will also be further mobilised to support research into violent radicalisation. Teachers and trainers are key and we will step up our efforts to support them. e-Twinning, the world’s biggest teachers’ network, which is supported by the Erasmus+ programme, enables 300 000 teachers across the EU to run joint projects and link pupils from different countries and backgrounds. We will extend e-Twinning further to selected neighbourhood countries so that pupils and classrooms can better know and understand each other from an early age. We will also set up a network to encourage direct contact between young people and positive role models, for instance, entrepreneurs, artists, sports persons and even formerly radicalised people. They will be selected at local level and invited to visit schools, youth clubs, sports clubs and prisons to share their experiences. Finally, we will set up Erasmus+ virtual exchanges between young people both within and outside the EU. Our aim is to bring 200 000 of them together through structured and moderated online discussions by 2020 to raise empathy and promote intercultural dialogue. Honourable Members, resilience against violent radicalisation will come through a combination of these actions and partners. The Commission is determined to help and support in every way we can in order to find a holistic solution to this urgent challenge we are all faced with. Together with all my fellow Commissioners, I stand ready to work with you in the European Parliament, with Member States and civil society to implement these measures. I trust that I can count on your support.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to thank you for having this debate today, because I believe that the issue of radicalisation and de-radicalisation is one of the important building blocks for reducing terrorism, which is currently occupying the European Union, or perhaps being able to take it away from it altogether. We are currently seeing in the attacks that we are dealing with new forms of radicalisation, in addition to the older forms of radicalisation that are already known. I believe that we need to pay more attention to this. I am thinking of areas that are not discussed so often. For example, in the area of prisons, Member States must take serious measures to prevent radicalisation in prisons, so that those who start with minor crimes do not end up operating as assassins – well recruited by terrorist networks – within the European Union. Secondly, it has also become very clear in recent attacks that we are dealing with new forms of self-radicalisation, that is to say, with people who are given guidance on how to commit the most serious crimes through Internet programmes, which are specifically put online by the ISIS propaganda machine, and accordingly we must both combat this propaganda machine and impose very severe penalties on those who are being punished in a very strict manner. , which are setting this propaganda machine in motion. It is also necessary to offer assistance to those who have already entered the networks and also to delete pages that could encourage young people to participate in such a network, because they are portrayed as heroes there – what we call terrorism in our penal code. Furthermore, it is essential that the new platforms are used for the better. The Internet can be used not only for the negative, but also for the positive. In other words, we must develop a very clear counter-strategy against this kind of propaganda, such as that carried out by ISIS or Al Qaeda. I believe that the Commission has also taken important measures in this regard within the framework of the Internet Referral Unit and within the framework of the EU Internet Forum, and cooperation with private companies in this sector is also extremely important. Furthermore, we must not overlook the fact that IS and other terrorist organisations are also trying to invade the social sphere and to appeal to young people who feel insecure in society, who do not feel accepted or accepted. We must ensure that the Member States offer the better counter-offers or support social organisations in such a way that they can actually offer good opportunities to young people.

name: Ana Gomes
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, in fact, in November, Parliament adopted a report on this subject with concrete measures, alongside cooperation, coordination, information sharing between security and information forces, which pointed precisely to the importance of measures in preventing radicalisation in prisons and in our ghettos, in the Moolenbeeks that go around Europe. But instead, we end up with the European PNR, which has been presented as a magic bullet against terrorism, which is bumpy against charter and private flights, thus illustrating the inconsistency of so-called security policies that do not really provide any security, and I will not even talk about what is going on in terrorist financing.  In addition, we continue to pay the price for Europe's lack of coordination, inaction, contradictions in our foreign policy and contradictions related to our internal security in the face of conflicts: Syria, Iraq, Libya, Turkey, Ukraine and others in our neighbourhood.  Our security depends on ideological and political combat within and outside our borders, but we will not know how to stop it if we continue to leave room for the fascist and Nazi far-right to inflate the winds of xenophobia and hatred against refugees and migrants, and if we continue to deny foreign fighters when they are, in fact, young Europeans, our , born, raised and pushed into small crime and radicalized in our prisons, who have attacked us, as they attack other peoples in the ranks of Daesh, because they fuel resentments against the societies in which they grew up, feeling excluded and discriminated against. It is lacking for our governments, the Council and the Commission to recognise that neoliberal policies have failed miserably and have fostered insecurity and populism in Europe by creating unemployment, ghettos, exclusion, more inequalities and social injustice, creating conditions for Islamic states and groups of fascist Nazi hooligans to recruit our young people and turn them into killer wolves. It is these same policies that have cut back on the capabilities and training of our defence and security forces, which have cut back on the rehabilitation capabilities of our prisons, letting them become centres of radicalisation, and have never, in fact, invested in radicalisation prevention programmes.  Now the Commission is talking about it. Very well! Resources are needed, but also smart social policies, involving municipal structures, schools, clubs, non-governmental organisations, the private sector, and actively involving in this effort families and religious communities, especially European Muslims who suffer the devastating effect of terrorist attack and behaviour.  We must prevent short-term reactions such as those suggesting the withdrawal of nationality to suspected terrorists or the criminalization of internet use. You have to... name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Radicalisation is a cross-border phenomenon and it happens everywhere. In the 28 EU Member States, there are estimated to be at least 6 000 radicalised Muslims, according to experts. It is certainly wrong to explain the cause only in the case of social deprivation. The motives are very diverse, including an aversion to the West and wanting to mean something. If such persons resort to violence and want to carry out attacks here, possibly after returning from conflict zones, then the situation becomes critical. We must combat individuals who feel the need to brutally impose a different state model with brute force. And by us, I mean all citizens of goodwill, including right-minded Muslims. Together we must fight for equality between men and women, the rights of gay couples and other values of enlightenment. Moreover, fighting terrorists is not just policing. The RAN anti-radicalisation network, for example, can also provide added value as a European project. This network brings together frontline workers who work every day with radicalised individuals or people with a sensitive profile. Wardens, health professionals and others share their experiences through that network. They have all the crucial information that can help the security services with early detection. For example, an OCMW employee may notice a suspicious home situation during an intake interview. For example, a man who refuses to shake hands with the female employee or teachers who notice that young children are forced to follow Ramadan during weekend classes by imams. These employees can then pass on the information to the police forces. Fighting terror is a matter for all of us.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President. Thank you to the representatives of the Commission and the Council, ladies and gentlemen. I keep Orlando's killer's selfie in the office and they ask me why. I do not want to forget the face of banality and cruelty in these times on the internet. I do not believe that anyone has doubts about the need to impede and stop the capacity for action and expansion of terrorist organizations. However, in order to defeat terrorism and the various violent fanaticisms of these times, prevention is as important as police intelligence or judicial activity. We must be able to effectively challenge a political logic that walks on human suffering and for this the most important thing in the long run is to defuse hatred, dehumanization and the legitimization of cruelty. On the other hand, the ideology that recruits fans also generates other forms of hatred. Therefore, combating crime and achieving prevention is crucial, and it is not easy. Young people need to get ideas that prevent the legitimization of violence against others. They need to prevent the temptation to hate other human groups, whether invented or real; prevent the temptation to see as enemies the neighbors themselves, their own family. In this globalized world, under the domain of communication technologies, our way of perceiving reality has changed. Especially the new generations must develop a vision of their own but coherent of what the dignity and humanity of each person means. That is why we welcome the Commission's new measures, as the European Union strategy adopted in 2005 had become obsolete and European jihadists are statistically overrepresented among those who will train from anywhere in the world. Experts insist on linking quality studies on the phenomenon of violent radicalization to public policy-making. Experts, local authorities and citizens are asking us not to remain in rhetoric of limited effectiveness. Those who aspire to the moral disintegration of our societies to bend and impose their sexual obsessions on us must know that we will overcome them with the law and with respect for fundamental rights.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in France and North America we are faced with a change in terrorism and radicalisation. Even more damaging is to respond with increasingly guarded democracies, islamophobia and wars to violence that is not warlike, but linked to individual or social uprooting that is difficult to decipher. Joe Cox's murder is reminiscent of the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in 1914: the shooting of a multi-ethnic empire does not fall from the sky, it is the result of decades of political desertion of the elites. If terrorism is responded to by the policy of fear, fearing conflict, it will be terrorism that wins.

text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to reiterate here, as we did at the beginning of this sitting today, my shock, my sorrow and my anger at the attack in Orlando just over a week ago, in which 49 people were brutally killed, at least as many injured and hundreds of relatives, friends and girlfriends, and do not understand what that could be like. But also about Mrs Jo Cox, who, before she became an MEP, worked here in this House, was one of us, so to speak, and who was also brutally murdered, also recently, about the police couple in France – all those we thought of today at the beginning of this sitting. This was a clearly homophobic attack under the name of ISIS. Today, it is a question of how we can prevent people who become radicalised from becoming violent extremists. On the one hand, this requires education, employment and inclusion, because quite often the causes are that there is no meaning in life, no work, no job, no hope. To give people opportunities and joy in life again, the feeling that I can do something in my life, that is necessary. And a second thing – and this has already been mentioned in part: working in youth centres, in schools, but also in prisons, where young people often come because of minor or major offences and there is a risk that they will become radicalised and then become violent. I would like to briefly mention two examples that do just that: the 2015 European Citizens' Prize was won for Austria by the Network of Social Cohesion, whose staff go to prisons and work successfully there to de-radicalise young people, young people, but also older people. And another example, very topical: Yesterday in Molenbeek there was a meeting between a martial arts centre from Vienna with martial arts champions and people from Molenbeek. They were invited to show here what they are doing in the centre in Vienna. Martial arts, which very often attracts young people who want to let off steam, so to speak – new things are created in this environment. This must be encouraged, these are positive examples. If they work together and say 'IS is not in the Koran' when Muslims raise their hands against ISIS, including in sport – we should continue to promote that, and then hopefully there will be fewer of these attacks.

name: Kristina Winberg

name: Steeve Briois
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, with Charlie Hebdo, The Bataclan, Brussels, Orlando and now Magnanville, the list of attacks perpetrated by the Islamic State continues to grow. If the peoples of Europe are right to pay tribute to the victims, politicians must act. To date, however, actions against Islamist terrorism have not been reflected in their results, on the contrary. Despite the so-called high alert levels, it is still possible to fly to Brussels without being checked, as I myself saw last week. The same goes for national border controls that still do not exist. In short, jihadist terrorists can move peacefully in this beautiful Europe.  To overcome the threat, one must first have the courage to name it. However, by scheduling today a debate called "Preventing radicalisation leading to violent extremism and terrorism", you are practising the policy of the ostrich because you deliberately deny the term "Islamists". name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Allow me first to add my voice in tribute to Jo Cox, a tough mother of two who got into politics to make a difference for all the right reasons, and who was so brutally killed while doing her duty. I know all of us here would want to ensure that her legacy in fighting hate is preserved. We must do what we can to find the right balance between allowing our freedoms and ensuring citizens’ safety. One of the hardest lessons learned from the attacks in Europe was that our information-sharing capabilities are still not being fully utilised. Europe cannot afford to play catch-up. Radicalisation, whether online or on land, is one of the toughest challenges our enforcement agencies face. We need Europol to have the resources it needs, and we need to come down harder on those who preach hate and use religion as a disguise for their message of evil. It is not only law enforcement. We also need a new approach to integration in our societies, where we see this as a two-way process of respect for people’s rights but also respect for European values. Work to overcome obstacles to revoking passports of so-called ‘foreign fighters’ – particularly dual nationals who travel to conflict zones before coming back to Europe to radicalise and recruit – must continue. They do not deserve any protection an EU passport may give them. If the horrific attack in Orlando showed anything it is that terrorism knows no borders, no nations. It is a global struggle that requires a global partnership for its defeat. Notwithstanding the horror of the crime in Florida, the worst of times brought out the best in people who stood up, scared but undeterred, and shouted that while today we mourn, in the end, love always wins over hate, and those voices echoed around the world. It is this that will be the lasting tribute to the victims of terror everywhere. Terrorism may well still cast its shadow on our lives. It will not however define us. It is the determination to continue to live our lives as we see fit, despite apprehension, that will show the true character of Europe.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Thank you, President-in-Office, Dear Plenum! Jo Cox died last week because of the beliefs and principles she believed in. She believed that diversity could unite us. She believed in values that, if everyone believed in them, would bring peace and coexistence.  Radicals are willing to die for ideas they believe in. But their ideas are counter to basic human rights and European values, because they are based on the glorifying of one at the expense of others. In the light of terrorist attacks and threats, the European Union is currently dealing with the problem of radicalising people, especially young people, who join Islamic extremists and their ideas. And yes, this is essential, we need European cooperation and information exchange between law enforcement authorities in order to combat the dangers of radicalisation and terrorism. But you know very well that radicalisation is possible in many other fields. Therefore, we must not forget that, in the crisis in which we live, the radicalisation of other groups can also be unfolded at the same time and as quickly as possible. This is already partly demonstrated in the attitudes of certain groups towards LGBTI people, immigrants, refugees, individual religious groups, Roma, people with disabilities, etc.  In order to prevent radicalisation, the first focus should be paid to addressing the causes of them and tackling the socio-economic situation and, secondly, dialogue with citizens and the fight against hate speech – especially online.  The political group of socialists and democrats has made particular emphasis and emphasis on this today. Writing and disseminating information online as if it had been launched into a new European freedom, which is completely unregulated. However, Member States urgently need measures to limit and punish hate speech and intolerance, cancer and discord in society.  We must call on the Member States or the Council of the Union to immediately stop blocking the anti-discrimination directives. Here, too, we are showing that we are not speaking with one voice, which is intolerable. Tomorrow the result of the referendum, no matter what it may be, will be a good school to find out where the European Union's politics are going.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I personally did not know Jo Cox, but I want to say how grateful I am that the President today took the opportunity to pass sympathy. As I come from Northern Ireland, I went through 40 years of this type of terrorism, and I know that today we have a husband left without a wife, and two children without a mother. I do not think any words can actually say how terrible that is to the family. And quite clearly the terrorists involved and the terrorist attacks in those cities by the so-called Islamic State are not simply a foreign policy problem, it is often a home-grown problem, often involving troubled young individuals radicalised in the countries they mercilessly attack. We need to strengthen the preventive strategies in our prisons, as well as engage in civil society, religious leaders and local communities. Radicalisation towards any terrorist group or violent activity regardless of religion or ideology is unacceptable.

Not to mention one of our allies, such as Saudi Arabia, which practices a systematic and sustained spread of Wahhabism, a radical doctrine related to takphyrism professed by Al-Qaeda, Al-Nusra or the so-called Islamic State. Saudi Arabia also has a bull: from 2008 to 2011, 17.3 billion in arms exports by the European Union. Solutions: cutting funding, cutting off the supply of weapons, delving into the solutions negotiated with regional actors within the framework of the UN, or 2012, non-interference, and also combating poverty and social exclusion in our neighbourhoods with real plans, turned into ghettos where Wahhabists or takfirists find the breeding ground.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Today we heard a Commission opinion on radicalisation and terrorism. Measures must be taken on the ground where people live: in Brussels or Munich. They do not live 'in the EU'. We have seen in Brussels that parallel societies are Islamic hotbeds and retreats for terrorists, because they are closed off and because Sharia law applies there before our laws. The Alternative for Germany has made very specific demands: foreign financing of mosques must be banned, imams must be trained with us – not Salafist preachers with petrodollars from Saudi Arabia! All Islam associations must unconditionally distance themselves from legally relevant parts of Sharia law, and anti-constitutional associations must be banned from building and operating mosques. Erdogan has said that the mosques are his barracks and the faithful are his soldiers. Let us clean up Erdogan's barracks if they are barracks, and disarm his soldiers if they are soldiers!

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: – The EU is the second largest funder of the Palestinian Authority, an institution of Jew haters and terrorists. The European Parliament invites Holocaust denier and terror reward Abbas. This man gives fixed monthly salaries to perpetrators of terror against Jews. Jewish blood is on his hands and Mr Schulz will shake these hands warmly tomorrow. The EU funds Palestinian radicalisation. Palestinian children learn to hate Jews and glorify terror, and the language of the Palestinian Authority is the language of violence. It is a disgrace and there is a welcome culture in the EU. Mosques are loaded with weapons of war as barracks. Hundreds, if not thousands, of terrorists are preparing attacks here. I say to this committee: stop Islamisation, stop sending money to Abbas and Erdogan, close national borders.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (
text: PPE). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue we are dealing with today, once again, depends on the strikes, the terrorist attacks that are taking place in Europe and around the world. The latest research in Europe has shown a dramatic increase in crime among adolescents and young people. It should concern us because it is happening; Young people, when they have no hope, they have no jobs, they have no perspective, they pre-print criminals and they feel heroes when they provoke hatred and panic.  We should be concerned about how this phenomenon develops, where young people are radicalised. One way is prisons, detention centres, where, to a large extent, only correction is not done and another route is the Internet, where unfortunately the roads are uncontrolled, so far uncontrolled controls and the ways in which these people evolve en masse, arm themselves with hatred and turn against society.  Friends and friends, the answer to these people, who want to cause the death of their fellow human beings, to those people who are being condemned by hatred and anger, is more humanism, more solidarity, finally taking responsibility from all of us, leading to a better Europe.  I would like to share with you the experience of a rhetoric that needs to change in this Chamber: "There are no innocent victims." All victims of terrorism are innocent. Guilty victims don't exist, and this rhetoric of segregation you realize is arming hands and awakening false morbid consciences that feed the terrorist's hand. The answer to hatred and fear is love and more Europe.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – No one wakes up one day as a radical Salafist who leaves their home and family and leaves for the battlefield in Syria to join IS. There's a process ahead of that. Radicalisation is taking place in our residential areas. This means that the identification and tackling of it must start at that local level with the local residents, the teachers, the parents, the imams and the youth workers. Not every Muslim who is poor and feels discriminated against becomes a jihadist or a terrorist. The causes of radicalisation are not only socio-economic in nature. Radicalisation is also a religious derailment, and this fact is too often denied in this Parliament. And why is it a European problem and should we in the European Parliament also pay attention to it? In a European Union without internal borders, radicalisation in The Hague, Molenbeek or the banlieues of Paris is a problem for all of us, and with more than 4 000 European jihadists, the recent terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels make it clear that we have a serious problem. It is very important that all Member States dealing with young people who are radicalising actually have and implement a common strategy. It must end with the non-commitment for European governments to tackle radicalisation effectively. At present, European countries are not being economically addressed to this responsibility. The same applies to the exchange of information and intelligence between the national security services. Numerous databases have been set up to ensure that a person who is seen by a country as a danger to society cannot simply travel to another Member State, where he is not in a database. Unfortunately, however, these resources are still under-used and it is proving far too easy for radicalised young people, but also for hate preachers, for example, to travel back and forth between European countries. That is why it is in our common interest that every European country has its deradicalisation programme in order. And let me just say that blindly blocking websites without the intervention of a judge is, as far as I am concerned, a sham measure which does constitute a serious curtailment of our freedom. We must not go in this direction and also in the fight against terrorism: let us be careful of our freedom.

name: Czesław Hoc (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In principle, each country has its own national identity, rich and proud national history and traditions. And every country protects these values. Today, Europe and the world are experiencing a dramatic time: irrepressed migration, radical extremism, terrorism. A lot of people lose their lives. A lot of people suffer. But we must also be aware that the integration of the people of Europe into refugees is not possible if there is no desire for assimilation and adaptation by refugees. Integration without assimilation is pure utopia, it is wishful thinking. Moreover, even millions of refugees admitted to Europe will not solve this dramatic problem. Europe must therefore help at the source of the conflict, i.e. provide financial, food, social, legal assistance, assistance in the construction of schools, hospitals, infrastructure, etc. In addition, it is important to remember the principle of ordo caritatis – first to provide help, safety and mercy to your family, then to your homeland, and then to another community.

name: Laura Agea (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, every time a tragic event happens, such as Orlando and the murder of Mrs Cox, we are here talking. We are here talking and we are also working, perhaps in committee, on the documents on combating terrorism. While we are trying to cure the effects of what is an even higher phenomenon, we forget that the sooner the causes have to be addressed, the causes should be understood. I would like to mention a few of them: we have poverty, social distress, marginalisation, lack of job prospects, cultural alienation, broken family ties. These are the causes that create the breeding ground for radicalization. Let us not forget that many of the new terrorists, of those who are formed through social media, are people born and raised on our continent, they are people who have lived on the margins, because today we do not know how to face a crisis, a social emergency that weighs in this Europe and not only on the citizens of Europe, but also on those who have arrived and who we have not been able to integrate and Sometimes, we didn't even want to integrate. So we must always remember what the causes are, because only by understanding the causes do we cure the effects. Today it is important, today we continue to talk, we solve the causes of poverty, because only through the dismantling of poverty, the taking care of the poor, all the poor, can we tackle the problem of radicalisation.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we sounded the alarm many years ago about the danger of reckless immigration, of openness to all and of the expansion throughout Europe of a radical Islamist preaching that was political, that had nothing to do with the Koran, but had much to do with hatred of our civilisation, we only got trials, accusations of racism and xenophobia. Now, at last, we hear the Commission and the Council say that they have realised that there is a danger, there is even the 'uberisation' of terrorism, in the middle of our homes, they shoot the policemen, they even shoot gay people. We should be reassured to hear the voices of the Commission, which tells us that they are looking at how to prevent terrorism. However, when you read the words that even the EU counter-terrorism coordinator, Gilles De Kerchove, said, and I quote, about foreign fighters, that we should inevitably be able to reintegrate them, because we cannot lock them all up in prisons, that we will have to offer them a new way of life... We're crazy! Here in Europe we do not have clear ideas, we must throw them out of Europe... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Axel Voss (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The recent attacks in Orlando and also in Paris have shown several conspicuous features. One is that all of a clear of all we are dealing with very individual terrorism here. They have shown that the attacks are carried out massively with firearms. You have shown that this individual self-radicalisation takes place through the Internet or in prison, and it is also striking that these are domestic terrorists, because they are also citizens of our Member States. That is why we must act accordingly at these different levels. On the one hand , and this has been mentioned many times in recent debates – we are talking about the fight against illegal weapons and arms smuggling. Secondly – and you also mentioned this, Commissioner – we are talking about how we can, via the Internet and social media, work more closely with the economy and find out how we can reduce this radicalisation there. Thirdly, however, we would also need a kind of programme for the prisons in order to get a better grip on this there. It is hardly understandable that they can become even more radicalised there. Then I think we need to do more education, particularly for teachers, and you mentioned that too. Teachers in schools will play a key role here. We might need a kind of single reporting centre for abnormalities, including for family members. Then, as has also been mentioned in the last discussions in Strasbourg, we need the interoperability of databases, which also applies to biometric data. In addition, perhaps, there is also a change to the Schengen Borders Code, but also the rapid construction of the PNR system, the review of Koranic schools or the payment of imams from abroad.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Two weeks ago, I was in the Sinjar Mountains in northern Iraq, where the Yazidis withstood the onslaught of IS isterrorists for months. In the midst of this devastated landscape, a soldier showed us on his mobile phone documents of shot foreign fighters, including ID, Social Security ID and driver's license of a compatriot, an Austrian, a thirty-three-year-old crane operator. Since then, The question of what drove this man has not left me. Obviously he voluntarily decided to do so, there must have been some event that made him do it. Someone must have recruited him and smuggled him into Syria, and almost certainly he must have committed a number of crimes and atrocities at that time. This is not an isolated case, it is a mass phenomenon. Only if we can answer these questions can we stop the phenomenon. It is a complex problem, because the terrorists do not shy away from anything and how there will be setbacks that will challenge our patience. I welcome the Commission's initiative because it is not stuck in symbolic action, but is trying to solve the problems at its root.  A sustainable solution to the problem requires foresight, differentiation and the combination of military, intelligence, police, social worker and educational measures. The Commission's strategy is based on tried and tested instruments, and RAN is mentioned, including the Internet observatory that we set up at Europol. This is very important, but we also need special attention to international cross-border cooperation, which is lacking. Nor should we forget that the recruitment of foreign fighters is particularly easy, where living conditions are poor. Youth unemployment, poor housing conditions are incubators for the foreign fighters.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: ECR). Madam President, violent radicalisation is a challenge that requires broad action on security issues and dealing with the operative factors. As set out in the European Agenda for Security, absolute priority must be given to preventing and preventing the spread of terrorist Islamic propaganda and hate speech. Education and political education must be at the forefront of the defence and protection of European citizens. The European Union must, within its limits and competences, help national actions to provide real added value in situ.  Unfortunately, Minister, Turkey is not at the forefront of countering terrorism, because it is itself carrying out state terrorism and, unfortunately, Turkey is setting up in European territories, in particular in the occupied territories of the Republic of Cyprus, fundamentalist mosques and Islamic schools which are greenhouses of Islamic terrorism and extremism. This needs to be very careful. I believe that protection is of the utmost importance.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, two initial words: solidarity and rejection. Solidarity with the victims of Magnanville, of the United Kingdom , our friend Jo Cox – and with the victims of Orlando. And I reject. Rejection without palliatives to any form of terror. I applaud and welcome the Communication published by the Commission on 14 June on the prevention of radicalisation. We are facing a new and very complex threat. Unfortunately, the latest attacks have shown us how easy these individuals are to train through social media and the agility and speed of spreading terrorist propaganda online. That is why I, as rapporteur for Europol, and together with the whole Parliament, have provided the IRU with the necessary legal basis for the development of its activity. But I would also like to say that I consider it necessary to carry out continuous research on the causes and forms of this phenomenon so that we can act coherently and, above all, quickly. I support the necessary interoperability of information systems, giving adequate access to state law ensuring, in particular by reviewing the Schengen Information System as soon as possible. We must make more use of the SRS – the Radicalisation Awareness Network – and equip it with greater skills and means, improve the training of prison staff, both to identify and prevent and to contribute to the reintegration of prisoners, to promote and encourage greater coordination and cooperation between all Member States, especially with Europol and Eurojust , and improve the social inclusion and values of the Union. That is why, Commissioner, I support the Commission's proposal for the use of Erasmus+, education and youth forums for intercultural debate. In conclusion, the Union and all States must strengthen and improve all necessary tools in the fight and prevention against any form of radicalisation.

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, while 9/11/2001 was the work of teams of Al-Qaeda operatives sent to the United States, today most acts of terrorism are the result of radicalised nationals who one day decide to kill as many people around them as possible. Why and how do they get radicalised and, even more important, how can we prevent that radicalisation? However, let us not forget that radicalisation does not come out of the blue, usually it is the result of increasing pressure exerted through siren calls and propaganda instigating hate and praising mass killing as a pressure-release, using in most cases the relative anonymity of the net. Some people, usually from outside our countries, are doing that and we must, apart from countering their narrative and even discrediting it, find those people and deal with them according to our laws. Because letting those people get radicalised and not interfering with that and concentrating our efforts on preventing them from committing the horrible crimes they are determined to commit is not enough. Sooner or later they will find a way. But if we actively engage in dismantling those sources of radicalisation both in mosques and on the net, in cooperation with the Muslim communities themselves, and engage in the active countering of their narratives of hate for a long period to come, then we stand the chance to do away with this phenomenon. After all, some years ago a well-known author of espionage books, Tom Clancy, if I am not mistaken, described exactly such a case when a recruiter of Jihadists was discredited in the eyes of his followers ended up being captured. His imaginary plot has become reality today, why not his recipe?

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Commission seems to assume that the terrorists first take a psychotest, then obtain the gun licence, buy the shopping permit, then buy the weapon and register it by the police, and then carry out a terrorist attack. That is why the geniuses of the Commission have proposed to severely restrict legal gun ownership. Under the pretext of 'fight against terrorism', decent people are being deprived of their freedoms. And then the ladies and gentlemen of the Commission are surprised that the EU is getting less and less support. In fact, Commissioner Bie-kowska claims that the EU must do this because hundreds of thousands of people are killed with legal weapons every year. That's not true. The real figure is around 1500 for the whole of Europe. I therefore call on the Commission to withdraw this amendment to the Firearms Directive altogether. It does not help a little in the fight against terrorism.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Minister, Commissioner, I greet the Commission for the document presented last week on the prevention of radicalisation, thus responding to the calls of this Parliament. This communication makes it clear that radicalisation is not the result of a single factor. It is a complex phenomenon to which the information society has added even more elements.  We must therefore address this phenomenon in its entirety. That is, looking at prevention, sanctioning and reintegration. But also by developing a set of cross-cutting measures in several areas, and the greater effectiveness of which will be the greater the proximity to citizens: whether by regions, chambers, schools or community centres. In this context, prisons are a central element. We do not want prisons to become either in the universities of crime or in the new centres of radicalisation. We know that these are imminently national competences, but the Union must support measures to prevent the prison system and invest in more successful reintegration. And the Union must also support long-term policies, particularly in the educational field. Of course, radicalisation leading to violent fundamentalism must also be sanctioned, blaming the guilty and deterring potential instigators. The proposed amendment of sis Ii of the Schengen Information System, to be presented at the end of this year, should introduce a set of improvements to enable SIS to contribute to more concerted and effective action by Member States, both at preventive and sanctioning level. Finally, let's not neglect the reinstatement. From children exposed to radicalized environments to condemned adults, we need to seek their reintegration, returning them to society, bringing them back to their core values. Parliament and the Commission can and must therefore work together. I presented in the budget for 2016 proposals for a pilot project in the context of the deradicalisation of children and young people. I hope you succeed. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. We will not have a debate on the need for genuine joint European action. In fact, I agree immeasurably that education and education have a lot of role to play in this whole issue. That is why I ask: when will the moment come for you, in the European People's Party, to talk about the endlessly disgusting propaganda that the Orban government, the Hungarian Government, is doing and that all terrorism is being brought back to migration?

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Speaking in personal terms and speaking in terms of PPE, we never confuse immigration with terrorism. On the contrary, we have always said that our response to immigration required two points: first, trying to solve the problems at the origin; second, to have a humanitarian response. Confusing both is a speech that cannot fail to disprove.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – The recently published Communication from the European Commission on preventing radicalisation leading to violent extremism makes a number of recommendations. Great emphasis is placed on education in the European Union, based on shared values. In addition to guidance on raising children in a spirit of diversity, teachers would be able to capture the first signs of radicalization among students. The aim is to insuce young people's shared values, but unfortunately this is not sufficiently precise.  While the European Commission sees an iunctim between radicalisation and recent terrorist attacks, it does not explicitly say that they are carried out by Islamic extremists. The European Commission should better diagnose the situation by rejecting misunderstood political correctness and return to the roots of Europe, christian values, and articulate them loudly.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Freedom is the most protected value in European societies. The same could not be concluded for another value that is fatally linked to freedom and which is becoming increasingly important to Europeans and, historically, a record-breaking long life in peace, I am talking, of course, about security. Unfortunately, there has been a sharp increase in the feeling of danger in recent years. Freedom and the European way of life are threatened by many factors, the so-called hybrid war, the increasingly violent extremists, the precarious security situation with refugees and migrants, radicalisation. Of all of us, terrorism is most at risk – not only imported, but also domestic. Europe is therefore security-vulnerable, living in a security vacuum since the Cold War. It therefore needs a new coherent security strategy, a more efficient use of security and defence potentials, and, above all, more budgetary resources in all Member States. This is not only about investment in security and defence structures, but also in quality education, and other areas that enable better social integration, especially for young people. I congratulate Commissioner Navracsics, who, in the European Commission's statement, has put out concrete measures, also supported by financial resources. It is now the Member States' turn. In the area of security, therefore, the EU will show its effectiveness in breaking up terrorist networks and organisations, 4,000 of them in the European Union, when it more effectively confronts hate propaganda, when it succeeds in protecting its external borders, when it secures peace and security in its neighbourhood, when it broadly set out the concept of deradicalisation in all European societies, not just on the Internet and in prisons. Let me conclude, we cannot rely permanently on the help of others when we talk about security, it is time for Europeans to contribute more to it than before.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam Presidencies, honourable members, there is nothing complicated about combating radicalisation, but one thing is clear: it does not fight empty talk and good slogans. The reason for its radicalization and its foundations are very simple, there are two. First of all, someone has to pay for it, and secondly there has to be someone to radicalize. Who pays for it? Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Turkey - countries that profess radical Islam, which pay for Salafist extremist radical organizations. Who's radicalized? Those who have gone to European countries and there have been greeted in the wrong way. They were told: "Your difference is very valuable. Be different. Stay together, stay where you are. Profess your values." These people should be told: "If you want to come to Germany, you will do like the Germans. If you want to go to Poland – you will do like the Poles". And the rest are empty talk and a very serious long and empty talk and political hypocrisy.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Madam President, again, in the minutes of silence, candles, weeping and anger at this terrorism which strikes us relentlessly and which we must defend ourselves against without really knowing when it will strike us again. Yesterday it was the young men in Orlando or a couple of policemen who fulfilled a duty to protect us. I want to give them all a huge "thank you" because they have given their lives so that I can exercise my freedom. The terrorists want to scare us. We know this well here in Brussels when they repeat their threats and we don't know where we'll be safe. We cannot give up our way of life, because that would be the same as telling them that they have won this new war which is terrorism. But in order for Europeans to continue living in an area of freedom and security, we need to take steps to prevent terrorism and combat radicalisation. We must do so without complexes, as the People's Party, which has made the fight against terrorism a priority, contrary to those here in this House seem not to understand that, in terrorism, prevention is very important, but so are security measures, the exchange of information and defending ourselves, by all means permitted by law , of those who only have in mind to take us down. We need to combat the online recruitment of those who join ISIS; radicalization in prisons; and we need to boost education. But above all, we need unity and political will to effectively fight terrorism, that will that is rapidly fading after an attack, jeop for the safety of Europeans. I conclude by reminding all European victims, inside and outside our borders and asking the Commission for what I have been calling for for seven years: a European directive on victims of terrorism, because victims of terrorism are killed to frighten the whole of society. We are all victims of terrorism.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, radicalisation, as well as terrorism or extremism, knows no borders. And it is all these three phenomena that are a great and unpredictable threat to us. In the fight against them, the role of the European Union is important and I am not afraid to say that it is irreplaceable. It's more important than ever. Its task and that of its agencies must be to link the individual Member States, information and components.  Unfortunately, in the past, as we could see in the attacks in Paris or Brussels, it just didn't work. And not only within the European Union itself, but also in cooperation with third countries. Let us connect and cooperate with countries from Africa, work with Turkey, work with other states to combat radicalisation, extremism and violence.  The fight against radicalisation itself is not so simple. In my opinion, this stems mainly from unmanily managed integration and long-term frustration, and from the loss or complete absence of European values. It is therefore extremely important to address these very causes, thus preventing the further spread of radicalism. First of all, we must focus on young people, as my previous leaders from the European People's Party have already said: we have a plan and the European People's Party wants to apply its strategy, which it adopted recently in its meetings.  If the role of the European Union fails here, we will see events in the future, as in previous months, and we will never be able to control radicalisation and the associated terrorism or extremism. I therefore call for joint cooperation. There in this is the alpha and omega of all success with radicalization.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his work I agree with this communication from the Commission and believe it is important that we work in Europe, between the Member States, on the ground in schools – there is probably the decisive thing to be done – and internationally against radicalisation and extremism. But also give me the opportunity to say this: this is above all an invitation to ourselves and our example that we are setting. I heard a speech earlier from the right about people talking about other people as scum. When such speeches are delivered out of our ranks, this is already the beginning of radicalisation. As politicians, we have to set an example that we want to experience democratic processes and that we accept the opinion of the other in these processes. The freedom of other opinion as a matter of course, without discriminating against the other and attacking them as a personality, is an example that we can give to our society. What is going on these days in political statements, what is going on in the media, is a call for radicalisation in some areas. And I believe that we will only achieve this if we are able to resist it and return to normality in our language. This is a question that we must ask ourselves within Europe, but it is also a question between peoples – and I say this as chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. This generalization "the other people is lazy", "they are Muslims, and therefore it is generally a bad thing!" – this kind of generalization with reproaches transports radicalization into our own society and radicalization between religions, between states and peoples. And it is also an important point that we set a better example than has been expressed in some of the debates. And that is why preventing radicalisation is also a demand for politics.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, radicalism and violence are nothing new, but what is new is its frequency and brutality, and also that it is persuased by people who grew up in the countries of the European Union and were brought up in the European Union, where we build on the values of humanity.  The reason, it has already been mentioned here, is the frustration of young people who have no perspective and are subject to propaganda, fanatical ideologies. And the solution, the Commissioner rightly proposed to strengthen society, certainly, we must have the tools to do so, whether it was mentioned here: internal security fund, work in prisons and so on. Instruments at EU and member state level.  But I believe that the key is in the solution, in strengthening personality and social education. The key is to boost the self-confidence of young people, who must have perspective and positive values. I am also glad that the Commissioner for These Values is sympathetic and sympathetic to their support.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the attacks in Paris and Brussels dramatically raise the problem of the recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations and the need to prevent radicalisation. These are men and women, often young people, who have in common a feeling of break with society and who pose a threat to security, in Europe and in neighbouring countries. However, in order to defend ourselves against this phenomenon, in addition to repression, we must put in place effective prevention policies, strengthening intercultural dialogue with all religious communities, strengthening the exchange of information between the countries of the Union and, of course, dismantling the terrorist networks, aiming to target money laundering which, as we know, ends up funding these networks. In short, a strategy to combat extremism and radicalisation can only work if it is developed in parallel with a strategy of integration and social inclusion.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the causes of radicalisation have a political and social sign. In the political field, the radicalization of Muslim populations is reinforced by the West's interventions in the Arab world. It is supported by Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which fund the jihadists.  In the social field, poverty and social exclusion are a fertilizer for jihadists and, while the Commission is proposing measures to tackle Islamic radicalisation, at the same time it is proposing the abolition of visas for Kosovo; a region that has been literally eroded by Turkey and Saudi Arabia; an area where violent Islamic radicalisation has led, according to local police itself; a region where violent Islamic radicalisation has led, according to local police itself. , identifying 314 Kosovar jihadists, including two suicide bombers and 44 women. Commissioner, Mr Navracsics, in the Commission you are pursuing contradictory policies, otherwise it is not explained on the one hand to say that you will hit terrorism and on the other hand to open the door to Kosovar jihadists. Tie this up, because it's serious.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, a series of terrorist attacks are terrifying: Paris, Orlando, Brussels. We can list a lot of cities in the western part of European civilization, we can list in many other cities and countries in the Middle East and elsewhere. However, I would turn the story around. Yes, we need intelligence information, we need to prevent frightening things on the Internet, we need to do a lot of oppressive, but I appeal to hundreds, thousands, hundreds of thousands of great examples of tolerance, great examples of people living together, who have welcomed immigrants, to religious communities living together, language communities living together. We have fantastic examples. Let's show it! Let's show it and take politics in the European Union that way.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: Madam President, the attacks in Paris and Brussels have shown the failure of your Europe; your ideology blinds you. The European Union, Mr Brok, has become a sieve. Measures must be taken and these are simple: national borders and border controls must be restored. Security, Mr Brok, is the first of freedoms.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, before we try to solve the problem of terrorism and extremism in Europe, let us take a closer look at our own house: gagging MEPs with a ban on events, controlling European nationalist parties to break them up, breaking regulations and expelling MEPs from the plenary for not voting, mocking statements and behaviour by certain MEPs. If this is not political extremism and terrorism, then what is it? On the pretext of democracy and the body of your common alliance, you are trying to annihilate the nationalist movements.  Unfortunately, the deep anchorages in pro-money policies, the priorities in systems at the expense of human fundamental rights and the attachment of political groups to power for years have led to the radicalisation of the current policy taking place in this Parliament. But this has to stop. I call on colleagues who place their country above economic interests, who resist the alteration of nations, who respect history and believe in God, to stand up to this political terrorism.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me first thank you, honourable Members of the European Parliament, for that interesting and very constructive debate. It was good to feel your unanimous support for the communication, almost all elements of the communication, and it was good to feel your support for the security policy measures. But I would like to emphasise now my particular happiness about your support for prevention, because education is the most efficient area and platform in prevention. We can educate good practices, good examples for peaceful coexistence just as Mr Jakovčić mentioned. We can show our power and the communities’ power and we can concentrate on the local specialties in education as well, because I think the local level is decisive in prevention. That is why we support role models. That is why we support NGOs and local projects and that is why we support reintegration and integration projects in prisons, for instance. We have very good plans for developing new programmes in education, in vocational education, in prisons and outside the prisons, in local communities, in schools and beyond schools, in sports clubs, youth centres and all other platforms where young people live and where they socialise. So thank you for your support and I rely on you in our further work and I hope that we will be successful in tackling radicalisation in Europe.

name: Bert Koenders
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you very much and thank you honourable Members for a very constructive an interesting debate. Let me just repeat that I am grateful for the Parliament’s and support and for your contribution. I think we share the same objectives in our common fight against radicalisation and violent extremism. We must live up to the expectations of our citizens to improve their safety. Fighting terrorism, preventing radicalisation and increasing the resilience of our societies requires a long-term approach, strong commitment and a sustained effort from the European Union and its Member States. So it is something that we have to do every day. It is work in progress, but we have no time to lose because our enemies are very quickly, if we do not watch out, in front of us. That means we have to be innovative. I have heard many contributions on the different levels of the debate both in the analysis and in the prescriptions. In the analysis, most of you have mentioned both social as well as religious and criminal sources for this process of a radicalisation, and I think you are right. It is a multi-faceted problem of which you have different characteristics and we have to make sure that we have tailor-made prevention and repressive measures to deal with this very complex issue. We cannot wait. The paper is always very patient but we need to act, and I feel very much the support in this Parliament for these actions taken by the Council and others. We simply cannot allow those who want to hurt our system or our way of living to win. In the end, democratic societies will always win against terror and extremists. It is, in the end, believing in your values and defending them. What terrorists want is, in the end, to instil fear by violence, and our vulnerability to that fear is the determining factor, and I think that is something that we have to realise every day we are dealing with this issue. With every step we take, every measure we adopt, it is important that we strike the right balance between security on the one hand and protecting our freedoms and the rule of law on the other. That is sometimes a precarious balance, but I think we have kept our values straight, including the rule of law, while being effective in the struggle against radicalisation. We must be strong and continue to repeat that same message over and over again. Our basic freedoms will not be compromised by terrorism nor by individuals with guns. The Council is determined to reach tangible results in the coming weeks and months.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – Recent terrorist attacks in Europe have highlighted the urgent need to address radicalisation that leads to violent extremism and terrorism. Most of the suspected terrorists involved in the attacks were European citizens, born and raised in the Member States, who were radicalized and conjured up against their fellow citizens to commit atrocities. Preventing radicalisation is a key part of the fight against terrorism, as highlighted in the European Agenda on Security. The design and implementation of anti-radicalisation measures falls mainly within the competence of the Member States. The EU has supported its work in this area for more than a decade. In 2005, the EU's counter-terrorism strategy identified prevention as one of the four pillars of its actions. name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – We all feel the same sorrow and outrage in wake of the horrific attacks in Orlando and Paris. Innocent lives have become victims of an act of terrorism, and this horrific violence has become almost commonplace recently all over the world. We are faced with the great task of improving our efforts to prevent radicalisation and counter violent extremism. The fact that many of these attacks are conducted by European radicals show that radicalisation is easier and more of a threat than ever. The return of radicalised Europeans from conflict areas in Africa and the Middle East pose a significant risk to Europe. We need to adopt effective measures and we must be aware of the magnitude of the situation. The Commission has made great progress on this issue in its security policy measures. We must educate our population and highlight the many examples of peaceful coexistence, tolerance, and the large numbers of cultures that live together in harmony. This fight requires a long-term approach with commitment from the European Union and the Member States. In the end, democratic societies will always win against terror and extremism.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. After the Charlie Hebdo or Bataclan attacks in France, the attacks in Brussels or Orlando in the United States, the EU is still content with declarations and beautiful resolutions on radicalisation or terrorism. However, in the face of the danger of radical Islamism and the growing threats to our nations, we must react without further delay. We must reject this environmental laxity that is taking place in the name of 'European humanism' and take strong measures today: suspending Schengen, restoring states to their sovereignty over immigration and security, restoring the number of our police or national armies but above all daring to name the enemy we are fighting against, Islamist extremism.  Today, more than ever, we must be able to expel from our states all the terrorists and criminals who are permanent threats on European soil. Only nations can try to ensure our security in the face of the terrorist threat; the EU, on the other, has already failed miserably.

text: Writing. – An estimated 4,000 trained fighters radicalised in the Middle East are currently in Europe. And according to the news of the last few days, the number of these is steadily increasing. This means that the threat to European citizens of becoming victims of possible terrorist attacks and violence is increasing every day. The root cause of this is radicalisation, especially among second- and third-generation immigrant youth. We must take decisive action against this phenomenon. I welcome the Commission's communication on this subject, as it sets out seven specific areas where joint EU action can reduce radicalisation. I believe that the only effective way to combat this phenomenon is through a comprehensive strategy.  The most important thing to do is to identify and lift radicalised individuals out of their communities so that they do not spread their murderous ideas and should be sent back to their country of origin. Proper exchange of information at EU level is essential for this. On the other hand, it is necessary to prevent radicalisation, for example in the areas of education, to strengthen social resilience, and to take appropriate steps in the field of de-radicalisation and rehabilitation. Our first priority, our responsibility to our children, is to give our citizens a sense of security. To do this, we must do everything we can to successfully combat radicalisation.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – It is of utmost importance to treat radicalisation and violent extremism as social phenomena and not as problems of a single religion or ideology; therefore, I believe that we should treat the real root causes behind radicalisation, namely marginalisation, discrimination and inequality. The EU and the Member States should focus on local capacity-building, awareness raising, integration and education instead of expanding their surveillance measures or deciding to build walls. Moreover, I cannot emphasise enough not to link the recent influx of asylum seekers with the extremist attacks that took place: asylum seekers more often than not have been forced to flee from the same kind of people that carried out these horrendous crimes, and the purpose of these attacks is to divide our societies. Last but not least, I would also like to highlight the gender perspective of the issue. Recent research not only underlines the trend of extremist groups creating targeted propaganda to attract women, but also emphasises the underestimated role women can play in tackling extremism in their families and local communities, which was also enshrined in the Resolution on the prevention of radicalisation and recruitment of European citizens by terrorist organisations adopted last November by the European Parliament.
