name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. –Madam President, Honourable Members, on behalf of the European Commission and of course Commissioner Karmenu Vella who is responsible for the file. In the college?  I would like to thank the rapporteur, shadow rapporteur and the Committee on Fisheries for all the hard work they have done to enable agreement to be reached for the multiannual plan for the management of the stock of cod, herring and sprout and fisheries in the Baltic Sea. The Baltic plan is the first of its kind; a landmark. It is the first of a new generation of multi-annual plans. These are important tools for the further implementation of our reformed common fisheries policy and for implementing its most ambitious element, the obligation to end wasteful discarding of fish and land all catches.  In addition, these multiannual plans provide an important framework for the development of a more decentralized way of fisheries management, which what we called regionalisation.  With regionalisation in mind, I would also like to take the opportunity to needed to state formally our declaration in relation to regional cooperation. When proposing and adopting delegated acts under their regionalisation provisions of this plan, the Commissioner will comply with the framework set out in the basic regulation, in particular Article 18, and the practice established under the basic regulation implementing the regionalisation process will continue as it has since 2014.  The Baltic plan is the culmination of a process that has involved many players working together to reach consensus across many interests of involved parties. This process has included the Baltic fishing industry and the fishery ministers of concerned countries as well as the legislators of course, and their interests. The outcome is a balanced regulation that has incorporated the key concerns raised throughout the process. The agreement of both legislators has provided the blueprint for this new generation of multi-annual plans. This is very important for other marine regions for which the development of these plans will allow for sustainable long-term management. I will look forward to cooperating with you as we present the next set of proposals for further fisheries management plans for your careful consideration.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, this first fisheries management plan under the new common fisheries policy (CFP) was hard fought and was the result of very difficult, long negotiations, in which Parliament had to make many concessions. We did it in the trust that the provisions included would be enough to uphold sustainable fisheries in the Baltic Sea. This new plan must be put into action as soon as possible for setting total allowable catches (TACs) and quotas for the year 2017. It is crucial that the EU institutions act responsibly and show, now, that commitment to the principles is still alive. Parliament has shown its commitment to sustainable fishing in the EU and to the future of the industry, and I must ask the Commission and the Council to do the same. That is why I have two questions: will the proposals from the Commission for next year’s total allowable catch in the Baltic be based on the scientific advice and the rules established in this new management plan; and is there any scenario where this new management plan and the rules within it to settle catches could not be used? It is crucial to use the new rules immediately, as the scientific advice regarding the western cod stock is very alarming. The stock has been under too much stress for a very long time, and so far the Council has failed to follow the scientific advice. The results of this failure have now led to a piece of advice from the scientists more or less closing this fishery. Luckily, the new Baltic management plan has some new rules in place and safeguards to deal with such situations. After 10 months of difficult negotiations with the Council and the Commission, these negotiations gave us a plan that upholds and respects the objectives of the basic regulations. In the end, this plan will ensure that fishing activities in the Baltic are conducted in a sustainable, reasonable and economically viable way, which will not put unnecessary strain on the environment – and now we will closely monitor the implementation of the plan.

name: Ulrike Rodust
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her These were intense, long negotiations. The text to be voted on tomorrow on the first multiannual plan under the reformed common fisheries policy is the result of eight trialogues. It took some energy to smooth the waters between the Council and us as a Parliament. Waves that, in my opinion, should not have been so high, would have been adhered to the reform in the same way. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Wasa, for his work and approach. This has led to a sufficient re-enforced of Parliament's position. Parliament, the Commission and the Council did not agree in almost ten months of negotiations, particularly on the determination of fishing mortality. Parliament has entered the negotiations with a clear message: the requirements of the basic regulation must be implemented. The Council rejected this and insisted on flexibility. The result is a compromise. As far as the values for fishing mortality are concerned, we have met the Council. Flexibility now exists under certain conditions. In return, Parliament has insisted on stricter security mechanisms. After a positive vote tomorrow, we believe that this multiannual plan must take effect in determining fishing opportunities in October. This means that the Council will have to carry out formal implementation in the next few days so that this law will appear in the Official Journal by August at the latest. The Baltic Sea Management Plan will immediately have its first baptism of fire. The western cod in the Baltic Sea is doing very badly, and so are the fishermen. Only the new Baltic Sea management plan will be able to help, and it must therefore form the basis for the quota decision in October. In the light of the current situation in the Baltic Sea, I am pleased that we have included in this plan support for a temporary cessation of fishing activities by the EMFF. I see this Baltic Sea plan as a blueprint for sustainable fisheries management. Sustainable in the sense of ecological, economic and social. It is good that, in the current text, we are now setting safe limits, which the fisheries ministers must adhere to. This ensures environmental sustainability. In the long term, an ecological approach is also a guarantee of economic and social sustainability. For me, this plan represents a decisive step towards the implementation of fisheries reform. I am very grateful for that.

name: Czesław Hoc
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The multi-annual plan for the management of cod, herring and sprat stocks is a key document for the future of more than 94% of the fish stocks caught in the region. This is the first multiannual plan in the European Union based on the new common fisheries policy. The main good news is the so-called multi-species management, which takes into account the interactions between different types of fish. That's very good. We all know that there is now an urgent need for the biological restoration of the wealth of the Baltic Sea and that the current system must be effective. Management must be sustainable, based on reliable scientific knowledge. Here are a few of my observations: the need for a regional approach should be taken into account in the formulation of the implementing rules for the plan, that the area closed to fisheries should be maintained in order to protect spawning and fish habitats on the basis of updated scientific knowledge, and that funding sources should be identified in the event of temporary cessation of fishing, if such conservation arrangements apply; fourthly, the so-called feed fishing, i.e. industrial fishing, must be explicitly reduced and fifthly, at least in Poland, if wind farms are to be built in the Baltic Sea, this cannot be done in the places of the best fisheries and spawning grounds and in fish breeding sites. Thank you. I would like to congratulate the very good report in general.

name: Nils Torvalds
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This was supposed to be a simple game. name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. I do not think that anyone can really be pleased with this multi-annual plan for the Baltic Sea because it does not protect fishermen and it does not protect the fish. This plan increases the maximum sustainable yield, the point at which waters are fished maximum. And maximum sustainable yield is therefore nothing but policy-cast greed. Plunder the available stock of fish as much as possible. And we're not talking about irons here, we're talking about living beings that can feel pain and fear. And even the maximum fishing out of the sea is not enough. This plan goes a step further: increasing the maximum sustainable yield, and for that I have only one word: overfishing. And in doing so, this Baltic Sea plan weakens the whole common fisheries policy. And this also opens the door to continue to fish structurally empty other waters, such as the North Sea. A large part of you have joined me in opposing this overfishing plan. And I am therefore surprised that you are defending this plan today. At least I can't. The rapporteur has invited us for a glass of champagne tomorrow and, ladies and gentlemen, I ask you: can you raise the glass tomorrow with your head held high? If this is the maximum that Europe wants to do, then overfishing will not stop until the seas are really empty, and unfortunately most of us will have to go through that. I also believe that European agricultural and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Linnéa Engström
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking Mr Wałęsa and his team for the work you have put into concluding the negotiations. The Baltic Sea Plan is the first management plan in which Parliament and the Council of Ministers jointly set a limit on how much we can fish.   The negotiations have been tough and I am disappointed that we did not make it all the way forward in defending Parliament's ambitious position, which would have put an end to overfishing in europe.  An ocean is not an aquarium where all factors can be controlled. Moreover, in our sensitive inland sea, the Baltic Sea, the situation is extremely difficult. This uncertainty requires safety margins when determining a maximum sustainable harvest of fish. In order to achieve the goal of the Baltic Sea being a healthy sea with viable fish stocks, we cannot constantly fish at the maximum limit of what is sustainable - FMSY. We need to be at a lower level so that fish stocks can recover.  Instead of deciding how much during FMSY we should fish, the negotiations came to be about the situations in which you can fish over FMSY and how much over FMSY.  That is why, unfortunately, I cannot recommend that my group vote in favour of this agreement. It does not remain within the objective set out in the basic regulation of the EU's fisheries policy. In any case, we managed to include a number of safeguards in the plan. Now comes a first test: three weeks ago came an alarming report on the state of cod in the western Baltic, which is threatened with collapse due to poor rejuvenation.    The ball is now in Commissioner Vella's. The Commission will now produce a proposal for new fishing quotas based on the Baltic Sea Plan. In order to protect cod in the western stock, I expect the Commission to propose quotas that are in accordance with the safeguard measures described in the plan. We have everything to gain by putting an end to the depletion of European waters, and from a citizens' perspective it is important that the European institutions respect and follow the decisions we take and do not undermine them by enforcing conflicting decisions. To say that we are going to protect our seas from overfishing and at the same time allow it, is hypocrisy. It, if anything, undermines confidence in politics and European cooperation.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in the face of some catastrophic interventions we have heard, I would like to stress that in recent years we have taken fundamental steps in the European Union to ensure a more sustainable and effective management of our seas and our fishing activity. The agreement we are discussing today is not only important to ensure a good multiannual fisheries management plan for cod, herring and spreck in northern European waters: this is an agreement that will serve as an example and as a basis for developing other regional management plans, which we will approve in the future, for fish stocks in different areas of the continent. And in this plan, we have talked about many things—the range of fishing mortality, biomass; also after TACs and fishing quotas — but we have talked above all about skills. And there I want to highlight the competence that each of the institutions has and that we have to be strictly respectful of it. The objective, therefore, is to establish multiannual plans that take into account all aspects surrounding the management of this activity, ensuring, on the one hand, a balanced and sustainable exploitation of fish stocks, but at the same time protecting the activity of our fishermen, also very important.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs who have represented Parliament in this process. Mr Walesa, Mrs Rodust and certainly the other shadow rapporteurs have for many months called for Parliament's position to be as mirrored as much as possible in the final version of this regulation. As the author of some more 'controversial' amendments, I admit that the solution found could contribute to 'keeping the stocks of species exploited at biomass levels that can generate maximum sustainable yield'. The approach used will now inspire the plans in the other geographical areas. But more than closing the process with this wording, I think we should always check whether it fits the objectives of the new Common Fisheries Policy. Despite this positive step, I must stress that, in addition to the real de-escalation that is taking place in the Mediterranean, many of the other European fisheries are not healthy. The robustness of the exploited populations must also be ensured and the resilience of their habitats and food chains must also be promoted. For this, it is urgent to implement genuine marine protected areas. The introduction of quotas for exploited marine resources is a necessary but inconsequential instrument in the absence of a preventive policy mitigating negative effects on ecosystems.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: Finally, we now have agreement on a fisheries plan for the Baltic Sea. The draft plan was presented in October 2014, negotiations began in May 2015, and now after a year and a half there is finally a legislative agreement. It has been a long road and the multi-annual plan has actually become a multi-annual plan for this Parliament as well. I expect that the treatment of other multi-annual plans, in particular that of the North Sea, can now go a lot faster.  The frameworks are clear: we have opted for bandwidths within which Member States can set catch quotas. These bandwidths are particularly needed for the North Sea, because we have a lot of mixed fisheries there. And with these bandwidths we can reach the maximum sustainable yield and all fish stocks can also enjoy it. This is the objective of the common fisheries policy. Finally, I would like to thank Mr Wałęsa and his team. They were tough negotiations. But we got along really well.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Wassa and the negotiating team on their efforts to bring forward this multiannual plan for cod, herring and spurin from the Baltic Sea, the first after the reform of the CFP. I hope that, at once, transparency and objectivity will be the key in setting fishing quotas. The Council's resistance to accepting that Parliament has codecision in this area has already blocked three multiannual plans, that of anchovy, of which I was rapporteur, that of mackerel and hake. This attitude of the Member States, which is in breach of the Treaty of Lisbon, has made it possible to maintain the opacity in determining fishing quotas and in the allocation thereof. Methods incompatible with the objectivity we defend and the current fisheries reform. The victims have been the professionals of the sea and on a few occasions the state of the pesquerías. That is why we are in favour of widespread this system of long-term management plans. It is better for the sea and its balance and for those who live off what they fish in it.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is a step forward that we analyse the situation of fisheries in the Baltic Sea together and not by species, because that is true that it helps to find solutions to improve biodiversity. But we would like to stress that it is essential that all these regulations really respond to the specificities of the territories and their people because, unfortunately, the needs of fishermen are not always met by Union policies. Our fishermen and, above all, low-impact fishing gear must be at the heart of these policies. That is why it is essential to respect their way of life and their culture. Fishing policies cannot be made without sea people to secure their present and future. We believe that there is a need to take another step towards managing a more sustainable model within the States themselves. We must be vigilant with the allocation of the fishing quotas allocated to prevent large vessels, which destroy maritime resources, from fishing at their own risk and, above all, to ensure that those who truly respect the sea can live worthily from fishing, which are those and fishermen.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank all those involved and negotiators for their perseverance and for the fact that a workable solution has been created with the multi-species multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea. It also provides planning certainty for fisheries directly, and in difficult situations – as we have just heard – also opportunities for financial compensation. FMSY – the maximum possible continuous yield: A continuous yield lasts for at least five, six or even ten years of a biological period. And it must be possible to provide reasonable planning certainty for fisheries, even with very specific criteria such as the spawning biomass. On the other hand, I am glad that some things have also been changed, which have actually involved a great deal of bureaucracy: the one-network rule, for example, the elimination of sea days, the documentation of fishing effort and the possibility of actually paying fishermen financial compensation when decommissioning periods are actually made.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this plan, since the last one was adopted in 2008, and I congratulate all those who have worked for its design, including the rapporteur and the deputy rapporteurs. I believe, however, that the European Commission should have been more ambitious in its proposal, because the continued decline of these species is at stake: cod, herring and sprat in the Baltic Sea.  The Common Fisheries Policy must contribute to the preservation of all exploited species, but also to the protection of the maritime environment, as this is the only way to achieve the first major objective of this policy, which is the maximum sustainable yield. For a country like Portugal, where large sectors of the population live off the sea, including the fishing community, all measures that contribute to the protection of the quality of life in the oceans are always welcome!

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which With the multiannual plan for the Baltic Sea, fishermen in my constituency of Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and Schleswig-Holstein are finally getting planning security. A more balanced and sustainable management of fish stocks in line with the common fisheries policy will be possible. As a leftist, we strongly support the objective of ensuring the long-term, economic and ecological compatibility of fishing and aquaculture. The International Council for the Exploration of the Sea proposes to reduce cod fishing quotas in the western Baltic Sea by at least 85 percent. This brings to an end the long-standing mispractice of setting fishing quotas contrary to the scientific recommendations, and I believe that the implementation of the multiannual plan should not be the case in the future. We are finally implementing the much and long-discussed objective, according to which only as much fishing as can be regenerated. The social aspect should also be taken into account. As it stands, the multiannual plan explicitly provides for ways of providing support and they are easy to apply in terms of coastal employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement on the multiannual baltic plan lays the foundations for the sustainable management of the most important fish stocks in the Baltic Sea. It is the first plan of its kind since the reform of the common fisheries policy and I think that the plan is coherent and fully in line with the principles of reform. I stress the importance of ensuring that the management of fish stocks in the Baltic Sea is based on up-to-date scientific data; It is essential that the new plan should make use of the contribution of those who know the region best, as they will be able to adapt the measures at regional level to the specific nature of fishing activity. This agreement paves the way for the drawing up of similar multiannual plans with the same model for fishing in other geographical areas. The multiannual management plans have proved to be very useful for the sustainable management of fisheries resources, because they establish clear rules for the exploitation of fish stocks, based on the precautionary approach and the principle of maximum sustainable yield, thus ensuring conditions of stability and predictability.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, on 15 March 2016 the Dutch Presidency reached an interim agreement seeking to establish a multiannual plan for cod, herring and sprat fishing, which are important fisheries in the Baltic Sea. However, according to opinions of the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, the current rates of exploitation of certain stocks are not consistent with achieving maximum sustainable development. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to take immediate measures to ensure that stocks of these three species in the Baltic are caught in accordance with the principle of maximum sustainable yield. At the same time, however, Mrs Bienkowska, Commissioner, the European Union should also look to the South and take financial support measures for Greek fishermen, who have been impoverished by the troika and memoranda. I convey to you, Mrs Bienkowska, the cry of protest from the Greek fishermen, who can no longer stand the troika's tax raid, the dismantling of the primary sector and merkelic austerity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would certainly like to congratulate my colleagues who managed to come to a joint agreement after eight trilogues and align the long-term plans for the fishing of cod, herring and sprats in the Baltic Sea. And that's a good example, it's a good time. The Baltic is a closed sea and we need to have perennial plans. But I want to highlight the urgent need to make a similar multiannual plan for the fish biomass in the Adriatic Sea as soon as possible. Some have said that some fish in the Baltic Sea should have been banned, that the scientific community was saying so. It may already be too late for some fish species in the Adriatic Sea. Please, let's start as a commission, as representatives, let's start guarding the Adriatic Sea.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first, of course, I want to thank the honourable Members for all their comments and contributions and I will pass all of the information and questions to Commissioner Vella and they will be answered in detail. But let me just shortly, very shortly, touch upon two points. First I would like to reiterate that the Baltic multiannual plan is the first of the new generation of such plans. And as we will present the next set of proposals for fisheries soon, and as you all know it is a legal obligation of the Commission to draft the proposals on the basis of the existing law, it has to be said that the proposal for fishing opportunities in the Baltic Sea is usually adopted by the Commission at the end of August / beginning of September, in order to prepare in a timely manner the discussion and agreement at the fisheries Council in October. If the new multiannual management plan is in force by then – and it is currently under the co-responsibility of the co-legislators – then our proposal will be based on this plan. So I do hope this will be the case, and strongly encourage Parliament and Council to organise formal signature to make this possible. And the second point, on the safeguards in the plan, I want to assure you know that the Commission will make appropriate use of the provisions in force such as targets and safeguards. So from my side, this is everything.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Cod, herring and sprat are the basic species caught in natural conditions and are important elements of the Baltic Sea ecosystem. According to scientific research, there are strong biological interactions between them. I therefore support a more flexible approach to resources. Poland has been in favour of a multi-species resource management plan in the Baltic Sea for several years. Since fishing for cod has an impact on flat fish stocks, I believe it is appropriate to include in the plan the possibility of responding to the deterioration of flat fish stocks. The signals coming from the fishing environment are alarming, especially the situation of cod is particularly disastrous. Feed fishing is extremely harmful here. I therefore particularly criticise the provisions of Article 13, which leave too much tolerance for large-scale pelagic fishing, including industrial fishing. It is necessary to increase their transparency and to take such measures to ensure that their impact on the baltic marine environment is as small as possible. The Commission must take into account the joint recommendations of the Baltic Sea Region countries. The Commission's actions must comply with the provisions of Regulation No 1380/2013 on the CFP and the results of the work of the Interinstitutional Working Group on Long-Term Plans. The legal and substantive analysis should be subject to the commission's powers to adopt delegated acts with a Treaty allocation of competences in the EU and regionalisation rules contained in Regulation 1380/2013.

name: Bernd Lange
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Sorry, but I had the information that we are starting the debate 16 to 7. Madam President, Commissioner, indeed, the question concerns the impact of the United States sanctions against Iran on European companies. Fortunately, we have achieved the so-called nuclear deal with Iran and have negotiated the lifting of sanctions. It is good that Iran's nuclear programme is being put on a sensible track and that economic recovery processes are being initiated in return. However, we have the problem that many US sanctions were imposed even before the discussion on Iran's nuclear route, as it was in 1979. These sanctions have not been lifted and, of course, they also have an extraterritorial effect on European companies in a way. In this respect, we need to look again at how European companies should deal with this. There have been demonstrably problems with some companies. Some others have been granted an exemption after heated discussions with the American authorities, but nevertheless the door is being opened to unequal treatment between American and European companies. That is why it is all the more important to bring clarity to the field of extraterritorial sanctions. In particular, this applies to the banking sector for access to finance. It is not acceptable for European companies to be excluded from the sensible financing of their projects. We all know how much the new opportunities with Iran mean, especially for the stabilisation of this region and also for the development of Iranian society, and in this respect, we in the Committee on Trade have formulated the questions accordingly, such as the Commission, Commissioner, how you assess the specific situation and what measures you have taken to ensure that the commitments are really implemented. How do you intend to make it clear once again, particularly to the United States, that this extraterritorial concern must not have any effect on European companies? Another question is whether you have ever spoken to the Americans and what the American response has been, and how you will ultimately ensure the activities of European companies in this context in the future.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, five months after the lifting of UN, EU and US economic sanctions in return for the implementation of Iran’s nuclear-related commitment, it is really timely to debate the impact of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) on the relations between Iran and EU businesses. This is really important.  Let me first of all stress that the lifting of sanctions was a key element of the nuclear agreement and an effective implementation of the sanctions lifting is a condition for sustainability and success of the plan. It is in our interests, and Iran can reap the economic benefits of it. It is undeniable that we are at a very critical juncture where we need to make sure that all remains on track during the visit of the High Representative and seven other commissioners, including myself, to Tehran in April. We could witness the domestic debate in the country about the merits of the plan, and international engagement is still vital. Successful implementation of the deal is also a key here in the EU. The EU continues to be closely engaged, including through the High Representative’s coordinating role of the Joint Commission overseeing the implementation of the deal.  Let me assure you that we have faithfully met our commitments, as agreed under the plan of action, by lifting the sanctions and publishing guidance on implementation day, providing clarity on the subject. But we have also engaged with the private sector to provide clarity and reassure operators wanting to go back to Iran.  Let us be clear, there are still challenges we need to overcome. The financial and banking issues we are experiencing should not be underestimated, but they should be put into perspective. Iran has been isolated from the world economy for more than 10 years. Iranian banks have been cut off from the international financial system for the same period of time. We have always known that the full reintegration of Iran into the world economy would not happen overnight, but I am confident it will succeed. There are other elements that banks take into consideration in their assessment: the full and correct comprehension of the scope of US sanctions, as well as Iran’s banking regulations and anti-money-laundering and counter-terrorist financing controls.  We are engaging very actively on both fronts: the EU with the Member States has been holding regular consultation with Washington since 16 January this year; the US has updated twice its guidance, publishing additional frequently asked questions. This has demonstrated ongoing commitment to provide clarity to business operators and to keep the guidance a living document. We also invited the Director of the Office of Foreign Assets Control to inform our finance ministers and encourage him to further reach out to the private sector. In addition, we are planning to hold a symposium in Brussels on the lifting of sanctions for business operators, with contributions from both EU and US experts.  In the same spirit, the High Representative chaired a ministerial meeting on 19 May 2016 with the Foreign Ministers of Germany, France, the UK and US. The release of the joint statement on post-JCPOA business with Iran was a clear signal to reassure financial operators and to encourage them to engage with Iran.  Let me also take this opportunity to share with you how appreciative we are of the US efforts to provide clarity about the scope of the remaining US primary sanctions and to reach out to the banking sector in Europe. In addition, it is important that Iran takes the necessary steps on the regulatory framework and business environment. Companies are concerned about these issues, in particular on anti-money laundering and countering financing of terrorism and of course, more needs to be done. Cooperation and consultations in the Financial Action Task Force framework should be treated as a priority. Our visit to Iran has served as an opportunity to establish the basis for cooperating and providing assistance in these domains. Despite all the challenges, the results of the plan are already positive, with a 22% growth in trade between the EU and Iran in the first quarter of 2016, compared to the same period last year. Thirty-three Iranian banks have been reconnected to SWIFT so far. More recently, it was reported that 200 small and medium-sized international banks, including European ones, have started correspondent relationship with Iranian banks. Major banks are becoming more comfortable as they start to comprehend the new rules in practice. To enhance the economic dialogue and cooperation, in October we are planning a European economic mission to Iran with representatives of European SMEs and businesses. As an element of the trade promotion role of the Member States, another promising avenue is the use of national credit insurance companies, which could provide cover and additional reassurance to investors. All of these issues together form the complex reality. It will still require, of course, some time as the international business community needs to adjust to the new reality of the post-implementation deal. While we cannot force banks or other businesses to take certain decisions in commercial matters, we will continue to be committed to ensuring that Iran can reap the benefit of the plan of action. With that in mind, we can better continue our consultations with the US in order to get as much clarity as possible, continue reaching out to the European business community and provide assistance to Iran’s banking and financial system. Dialogue and persistence are the way forward.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to tell the Commissioner how glad I was, one year ago, to see a breakthrough on the Iranian nuclear deal after difficult and long negotiations. The EU played a crucial role in this success, and as I said at that time, the deal has to be beneficial to all parties involved. The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, adopted in October, can be a significant step forward for the security, stability and development of the entire region. But it remains extremely important that it is implemented thoroughly and in good faith by all partners and all sides as soon as possible. We should not forget that the significance of this deal extends beyond its technical details: it has been celebrated by the Iranian people, following its conclusion, with the hope that it will improve their living standards. It is essential that we deliver on that. Only successful implementation will allow us to show the benefits of diplomacy and negotiation over the politics of obstructionism and confrontation.  In spite of the partial lifting of sanctions, EU companies still face substantial difficulties in accessing the Iranian market, and this is mostly due to the fact that many US financial sanctions are still in place and have an extra-territorial impact. Much as we are aware of some of the remaining US and regional partners’ concerns on issues such as security, in particular, and the use of ballistic weaponry, it is important to use all our channels of cooperation with the USA in order to remove, or at least find a temporary solution to, the difficulties faced by European companies and to ensure in the long term , together with our Iranian partners, the security and legal certainty of European investments in Iran. Finally, the Commission should explore, as soon as possible, the adoption of new mechanisms and measures to lessen the dependence of European companies on US credit and insurance institutions.

name: Jan Zahradil
text: on the ecr group. – Madam President, I am afraid that we still have an ambivalent attitude towards Iran. There are many Members in my INTA committee who deal with the human rights situation in different countries and are willing to support various sanctions or economic measures against countries that violate human rights, but I feel that this is not the case with Iran and that, unfortunately, we still underestimate the nature of this theocratic dictatorial regime. There is a shift in society that is not yet reflected in those ruling circles. It is a theocratic dictatorship, it is part of an anti-Western coalition with Russia, with Assad and the Hezbollah movement, for example, in Syria. It is a state that seeks regional hegemony, which would certainly be disadvantageous for Europe if something like this were to happen, and it is a state that has never abandoned its nuclear ambitions. So I would recommend that we be very wary of Iran, both in economic and commercial terms.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner and colleagues, this debate is about creating more clarity for EU-based companies looking to trade with or invest in Iran after the lifting of sanctions as a result of the nuclear deal. But ongoing as well as new US-based sanctions for human rights violations or to deter Iran’s missile programme – regardless of the validity of those goals, and I think they are valid – have led to uncertainty for European companies. As a result of the extraterritorial impact, an estimated half of interested companies are holding back. The need for financing, insuring and transporting products going to Iran can lead to a chain reaction where banks do not trust that their services, even if fully legal in Europe, will not be punished in the US or by the US: not only billion-dollar fines, but also new visa requirements that hinder access, or undermine trust in being able to access , the US after doing business with Iran. Since we requested this debate, Secretary Kerry has met with EU-based banks and the question is this: has this sufficiently clarified their concerns, according to the Commission? And what has the Commission or the External Action Service done to address these concerns with US officials to get more predictability and clarity for European companies? And have you engaged in the underlying problem and addressed it with the Iranian authorities – namely the fact that a significant role for the Revolutionary Guard in the Iranian economy hinders the emergence of a truly private sector, and also risks that the benefits after the deal will go to a few and not to the many. Does the current situation of uncertainty jeopardise the deal at all? Key for our group, and key for the EU to be effective and credible is for us to be able to make our own policies – in tandem with the US when needed, as we successfully did to bring Iran back to the negotiating table – but always independently, based on our own assessments and decisions of which foreign policy tools benefit our interests and , most importantly, our values.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the European Union remains hostage to American interests and is once again contingent on its foreign and economic policies. US sanctions restrict the political and trade space of the European Union and affect its interests. Sanctions that are contrary to international law and which are, above all, contrary to the population. As with sanctions against Iraq in 1990, which, according to the United Nations, caused more than half a million children killed. Since the adoption of the joint comprehensive action plan, the European Union has announced that it would lift economic sanctions, including the embargo on crude oil and the ban on trade and transport. But European companies continue to struggle to access the Iranian market as a result of the extraterritorial impact of US stocks. Many companies, which also engage in business in the United States, may be accused of violating U.S. sanctions with negative consequences. Where is Europe's sovereignty?

name: Klaus Buchner
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We now have a historic opportunity to end Iran's decades of isolation and to come into contact with the country. This is urgently needed if we want to improve the human rights situation there, if we also want to influence and improve the situation of terrorism in the Middle East. Society in Iran needs the lifting of sanctions, because there is unemployment there, where many people live below the standards that we believe are necessary. This can only change if trade and the lifting of sanctions can improve the economic situation in the country. That is why, also in order to stop the trend towards terrorism within the country, that is to say towards the more radical currents, it is absolutely necessary to improve the standard of living in the country. That is why we have no choice but to strengthen economic cooperation and lift the sanctions now, even from the point of view of the United States from the point of view of historical development. Nevertheless, I believe that it is not acceptable for German, European companies to have to comply with US sanctions. This is a fundamental contradiction to the sovereignty of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Do you not think that the Commission should address the extra-territorial impact of US sanctions with the American officials and make sure that EU companies can do business, in line with EU policies, without fear of violating US sanctions and of possible fines?

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE) –
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, of course I believe that these sanctions must be resolved in negotiations, in negotiations between the EU and the US, of course. I fully agree with that.

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my question is: who decides the rules for European companies? Is it us or is it Washington? Since October 2015, the European Commission has progressively lifted sanctions and is again allowing our companies to market with Iran, while the United States has not yet lifted its sanctions and, in addition to banning its companies from doing business in Iran, are heavily fining European companies that do so, under a law that allows the United States extraterritorial application of their sanctions. This is because the US government believes that anyone who uses the dollar in transactions implicitly recognizes its sovereignty. It is obvious that Iran still has a long way to go, especially as regards respect for human rights, but since sanctions no longer block trade, European companies have been quickly filling the gaps left in the Iranian market by years of embargoes, and I find it ridiculous, to say the least, that, having received the authorisation of the various European governments, our businesses are being blocked by the American government. As far as Italy is concerned, for now only one large Italian bank has been hit by American fines, while another large bank is still waiting for the response and an Italian company has been investigated by the USA but without receiving fines. The same cannot be said, however, for other European companies that will have to pay. The procedure for asking Washington for a derogation from these sanctions is long and very complex, not easily accessible, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. I do not therefore wish to deny, I repeat, that Iran's path from the regime to democracy is still a long one, but this road also involves gradual integration into the international trading system and, above all, if Europe has decided to give the green light to our companies' investments in Iran, the last word must certainly not fall to the United States.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the eve of tomorrow's Brexit vote, one would have expected a stronger stance on the part of the European Union, at least on these issues, when it comes to defending European businesses, but we do not even know what sanctions against Iran the United States has lifted. It is a situation of complete uncertainty, even in the words of the Commission, while on the part of Iran there are repeated calls for European companies to enter that market that is spectacular, especially for a country like my own, Italy, which was the first of its partners before the sanctions. In Genoa, the hauliers tell us, there are tens of thousands of containers stationary, ready to leave with goods, which could greatly lift our economy. It is incredible that the European Union should stop, be so weak, so uncertain, in the face of a problem of this kind, which is, I would say at a glance, linked to the widespread interest of our companies and therefore also of our workers. Parliament, unlike the Commission, is united and speaks out about the lifting of these sanctions and the risks of fines on our companies by the American supervisory bodies.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Madam President, I am delighted with this debate on the impact of US sanctions on the activities of European companies in Iran because, first, two months ago I asked the Commission a written question of this, which I am still waiting for; secondly, because the news of the last few days shows that the US administration favours its national companies against their European competitors. The U.S. administration has lifted sanctions on U.S. companies and maintains the threat to European companies. That's the reality.  Secretary of State John Kerry has been proclaiming everywhere that Europeans can do business in Iran, but Airbus, for example, has been waiting five months for the green light from OFAC, the Office of Foreign Assets Control, to be able to make the sale of aircraft concluded in January a reality. Without this green light, no bank, scalded by the huge fine imposed on the bank BNP Paribas - it is not millions of dollars, it is billions of dollars, nine billion for the bnp Paribas bank alone in complete indifference of the Commission and all the European authorities. It's a shame, it's a real scandal that reveals the state of vassality you are in with respect to the Washington authorities.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Vienna agreements and the consequent and progressive lifting of sanctions which, let us remember, have contributed to a 70 % reduction in trade between Iran and the European Union since 2005 open up new opportunities for European companies in a country of 80 million inhabitants, which is the greatest attraction for international investment since the fall of the Berlin Wall. I am thinking of mechanics, transport, the environment, the fight against pollution and the provision of technologies for the exploitation of renewables. The path has been mapped out, now all the actors involved in this process – the European Union, the United States, Iran – must follow it together, in order to build solid relations based on mutual trust and not just on compliance with the agreements signed. Concrete signs of openness and change are expected from Iran, starting with the fundamental issue of human rights, while on the economic front it is essential to work above all on the banking system, which is still not transparent today, also in the light of the recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force, in order to avoid money laundering and to combat the financing of terrorist activities. The European Union also calls on the United States of America to encourage investment in Iran. To date, it is impossible for any company with at least 10 % US shareholding to do business with Iran, due to the sanctions still in place restricting freedom of action. We therefore strongly urge the Commission to take this message to the American authorities. It is essential that the many memoranda of understanding signed to date by European public and private companies should be transformed into contracts and concrete actions.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – As you know, Madam Presidencies, I am responsible for Iran in the delegation as well as in the Energy Committee. Europe has a duty to benefit economically and politically from the nuclear treaty. European business geographically and economically is closest to resuming ties with Iranian business, especially in the field of energy.  We need to regulate these relations in the America-Europe-Iran triangle. This is the work of the European Commission. There are remaining uncertainties that extend the termination of sanctions, both with this period and with additional financial sanctions by the United States. At the request of the European Union, Bulgaria terminated its nuclear program for a second plant. The Bulgarian state-owned company was convicted last week of nearly 650 million euros by the Russian state-owned company. A proposal by the Bulgarian prime minister to sell the Russian nuclear reactor to Iran has emerged.  And here I ask the question: Will we have the support of the European Commission, given that the Iranian government is clearly not in a hurry with the democratization of the country and there are still obstacles to fully covering the capacity in relations Iran – United States?

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, today the Commissioner has given us an answer to the question, which I would say was twofold. Commissioner, you have given us an answer on the efforts that you personally, the Commission, your colleagues and also Member States’ representatives are making vis-à-vis Iran. I think that it was rich in information. I am sure that you are making an effort. I think that we have a double agenda there. We have got an economic agenda and we still have an agenda that has to do with the quality of ‘democracy’ in Iran, human rights abuse, etc. On that part I must say that I found your response satisfactory. To be absolutely frank with you, I do have difficulties with the second part of the twofold answer, namely with the US part. You also took somewhat less time in answering that question. You said that there is progress on getting clarity on the guidelines and that there is an effort on the US side. I am sure that this is the case, but the fact is that we do have cases which have concrete implications. I am Czech. I do not come from a country where Airbus would have a production line, but I think that is one really flagrant case, Airbus versus Boeing. Boeing, which clearly started negotiations with Iran much later than Airbus, has signed a deal – I think it was last week – while Airbus has now been waiting for five months for US Treasury clearance. I think that is unacceptable. So we do not just need to hear what efforts are taking place, but we really need results. Tell us how we can assist you, but let us be more concrete on those issues in the future.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Iran signed the nuclear deal and that is why the EU and the US have lifted sanctions against Iran, as we have heard, but only in part. The US is again doing trade with Iran, and General Electric, for example, could do business with the Persians, but if Siemens does the same, sanctions by the US threaten. So trade with Iran or with the US. That is the current position of the United States, and you have, as has just been said, in principle said nothing about how you intend to work on it. I wonder why the Americans are doing this, and what are you doing? The American oil company ExxonMobile can buy in Iran, and any other company that does so is using it to build the American market. The US is in favour of free trade, we are in favour of free trade, so I propose that the US stop penalising free trade, otherwise it will only get the impression that it is only saying free trade, but ultimately defending its own supremacy at the expense of everyone else, as with TTIP.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Madam President, Iran has given all the guarantees required by the treaty of 14 July 2015 with regard to its nuclear programme. In return, EU sanctions were lifted in January 2016. Nothing should theoretically stand in the way of the resumption of normal trade relations between Iran and the rest of the world. European banks, however, are reluctant to finance trade projects with Iran because they fear being fined by the United States. Thus, the contract for the sale of 118 Airbus aircraft, signed recently by the French and Iranian presidents, is paralyzed. The United States must make a written commitment not to impose such fines and thus to break with its pre-2015 practices. The European Union must, for once, take its courage with both hands and demand this written commitment from the United States. Failing that, France will have to take its destiny into its own hands and ask its central bank to finance French projects in Iran.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support An agreement was reached between the international community and Iran in July 2015. Iran has limited and verifiable its nuclear program, and in return, in principle, sanctions against it have been lifted. Only in principle, because the United States has done everything possible, especially in the banking sector, to stay above sanctions. It is in the EU's fundamental interest, and not only economically, on the migrant issue, a good, balanced relationship with Iran and stability throughout the region. To do so, the United States really needs to lift sanctions and put pressure on its flagship partner, Saudi Arabia. Because Saudi Arabia is currently intervening in Yemen by committing war crimes, and tensions with Iran are rising in this regard, and easing and ending this tension is also in the EU's fundamental interest.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this case describes well the delicate position of the European Union in global diplomatic, military and trade relations. We are a key partner to the United States and for many years and even decades we have enjoyed certain privileges, but this partnership can also have negative sides as in the case of our companies operating in Iran at a time when the US has not yet fully lifted sanctions on the country. Some colleagues are going to use this to question their partnership with America, and I think that's wrong. This is a situation in which to build a new position of the European Union as a strong independent actor on a global scale that enjoys the trust of its American partners, and in the eyes of eastern powers adds to them the necessary benevolence and credibility. The intertwining of European and American values and interests is a constant that makes no sense to deny, but that does not mean that Europe cannot play a more constructive role and in certain cases be the one hitting the pace and determining the direction of Western politics.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for This is yet another wonderful example of the fact that the European Union, and indeed the US administration, likes to talk about free trade, but very little is being done about it. The Commission is watching. While European banks must continue to fear financing deals in Iran because they face sanctions in the US, making it impossible for virtually all small and medium-sized enterprises to do business in Iran, we are now seeing that the whole thing works in the big game. Airbus has been waiting for approval for a deal with Iran since January, and today – no, yesterday – Boeing announces a 25-billion-dollar deal with Iran. It is perfectly obvious what is happening here: this is an economic war by the Americans, not against Iran, but against the European Union, and the Commission is standing idly by.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Madam President, the United States of America consciously chooses to block European business in Iran. The reason is obvious and of course has nothing to do with alleged concerns about Iran's nuclear program. The main concern for them is the promotion of American trade interests in this country. A typical example is the case of Airbus, which, as you know, has struck an agreement with the state-owned IranAir to supply 118 aircraft since the end of January. However, due to the use of some subsystems of American origin, approval is required from the US government for the sale of the aircraft, which, five months later, has not yet been given. Of course, this obstruction has benefited American Boeing, which a few days ago concluded negotiations with Iran on the supply of 100 of its own aircraft.  With these displays of allied solidarity and trade, as the Americans mean them, they make it clear each time who has the upper hand in this alliance.  Let the devotees of the TTIP agreements take this into account, as to what the future of the Union will be, because issues such as Iran's are simply an image of transatlantic trade, a future that some here support.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the extra-territorial effects of the sanctions adopted by the United States against Iran continue to create difficulties for European companies in accessing the Iranian market. As a result of sanctions between 2012 and 2013, total EU imports from Iran decreased by 86 % and total exports decreased by 26 %. European countries have followed up their commitments under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, and it is now up to the United States to lift the restrictive measures. After Iran's commitment to nuclear power only for civilian purposes, it is necessary to consolidate the signs of openness coming from Tehran and to direct them towards a constructive dialogue at international level, paving the way for Iran's full reintegration into the international community. It is quite clear, in fact, that re-establishing trade relations with an important part of the Arab world has a fundamental value for the stabilisation of the area and for an improvement in human rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, most European companies do not venture to open up business with Iran, despite last year's agreement on Tehran's nuclear programme. That's because they fear they will be fined by the United States for violating U.S. sanctions on Iran, which remain in place. The European Union must provide a solution to this major issue, which limits the development of Iran's bilateral trade relations with Member States of the Union.  This country of 80,000,000 inhabitants is in a construction orgasm. The immediate plans are to build seven airports in the coming years, while eight cities are rapidly expanding. This event paves the way and can be a breath of survival, both for construction companies from Greece, which have been affected by the troika's policies, as well as for Greek supply companies in the field of cutting-edge technologies, medicines, parapharmaceuticals and medical products. We await the Commission's action, Mrs Bienkowska.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, when I once visited Iran, sanctions were still in place, but I was convinced how much the Iranian economy cares about cooperation with the European economy, how much the Iranian economy is able to provide many opportunities to invest in the European economy. And that is why I am convinced that this situation we are in now is nothing more than one game with the European Union by our American friends. That shows the event around Boeing and the sale of Boeing right now, although Airbus was also able to do a good job, but he's not going to do it.  That is why I say that we have two situations here: we have an economically interesting situation for the European Union and a politically interesting situation for the European Union. Let's use both situations because they're in our favor.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, one of the biggest errors of the European Union's foreign policy is its absolute and inexplicable association with that of the United States. This obsession has created many problems in countries of the European Union and has often also turned against the interests of the Union. A typical example of this situation is the problems faced by companies from European countries operating in Iran as a result of sanctions that the United States has not yet lifted for that country.  This creates a situation of unfair competition for European companies and at the same time, if they also have dealings with the USA, they risk being penalised, i.e. being fined. This is an unacceptable situation and it is essential that the European Union is quickly relieved of this informal guardianship, so that European investors can be active in the Iranian market and in the energy sector.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think this was a very useful exchange and I want to thank all Honourable Members for the clarity of their interventions. I assure you that we are analysing all of the subjects, especially particular cases. Later on I will refer to Airbus-Boeing very briefly. But as far as this debate is concerned, I conclude that we share a common interest in ensuring that the plan of action works for all participants, especially for European companies and businesses, and leads to Iran’s reintegration into the world economy. Let me again reiterate that the EU is fully committed to providing all necessary assistance and the necessary references to the private sector on the lifting of sanctions, both business opportunities in Iran and, of course, defending the interests of European companies. On Airbus, I can only say that Airbus signed a deal months ago. At the end of January, during the visit of the Iranian President to France, it signed a deal with Iran on 28 January for the export of aircraft. As for Boeing, they only signed a memorandum of understanding, so not a contract, also for the export of aircraft, very recently. So the situation of both companies is almost the same, but with Airbus it is a deal and with Boeing it is just a memorandum of understanding. Of course, we all know that the implementation is an ongoing task and we need to be diligent with our joint efforts, but I will of course pass all of your concerns and your comments to High Representative Mogherini. Again I want to thank you for bringing the topic to the agenda. Hopefully we will also discuss it in the future because it is really important for our European economy.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. I support Iran's reintegration into the international community and their application for WTO membership. It is fundamental that the Iranians see that the agreement is working. Therefore, we must work to remove all barriers on both sides in order to lift the sanctions established by the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. In October 2015, the European Union, the United Nations and the United States signed an historic agreement with Iran and adopted a Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (GCC). The plan included a commitment that Iran's nuclear program would have only peaceful purposes, in exchange for the gradual lifting of sanctions against Tehran. A new chapter in international relations which opened up a constructive dialogue between the European Union and Iran, with the positive result of giving security to European companies wishing to invest in that country and allowing favourable conditions for the stabilisation and social and economic development of Iranian society. This process of rebuilding trade relations and dialogue with Iran is now hampered by the united States' failure to lift financial sanctions; a hitherto unfulamed political commitment that has a serious extraterritorial impact on European companies, which not only face difficult access to the Iranian market but are often forced to suffer fines or even a ban on trading freely. I am therefore convinced that in the coming months the European Union must take active action to ensure that the United States also fully implements the provisions of the PAGC.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In January 2016 the Council lifted all nuclear related economic and financial EU sanctions against Iran. This follows verification by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) on the same date that Iran had implemented the agreed nuclear-related measures as set out in the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). The EU has been joined by the US and the UN which also lifted their sanctions against Iran upon verification. However, the US has suspended not terminated its nuclear-related sanctions on Iran while at the same non-nuclear US economic sanctions remain in place, notably the ban on US citizens and companies trading with Iran. Recently, the US imposed fresh sanctions on Iran over an Iranian ballistic missile test. Continuing US sanctions represent a real trade barrier for many European companies which want to access the Iranian market especially since many of them have business activities in the US. The EU should discuss this issue with our American partners in order to find a working solution that will benefit all sides. Trade with Iran is important for the EU, but a transatlantic partnership with the US is vital for the Union and its Member States since it is the largest bilateral trade and investment relationship in the world.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I was told six minutes, and I will try to respect your time. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the mobility of the citizens of the European Union is no illusion. It is real and that is why the European Union has sixteen million couples who are multinational or international.  These couples own property - that is, car, house - or have bank accounts in various countries. In the event of a problem, it is, so far, a real journey of the combatant to find a jurisdiction that is effective and accepted and, on the other hand, to achieve a fair sharing of responsibilities.  These two regulations will put an end to the legal uncertainties that these couples face with, of course, the costs that divorce proceedings and separations entail or in the event of death and, above all, will put an end to the conflicting decisions that sometimes arise from these legal difficulties. These texts will apply to both married couples and those who have entered into a registered partnership. It was very difficult for these couples to know which jurisdiction would be competent to settle disputes over their property in another Member State, with the rules varying greatly from one EU country to another. For this reason, when these regulations are adopted, spouses or partners will be able to choose, under certain conditions, the jurisdiction that will be called upon to rule. This may be the right of the country of residence or the country whose couples or partners have nationality. This is a very clear layout at the same time as it is very flexible. The right that has been chosen will be the one that will apply to all the goods, even if they are located in different countries. However, I would stress that these legal rules of each country will be well applied and that the principle of subsidiarity will be well respected. These two regulations do not concern the definition of marriage or the definition of partnership, and the rights and obligations arising from a registered marriage or partnership will continue to be governed by national law. Thus, a Member State that does not recognise the registered partnership will be entirely free not to judge a dispute that would arise on its soil and, in particular, in view of the consequences of a separation or death of registered partners. It will therefore be able to entrust the matter to the courts of another Member State, which recognises their partnership.  The negotiations on these two regulations have been very delicate, as you well know. The agreement between the Member States to be unanimous on family law required the use of the enhanced cooperation procedure to unblock this situation which was causing suffering from many people.  I am announcing to you, or rather, I can confirm that eighteen Member States have agreed to introduce and apply these different provisions between them. Parliament gave its approval at the last plenary in June 2016 to the decision to use enhanced cooperation for these two regulations.  The two regulations, that is, matrimonial regimes and registered partnership, were voted by a large majority last week in the Committee on Legal Affairs. So there were no major difficulties. There is an amendment which is a bit cosmetic, which calls for the initial definition of Member States to be supplemented and to become 'the Member States participating in enhanced cooperation'. This is a clarification that will have no legal effect. In any case, this addition is in my opinion somewhat unnecessary and superfluous but, in any case, it does not influence the substantive decision. Therefore, I inform you that my group and I have agreed to vote against this amendment because we believe it is essential not to question the entire agreement that has been difficult to negotiate by these eighteen Member States who are participating in enhanced cooperation. In conclusion, Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to say that tomorrow's vote in favour of these two regulations is absolutely important, because it will ensure that the timetable is kept, so that the texts can be adopted at Council level by the Member States participating in this collegiality of enhanced cooperation as soon as possible. Madam President, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen, remember that this is a number of couples, i.e. about sixteen million couples, which makes 32 million people; if you have two parents for each of those 32 million people, you see a little bit about the number of families and people involved.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam Chair, honourable Members, as European cities ask to make use of their right to free movement, the number of international couples increases. Today, as Mr Cavada mentioned, there are an estimated 60 million international couples in the Union. Currently, these couples face difficulties when managing their property or, in cases of divorce or death, when having to divide it. These new rules in relation to the property regimes of international couples, covering both marriages and registered partnerships, aim to remove such difficulties. These rules will provide international families with legal certainty and will reduce the costs associated with proceedings when things go wrong. Couples will know, with clarity, which courts will deal with matters concerning their property and which national law should apply to such matters. These new rules also complete the programme on mutual recognition of decisions in civil and commercial matters adopted by the Council on 30 November 2000, and fill an important gap in the field of Union family law. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Cavada, for his excellent cooperation in pushing forward this difficult file. I also wish to thank the Dutch Presidency for treating enhanced cooperation in this area as a priority. We would all have wished that these important matters could have been addressed with all Member States taking part, but it is important that we move forward now with those who can. And, of course, the enhanced cooperation system always remains open to other Member States to join, if and when they feel ready to participate. In the meantime, the enhanced cooperation rules contain provisions ensuring that agreements on property regime matters concluded between Member States participating in the enhanced cooperation and those not participating will remain unaffected. It is important that these new rules apply for people in both marriages and registered partnerships, but I wish to reassure Parliament that the draft regulations also contain safeguards aimed at respecting the legal traditions of all Member States. They do not require recognition of marriages or registered partnerships concluded in another Member State. This is a good example of how, by working together constructively, we can make life simpler for citizens throughout the EU.

name: Axel Voss
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would also like to thank the rapporteur and the predecessor, who dealt with this whole dossier very well. It is really hard to believe that we are only dealing with such things today, including legislation, because we have already had freedom of movement for a much longer time. That is why it is absolutely essential that we have this now. I do believe that some people felt very alone. When you are in such a situation and have to see how, in private international law, one somehow comes to a separation of goods, this is highly complicated. That is why it is very nice that we will now also find a regulation on this. Tomorrow's vote on increased cooperation between some Member States on these issues of property rights, both for marriages and for registered partnerships, is therefore also an important step towards the end of multiannual negotiations. And we urgently need these regulations, also in our interests as co-legislators. I am pleased that we are now able to conclude this dossier in plenary. We are only here, I say, in the hearing procedure. I would therefore like to stress and also thank you for the fact that the Council has largely accepted all the suggestions of the European Parliament and that we can therefore be very satisfied with our position in the end. As has already been mentioned, we ourselves adopted this in committee. Of course, we have also ensured – fortunately – that it has no legal implications for the recognition of forms of coexistence that some states do not yet know. This would most likely have led to further blockades. In this respect, it is also good that the text on registered partnerships contains a public policy clause. I believe that we are on a very good path here as a whole. I would like to thank all those involved.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very pleased that today we can finally conclude the discussion on this procedure here. I was the rapporteur during the last parliamentary term, shadow rapporteur in this parliamentary term, and this has been a very long process to ensure that a solution is found for the citizens that will help them to live really sensibly in the internationality in which they live. After custody of failed marriages, on the issues of inheritance law, we now have property law, and I think that this will take another step forward by giving help, especially to the people who have made it their goal, who have simply said: 'We are living this Europe as it is, in all internationality'. That's a good thing. From the outset, it was very important for the European Parliament to ensure that the two legislative proposals before us – firstly for registered partnerships and, on the other, for marriages – both contain, in principle, the same rights, but at the same time – and this has always been very important – respect the different traditions and cultures in the Member States. That is why it is precisely this clause that no state is forced to introduce or recognise, for example, registered partnerships – if they do not exist in their country – that is a correct and important formula. In the context of this law, it has always been important for us, as Social Democrats, to say that we must also ensure that there is no forum shopping. We have all too often seen in these areas that the stronger, richer of the two partners – if there was a problem or a divorce or separation – has prevailed and the weaker one has been left behind. This, too, had to be prevented, and I believe that we have succeeded in doing so with this right. I agree with the previous speakers on this. We have succeeded in creating a right in which both the European Commission and the Council have followed the European Parliament's proposals. That is why it is no longer so important to me that we should only be consulted, because after all, we have a say in what is in this law. I think that with this piece of work, we have once again ensured that we can find really sensible solutions to real problems that people have.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
