text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam Presidencies, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, Honourable Member Cavada, family law is a sensitive subject and must always be dealt with in such a way as to provide for as much care and attention as possible and the greatest possible delicacy to this public sphere, which is usually governed by local customs, by local traditions. Over the past few years we have seen strong cooperation in many legal areas. One of them relates to the cross-border aspects of legal disputes arising from married couples or coexistents from different countries. National provisions on family law often differ. For example, the concept of a marriage-free partnership is not known and is not part of the legal system of some Member States, such as Italy, Poland, Romania and Bulgaria. We often encounter cases of conflicting provisions that can lead to an additional legal door and can lead to even more headaches. There are strong political currents in such legal disputes and I warn that these proposals could lead to significant differences in the legal framework of the Member States. I am an advocate for better cooperation in many respects, but we must also not forget the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, today we give our approval to the establishment of enhanced cooperation in the areas of jurisdiction, applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in matters of property relations between spouses and registered partners. The new rules among the 18 Member States that have agreed to participate in the enhanced cooperation regime should facilitate the daily lives of couples of nationals of different Member States by choosing a legislative framework applicable to their assets, as well as by introducing mutual recognition of decisions given in different Member States. It is truly regrettable that the Commission's original proposal in 2011 did not go ahead because of a lack of unanimity in the Council, so that we are five years late in establishing the necessary procedures. It is also regrettable that the European Parliament is simply giving its opinion on family law issues, such as what we are discussing today, which has a direct impact on thousands of couples across the European Union. Legislative initiatives on such issues should fall within the area of codecision, so that the European Parliament, as the direct representative of European citizens, can have a say as an equal partner in the legislative process and have a decisive influence on developments.

name: Terry Reintke
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam Chair, Commissioner, how can we tolerate a situation in which families – parents with their beloved children, or partners who have promised to be there for each other for the rest of their lives – lose their rights in relation to one another if they move to another European Union country? How can we tolerate a situation where parents cannot sit next to their children’s hospital beds after they have had an accident, just because they have crossed borders? And how can we tolerate families losing their property rights just because some Member States still do not understand that family and couples and love know many different forms? We need to change all of this, and I believe that this proposal is a tiny first step in that direction. Rainbow families and same-sex couples can no longer be treated like second-class citizens in the European Union. We deserve full rights and equal protection. We want to be free to move within the European Union to work and to study wherever we want, and to be protected from discrimination. That is not too much to ask: it is a right granted to all EU citizens. Let us end the discrimination that same sex couples are still facing. Let us end legal uncertainties for rainbow families and for such couples. Let us create a European Union that gives support and protection to all families. The current proposal is one piece of a much bigger puzzle in the effort to make this a reality. Let us take this as a starting point for creating a European Union where all families and all couples can live the life they want, can be free to move and to live wherever they want, and have equal rights in this European Union.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the EFDD Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are talking about two explosive templates that deal with the definition of marriage and family. At the end of last year, the Council of Ministers presented a regulation to regulate property issues for spouses – more precisely, for homosexual spouses. Hungary and Poland have blocked this because these marriages do not exist there and they did not want them. But that is the technocrat principle: gay marriage is to be introduced throughout Europe through the mutual recognition of civil status documents through the back door. Eight Member States had stipulated in their constitutions that marriage consists of a man and a woman. Mutual recognition of civil status certificates should undermine national constitutions by the EU. This is precisely the EU principle that more and more people reject and do not want. Here in Europe, values are defined, which should then all accept and recognise. And if states do not want to do so, they are insulted, and the EU comes through the back door. That is precisely why there is now a Europe-wide, European citizens' initiative. It is called 'mother-father-children' and it collects signatures throughout Europe so that the institutions in the EU too are forced to understand marriage only as marriage. The registered civil partnership consists of two men or two women, and the marriage consists of a man and a woman – to be more precise: a man and a woman. Stop insulting or denigrating this as discrimination, or as sick, as a phobia. Accept that marriage is something other than a registered partnership. It is not better or worse, it is something else. To all those who want to protect marriage and family, I say: stay vigilant, stay engaged! We cannot expect anything good from this EU and from this Commission. The EU institutions are powerful, but the citizens end up being more powerful.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, according to the Brussels Commission, there are nearly 16 million international couples in the European Union. In any event, the Union is using this as an excuse to interfere twice in family law. A first text concerns the applicable law and the recognition of decisions on matrimonial regimes. But there is already the Hague Convention of 14 March 1978. It would be better to encourage states to ratify it rather than to compete with a European regulation. The second text concerns the recognition of decisions on registered partnerships. However, it poses a fundamental problem, because each state has its own conception of partnerships within a couple. To want to impose the recognition of foreign partnerships will therefore, sooner or later, be tantamount to circumventing national rules in this area. That is why 10 out of 28 States have refused to accept these two texts, and that is why I will vote against them.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we are indeed discussing an issue of particular importance. I wanted to congratulate your rapporteur, Mr. Cavada. There have been many practical and legal difficulties, when there has been an international partner and there has been a separation by death or because there has been a separation or divorce, because of the disparity of regulations that currently exist in the Union. In fact, there was an agreement in 2015, and one of the priorities for the Union had to be the treatment of these registered marriage schemes or 'units'. There was no unanimity, and that led to seventeen Member States subsequently asking for enhanced cooperation to essentially facilitate the lives of citizens. And that is what we are discussing today: two Regulations which seek to clarify the issue legally, to establish who has the competence, who is the competent body judicially, what is the applicable law. And then, too, the recognition and execution of all resolutions. If there is an organisation, the free movement of citizens is facilitated, which is one of the Union's priorities. The lives of citizens are also made easier; the procedure is much faster and much safer. The European Union is undoubtedly an area of freedom, security and justice, in respect for human rights and, of course, for the various legal systems of the Member States. Many cases of confusion and many cases of legal difficulties will be put to an end. This enhanced cooperation is voluntary; at any time, any other Member State may accede, and therefore it is a matter of making life easier for all citizens of the Union. In fact, it is an instrument of private international law which comes to complete the many instruments that exist today in civil law and, in particular, in family law, and above all, a very important issue which is another of the Union's values: we somehow managed to ensure the principle of non-discrimination.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – I consider the marriage of one man and one woman to be the most essential union on which every society must build. Protecting and strengthening this institute should be our political and legislative objective. In this way, we can send an important signal to the citizens of the European Union – men and women – that getting married, getting married, establishing families and having children is right, healthy, and we, as Members of the European Parliament, will always support you in this. However, it would be wrong if we tried, through European regulations, to smuggle impassable legislation into Member States, such as registered same-sex partnerships, because several countries do not yet accept this. It would be malignant. The increased increase in extremism and scepticism towards the Union is a direct consequence of such actions. Citizens feel deceived and unheeded. A similar case is the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. The European Union wants to approve it en bloc, so it will only be another blow to citizens' confidence in the common European project. Let us listen to the voice of the citizens, because it is only because of them that we are here. Let us listen to the voice of the Member States, because they form this community and not a few people in the chair. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague, you are certainly not sure that this area falls within the discretion of individual Member States – also my own state – within the framework of subsidiarity. What human right are you talking about? We all have the same human rights. No other rights based on feelings can be invented.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me first of all thank Mr Cavada for the work done on both proposals. The proposed cooperation, the enhanced cooperation seems to me to be effective.  According to the Commission, for example, in 2007, of the 2.4 million new marriages entered into in the European Union, 13% were international. It is therefore appropriate to ensure clear cross-border rights for these citizens. According to the Commission, this fact-making can also save up to EUR 1.1 billion per year, which is now spent on parallel legal proceedings in different Member States.  I also believe that member states' concerns about the non-disruptiveness of their national arrangements in the area are being treated in two cases.  Firstly, the purpose of the document is not to harmonise the substantive law of the Member States concerning the property conditions of international couples. The proposals do not say that a registered partnership is the same as marriage. The purpose of the proposal is only to ensure uniform rules for the management of the assets of international couples or in the event of division of such assets. The proposal is therefore in line with the principle of subsidiarity.  Secondly, the public policy clause is also part of the adjustment. In any event, it allows the participating State not to apply the proposed arrangements if a specific reason for public policy arises on its part, such as a difference in the concept of registered partnership.  I see free movement within the European Union as the greatest positive of the Union itself, but we must not only care about making it more difficult not to deepen this movement through intergovernmental cooperation, but to create a real common space with common rules, such as those we are discussing.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Mr Cavada for his work and, above all, for the consensus reached in the Committee on Legal Affairs on this dossier. By adopting this regulation, we are finally taking a step forward, as my fellow Members have said, for real rights. This regulation, in fact, finally gives a concrete response to the need for legal certainty and simplification for some sixteen million European couples living in cross-border situations. It will finally be easier to know the law, to apply the competent jurisdiction and how to apply the different existing ownership regimes. The hope is that now, after the entry into force of the regulation in the eighteen States that have supported enhanced cooperation, more can be added, so as to make the European legal order even more effective and coherent. Finally, I would like to thank the Dutch Presidency for having succeeded in successfully closing the negotiations, and in this regard I call on the future Slovak Presidency to work to extend the consensus to the entire Council on this reform.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE).
text: – Madam President, only in the last plenary this Parliament voted in favour of decreasing bureaucracy for Union citizens, especially when exercising their right to free movement and establishment, when we voted in a system of recognition of public documents. Tomorrow, with Parliament’s vote – I hope in favour – on Mr Cavada’s reports, international couples in the EU will obtain a clearer framework within which they can manage their property. To date, international couples at their most vulnerable moments in their personal lives – that is upon the demise of a spouse or partner, or the dissolution of their marriage or partnership – have been burdened even further by complex legal rules regulating which courts could determine issues relating to their property regimes and which law should apply. Often, after obtaining a decision on divorce, separation or dissolution of a partnership, the couple have needed to institute separate and distinct proceedings in another jurisdiction to have issues related to their property regime determined. These two proposals for Council regulations on enhanced cooperation will ensure clarity and certainty. Couples will enjoy simplified procedures so that if they are involved in divorce, separation or succession proceedings, it will be the same court ruling on these proceedings that will determine issues related to their property regimes. Couples will no longer need to institute proceedings in different states and get embroiled in complex legal issues to obtain justice. Laws should be there to assist citizens in obtaining access to a remedy and to a judicial determination. These proposals will ensure just that.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, these proposals for a Council regulation on matrimonial regimes and property effects are the result of institutional discussions that have already gone back too long. Although we regret the deadlock in negotiations between Member States, we are pleased that these proposals are coming back to Parliament in the form of enhanced cooperation, containing numerous amendments proposed by the European legislature. The regulation will be a very useful tool for international couples in the European Union and we are referring here to more than 16 million couples, clearly setting out which court has jurisdiction to rule on applications for matrimonial property regimes. However, these rights must be extended in all Member States to ensure equal treatment for families, anywhere in Europe. Unfortunately, we have also encountered many couples made up of Romanian citizens, who have encountered such difficulties because of differences in legislation. This regulation will thus allow for the elimination of many cases of confusion and legal difficulties, helping international couples and families to benefit from clear protection and, why not, additional support for mobility in the European area.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. We are talking today on a very important topic. It would seem that it is marginal , at least in comparison with the enormity of the problems facing the European Union, the crises that are emogeing us, tomorrow's referendum in The United Kingdom, but I believe that it is nevertheless fundamental. It actually shows what the European Union is and in which direction it is going, and what it will be like in the future. A community that boasts and prides itself around the world on being so humanistic, and which says that its foundation is equality and tolerance, comes to a day like today, when we are glad that tomorrow perhaps we will vote for the obvious that should have been in force for a long time in the European Union: Actually, why are there a social agreement that has established states and those countries that later, in a process that began sixty years ago, have established the European Union? They exist to give people at least a chance to be lucky. To date, in many areas of activity, not only public, but also private life, we do not give these opportunities, or limit them. The legislation that we are talking about today and, I hope, the decisions that we will adopt tomorrow are a small but important and necessary step towards building such a relationship between the state and the citizen, between the European Union and European society, where the citizen is an entity, and the European Union and the Member States are the institutions to serve and serve him to be happy.  Therefore, in concluding, Madam President, I appeal to all those countries which, after all, have adopted these decisions – small but necessary and necessary for the happiness of the people – so far.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this proposal is indeed an asset to around 13 % of couples in the European Union, according to 2007 data. After nine years, I suppose and I imagine it will be much more these couples. If we add divorces to marriages, the more so will the situations that determined the existence of a set of rules that were clear in relation to property rights for couples in the European Union, and, as has already been said, the family law safeguarded, as well as the matrimonial property regimes not being affected in their substantiact. In this sense, the recognition of these rights is an important instrument. These are civil justice, the property of couples, including couples in a proven union, which will ensure the free movement of judicial decisions and the recognition of those decisions in the countries of the Union.  I regret, however, that common sense and, above all, justice have not avenged in the Council to the point of achieving a decision that was unanimous, desirable and that there has been a need to resort to enhanced cooperation. Only seventeen of us trusted each other.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I very much support this material. Like my colleagues who spoke from my faction before me, I regret a little that the material has been approved for more or less five or six years since it began to be discussed in the Council.  Unfortunately, I remember, at that time I represented the Czech Republic at the Council of Ministers of Justice, and even then it was shown that there would be a long way to go before the material was finally adopted. Perhaps, finally, common sense will prevail tomorrow, and we will accept this material, although unfortunately it concerns only 18 countries, not the entire European Union, and therefore logically its effectiveness will be limited territorially to only part of our Community. It must be said here that this material does not in any way limit the sovereignty of the Member States. It does not affect their family law, it does not interfere with whether or not a country recognises a registered partnership. And that has to be said here, because unfortunately some of the pre-ers have been a little bit more important in what we are discussing today.  It is a set of conflict of laws rules, private international law and international procedural law. Once this material has been received, it will become clear what specific courts in the case will decide for an international couple who resolves property disputes. That is, we are dealing with jurisdiction and one applicable law will be determined in addition. And as a practitioner, I am clear that this will help greatly in practice, because I had a number of clients, people who were from an international union, and it was, in a way, a big problem that their assets were dealt with by different legal regimes. And that's what we're removing here today. So it is a matter that objectively helps citizens. I do not understand, therefore, that anyone can oppose an arrangement that is objectively for the benefit of our citizens, it is not regulation from Brussels that restricts our citizens. So I am very happy, thank you to the rapporteur, I support the material and I hope that it will be adopted tomorrow, although, as I have already said, I would like it to apply to the whole territory of the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the management and liquidation of the assets of international couples, as a result of the separation of the couple or the death of one of the spouses, initially falls within the exclusive national jurisdiction. However, the Council proposes to change this situation. It wants to create a single regime so that the question of the assets of international couples is subject to international law. However, the regulation being adopted thus invalidates national laws; The public policy clause addresses the problem of not recognising certain partnerships in certain countries, but I do not think it solves the new problems created by the new regulation, since it violates the principle of subsidiarity and does not respect the cultural traditions of the Member States of the Union. I therefore believe that the regulation creates more problems than it solves.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, finally good news for as many as 16 million Citizens of the European Union. Indeed, there has been too long legal uncertainty for such a large number of citizens who have a registered partnership or are married couples from different countries. It is inadmissible that another ten members, ten EU countries, do not accept this proposal from the Commission and our rapporteur, Mr. Cavada. It is unacceptable because regardless of what love is the most beautiful thing in the world and what I like to say love has no alternative, yet divorces happen, accidents happen, people die and we should provide such citizens with legal certainty. There is no other way for us because if we don't, I don't know what values we will then build the European Union to the end.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the increasing mobility of people in an area without internal borders has led to a significant increase in unions between citizens of different Member States. As many as sixteen million international couples are forced to face difficulties both in the day-to-day management of their assets and at the time of the division of assets following personal separation or death of the partner. Difficulties often arise from the great disparity between the applicable rules, both in substantive law and in private international law, on the property effects of marriage. I therefore welcome a regulation which affirms, in a unified manner and respectful of the choices of the Member States, the sensitive issues concerning the capacity of the partners, the validity or recognition of a union, maintenance obligations and the succession of the pre-death partner. The great step forward is the principle of the unity of applicable law, which provides that the law of property regimes between spouses applies to all assets held within the Union, wherever they may be. In short, we need a uniform regulation which will be of real help in the development of family issues.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam Speaker, after several years of complex negotiations 18 Member States have expressed their wish to participate in the enhanced cooperation. I trust that more will join. I would like to invite the Parliament to give its positive opinion on the two regulations implementing the enhanced cooperation. We are removing legal complications, making the lives of EU citizens simpler. International couples in the Union, whether in a marriage or a registered partnership, will benefit from Union common rules in handling their property matters. I would also like to invite Member States who have not yet done so to join the enhanced cooperation, because the more Member States that join, the greater number of citizens will benefit from the regulations.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I do not know if this will be the last word, but at least for tonight, probably, on this subject. I want to publicly thank the Council, its services and those of the European Commission for ending six years - I would say - of inequality. Why do I use that term? If 18 countries have agreed to sign up to some kind of pact - the same regulation at least - for couples or "registered partners" - as they say modestly - that is, either unmarried male-female couples or same-sex couples living together, it is because they have found a demand in their country, and because these citizens cannot be left outlawed and , moreover, in conflict with international systems that no single person, even with a good lawyer, can overcome, because it is extremely complicated to be locked up in this suffering.  The 16 million couples I was talking about earlier represent 32 million married or registered individuals, and in reality 64 million people - because each has two parents - who are projected into the world of Kafka, because it is not possible to overcome or very difficult. I am therefore very grateful for the political will that the two institutions have put in helping us - the shadow rapporteurs and I - to bring about a text that has dragged on too long. Why did he drag him too far? Because it is quite strange , and indeed some have said earlier - that the European Union, by claiming values, as you said, dear colleague, has favoured free movement, free protection, free defence before the courts of capital, goods and services than the situations of individuals. We have dragged on too long and I want to thank those who had the political courage to break down the obstacles to reach this agreement. I'll end by saying two little things. First, does this text call into question subsidiarity? But absolutely not since, on the contrary, it is exclusive: those who do not want to subscribe to this text are not in the eighteen who have accepted it. Better yet, those who have citizens in their country who want to use a court to settle their international situation but live in a country that does not want to change family law will still be protected by going to another country's court. That is why my colleagues, myself and the two institutions have been able to come up with a text which, in reality, is of great human simplicity, because it finally protects a minority that has been ransacked by the will of ignorance of States. As for the ten who do not want it, they will have the latitude to consider whether it is beneficial to citizens who have an obligation to use it, or to refuse it.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The high mobility of Eu citizens makes them much more likely to marry people from a country other than their own in other Member States. The Commission has identified uncertainty regarding the property rights of international couples as one of the main obstacles EU citizens still face in their daily lives when they wish to exercise their rights outside their country. The purpose of this proposal is, in particular, to establish in the Union a clear legal framework governing the conditions for determining the court competent to hear disputes between international couples, the law governing property relations and facilitating the movement of judgments and authentic instruments between Member States. In conclusion, this regulation, which includes jurisdiction and applicable law and the recognition and enforcement of judicial decisions in the field of matrimonial property regimes, will be a useful instrument, putting an end to the numerous misunderstandings and legal difficulties that international couples may encounter.

name: Емил Радев (
text: PPE), in writing. – Dear Colleagues, there are around 16 million international couples in Europe who are married or living in a registered partnership, and the marriage or partnership of at least 650 000 of them breaks down each year. Decisions on matrimonial property regimes and the property consequences of registered partnerships are therefore of utmost importance to European citizens. It is currently very difficult for international couples to understand who the competent courts are and what is the law applicable to their personal situation and property. The rules vary considerably from country to country and sometimes lead to conflict situations. International couples affected by the share of common property face complex issues, in particular as regards applicable law, choice of court, recognition and enforcement of judgments.  The adoption of this Regulation will avoid legal differences between the 18 Member States participating in enhanced cooperation. Thus, European citizens will not face legal uncertainty and bear the accompanying costs when sharing their property in the event of divorce, separation or death. Member States' decision to enter this enhanced cooperation is particularly timely and I am pleased that it contains a large part of the 2013 EP recommendations, in particular as regards regulatory certainty and clarity.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "No parting is easy. No matter what the causes are, it is a kind of personal failure. The decision to divorce is only the first step. Later, when the division of assets occurs, huge legal problems begin, especially for international couples. Both regulations are intended to improve this situation by regulating the rules on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of decisions of courts on the division of assets. And, frankly, it doesn't matter if they're heterosexual couples or not , everyone has the right to access justice. These regulations do not introduce a back door to the recognition of one definition or another of marriage or a partnership institution. The only possible consequence is the enforcement of a judgment delivered in one State in the territory of another Member State. This, too, is covered by a public policy clause in the text. I therefore pity the citizens of those Member States who have not joined the enhanced cooperation, e.g. Polish. They will be disadvantaged, they will not be able to benefit from a clear set of rules, which will make legal proceedings longer and more costly.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the course of preparing this report, we consulted the Commission's Directorate-General for Culture and Education, European associations representing various bodies involved in education processes, national organisations, including those operating at local level. We also consulted the ministries of education of several countries. I have also tried to include in this report the results of the evaluations commissioned by the European Commission and the various position papers published by the organisations. Therefore, in order for this report not to be a report on everything, I have decided to focus on three main points. As you will note, this report has three parts. One concerns some proposals on how to organise this framework of cooperation in the field of education. The second part concerns the quality of education and training. Finally, the third concerns a very topical one, but I also do not hide – and I will say a few more words – the controversial subject: migration and education and training.  I would like to emphasise now only a few points that seem to me to be very important in this report, and are worth highlighting. For me, they are especially important. Firstly, we draw attention in this report to the role of the family in education. This seems obvious, but it is obvious, which is often forgotten today, namely that all this data shows the importance of the home environment for the development of the child's basic skills, then communication between school and parents, also relevant in matters such as shaping civic attitudes or preventing radicalisation.  Another aspect that is mentioned here is the community-based approach to education, which emphasizes the importance of all local organisations and actors. Unfortunately, there was no compromise amendment in which we also wanted to include religious organisations, local NGOs. And once again, we have just highlighted the role of parents, their responsibilities and the need to ensure that children's education has an impact. This is so important that there are no members of European organisations representing parents in the working groups that have already been set up.  Finally, another aspect is to appreciate all the successes of European policy in this regard, such as the Bologna Process, such as the student mobility programme or teaching staff. I wanted to draw attention in this report – and this sentence has also been divided by the shadow rapporteurs – to some weaknesses in this process, namely the feeling in academia of ignoring the objections of academics related to the Bologna Process. Therefore, we recommend that the university community be more involved in the ET 2020 work cycle. More flexibility is needed in the use of modules or the ECT points system and, most importantly, mobility results should also be based on qualitative indicators, not only quantitative indicators. Finally, the issue of migrants. I would also like to draw attention to this very briefly. We focus on immigrants from outside Europe, but all the data shows that the children of intra-European migrants also have great difficulties in adapting to society, and here educational systems are of great importance. We also advocate the inclusion of teachers from migration in the education system, of course in the exchange of practices, but also in helping migrants, including those in Europe, to adapt to the requirements and standards of teaching in the host country. Thank you very much, Madam President. I am waiting for the opinion of colleagues.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank the Culture and Education Committee and especially the rapporteur Mr Krasnodębski for his excellent report which follows up on the Joint Council and Commission report regarding the strategic framework for European cooperation in Education and Training 2020. Education and Training 2020 is important: it is the umbrella under which all EU-level policy exchanges on education and training between Member States take place. It covers learning in all contexts, whether formal or non-formal, and at all levels, from early childhood education and schools through to higher education, vocational education and training, and other learning. Thanks to the joint report which the Commission and Council adopted last November, we defined our new common priorities in the field of education and training, which all contribute to the current top priorities of the EU. We now have a much more focused agenda which concentrates on key issues, namely the provision of relevant and high-quality knowledge, the recognition and transparency of skills, inclusive education including the promotion of civic competences, the promotion of innovative approaches fully embracing the digital era, strong support for our teachers and, last but not least, sustainable investment in education and training. We have made sure that Education and Training 2020 is firmly embedded in the Union’s overall political priorities and actively contributes to the development of skills and employability. The New Skills Agenda, which the Commission adopted on 10 June, underscores this point and announces a series of actions at EU-level in which education cooperation plays a key role. Education and training are not only important for acquiring skills for jobs: education is equally important to ensure social inclusion and to make certain that our human and civic values are safeguarded and passed on to future generations. These elements have been much reinforced in the new priorities under Education and Training 2020. I am proud to announce that one of the working groups is specially dedicated to the follow-up of the Paris Declaration, and we play a key role in exchanging with Member States on how to strengthen inclusive education and our common values – a very relevant development in the light of the recent action plan for the integration of migrants, and the new Commission communication to support the prevention of violent extremism , which were adopted some days ago, both highlighting this dimension. I am very pleased that the European Parliament is strongly supporting this increased attention to social inclusion, civic competences and common values in our work with Member States. Your voice will be important to further develop this dimension. Your report also highlights a number of problematic issues on the European education scene. We have taken good note of your concern about a brain-drain and imbalanced mobility, for example. Of course, there are larger structural issues behind this which go beyond the education dimension, such as varying employment opportunities across Europe. The Bologna Process, which supports the provision of high-quality education in all Member States, makes a positive contribution to addressing these challenges. Also the new Education and Training 2020 working group on the modernisation of higher education will address the issues of internationalisation, recognition and mobility in a balanced perspective. Let me end by once again thanking Parliament and the rapporteur, Mr Krasnodębski, for your very valuable input and your strong support for our joint efforts in this field. I am now looking forward to what will surely be an interesting debate.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by sincerely thanking the rapporteur for this report, my colleague Krasnodebski, who has taken it systematically and written it with great understanding of the value of education.  Therefore, the report also stresses that education and training are a value in themselves and should not be oriented solely towards meeting the needs of the labour market. The report respects subsidiarity. The competences we have at EU level are relatively limited, but education is increasingly expected. From the fight against radicalisation to economic growth and poverty reduction. This is because we know that setting educational objectives and tools determines how our children will be prepared and successful in the future and whether we will be able to ensure their satisfaction and economic growth in the EU.  That is why the European Parliament is opposed to the European Commission's proposal, which has narrowed the framework from 13 to six priorities, and member states will choose from them according to their different situations.  Firstly, it is the relevance and quality of skills, secondly, inclusive education, innovative education, strong support for teachers, recognition of non-formal learning outcomes and the effectiveness of education. I consider it important that the report emphasises the need to support teachers, adding that erasmus should be an instrument at EU level.  The report also highlights the role of early childhood and primary education for lifelong learning, the focus on accessibility and quality, as well as the quality of vocational training and the expansion of language learning programmes.  In the context of the evaluation, the report draws attention to the risk of testing. The report also realistically assesses the Bologna Process and calls for its fulfilment.  It is in conjunction with the rise in radicalisation that the European Parliament is calling for a survey of how education systems incorporate ethics and personality and social education into their education programmes as a tool that has proven itself in many schools. I supply as a prevention for the creation of good people-to-people relationships and measures against bullying and violence. This report is worth reading, but above all it will be good to go back to it and implement its recommendations.

name: Silvia Costa
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that this update of the ET2020 strategy for education and training has indeed developed new objectives and taken on board the new challenges that Europe has. We were talking earlier about the issue not only of radicalisation but also of an education that takes on at least two challenges: social inclusion – we still have too many differences in educational landscapes – and greater attention to the quality of education systems, on the one hand, and, on the other, the ability to create the so-called informal competences of citizenship, transversal key competences that also serve to activate that intercultural dialogue , that ability to be citizens not only of Europe but also of the world that is now absolutely necessary. I would like to thank Mr Krasnodębski very much for this report. We realise that today the strategic issue of education and cultural investment is a matter for the future of Europe. It is important that this communication on the modernisation of higher education has been announced, not least in order to make the system of comparability of qualifications, credits and also the Bologna process more effective, which still has several difficulties. I think it is absolutely right, as the rapporteur said, to support teachers as well. I think that perhaps the problem of support for teachers should be better highlighted and that it is absolutely necessary, for example, to make increasingly use of the EFSI investment plan for European platforms that also help in the field of education and education, for example with regard to the digital adaptation of educational profiles and content. There remains the problem of too many differences that still exist in Europe as regards the difference in access, educational poverty, learning outcomes and the study perspective for immigrants. I believe, however, that this initiative, together with the initiative presented by Commissioner Thyssen together with Commissioner Navracsics on the agenda for new skills, can finally build greater centrality of European education policies.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, among the main objectives of the Union's strategic framework 'Education and Training 2020' are to improve the quality of the education system of the Member States of the Union, as well as to promote equality at all levels of education and training. The Union's attitude, of course, does not seem to reinforce this strategy. The austerity policies imposed by the troika in some Member States of the Union have led these countries to cut spending in the field of education.  Specifically in Greece, according to the 2017 state budget, expenditure on education will amount to 4.2 billion euros, while since 2009 they have fallen by 35.6%. At the same time, the Greek prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, dared to talk about supposedly fair growth and decently paid jobs, while in Greece in the first quarter of 2016 the unemployment rate reached 24.9%, the highest in Europe. If the Union really wants to achieve the objectives of its strategy, it must abandon austerity policies and boost investment in education, innovation and growth.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, European cooperation in the field of education and training is voluntary but essential. Cooperation and, in particular, exchanges of best practice have proved to be very useful. Yet very little is communicated within the Member States and the various bodies participating in the framework strategy. We should encourage and further support Member States in order to ensure coherent, transparent and inclusive education providing an appropriate response to the needs of the current diverse groups of learners in both formal and non—formal educational settings. Creating alternative ways of learning and facilitating the recognition of learning are vital means of widening access to educational opportunities. Better cooperation between Member States is needed on the establishment of new, innovative and interactive methods of teaching, training and learning, where individuals are active participants in the educational process. That will increase the attractiveness and effectiveness of the educational process and will enhance the development of students’ creativity. Further efforts are needed with regard to improving early childhood education and fostering its modernisation, and there is also an urgent need for reinforcement of the renewed European agenda for adult learning. Better cooperation between the EU and the national authorities is required in order to find the right approach to swiftly, fully and sustainably integrating refugees, migrants and asylum seekers into education and training systems and ensuring that those who have already obtained qualifications get proper recognition for them. To conclude, I would underline the importance of better monitoring in order to implement education and training strategies successfully.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the European Union's strategy in the field of education is essentially cooperation in the dismantling, degradation and fragmentation of education in Europe. It is a collaboration for the commercialisation of knowledge and the privatisation of the education system. It is a mechanism for reproducing the distorted pattern of unpaid, precarious work without rights. Neoliberal perception has altered the very concept of education. Instead of promoting integrated knowledge, it creates sterile pieces of knowledge, ready for assembly, depending on the requirements of the market and the dominant economic interests.  The whole situation is also exacerbated by austerity policies. Especially in countries like Greece, which are in an adjustment programme, education has been dealt a huge blow. Underfunding and public spending cuts on education devalue education systems and, combined with disinvestment, lead to high rates of long-term unemployment of up to 40% among young people, resulting in deregulation of industrial relations and an increase in the phenomenon of brain drain.  If we want a high-level education, as our youth deserve, the strategy of European cooperation in the field of education must change radically. For Europe's young people, the future cannot be semi-learning, unemployment, part-time and precarious work and migration. Education is a social good, we must preserve it by strengthening its public, free and social character at all levels.

name: Ernest Maragall
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I am sorry, Mr Navracsics, but no, it's not an excellent report.  Not so much for what he says as for what he doesn't say, so he shuts up or so he doesn't develop. In a European strategy we are reviewing, this Parliament should play a role of stimulus, of positive demand in relation to the actions of the European Commission, and it is not. This report falls short in content and even more in strategic ambition, below the Commission's initial proposal. For example, we have had to struggle to include explicit references to the refugee issue, such as against a kind of incomprehensible allergy to the mere expression of the concept. As if not talking about refugees or asylum seekers made them disappear from our reality, and even now, tomorrow we will have to work on the [unintelligible] to defend their presence in the report. The most serious thing is the renunciation of considering this strategy from its possible added value in European terms, not from a perspective of simple improvement of coordination between Member States. Families, parents, religious communities, attention to radicalization. No, Mr. Krasnod-bski. We can understand your concern, from contradictions of national policy in your country, but we cannot admit that you are trying to translate that logic into a very European debate on one of your core strategies. The report makes excessive criticism, perhaps, of the Bologna process, but deals insufficiently with such important issues as preschool education, the promotion of e-skills, the premature abandonment of the training process and others of the same caliber. In all of them the report expresses the corresponding wishful thinking, good intentions, but does not identify critical points or offer clear lines of improvement. Education and training are not instruments at the service of the economy and growth. They're much more than that. They are part of being or not being from Europe. They are the common mold where natural diversity must appear and where we can learn from each other to share, to build, to be a country and to be Europe, without fear or mutual suspicion.

name: Isabella Adinolfi
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, austerity policies have had devastating effects, which have also fully affected the education sector, undermining its quality, the conditions of teachers, families, students and access to training opportunities. Unfortunately, in this report we have not had the courage to denounce the fact that the marked reduction in funding and, more generally, the increase in the problems of the education and training sector are a direct consequence of the austerity policies that the Commission continues to impose on European citizens. Since the beginning of the crisis, it has been found that the choices of models adopted at EU level, rather than converging towards reducing inequalities, have dramatically accentuated disparities and discrimination based on economic ownership. The fact that the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training is clearly functional to the current economic model of the Union, which also incorporates the Juncker plan, is yet another confirmation of a cynical desire to continue along a path that has already proved to be unsuccessful and damaging. Since the beginning of the legislature, we as a 5-Star Movement have been calling for tangible actions aimed at strengthening the social dimension of education and training. Since the beginning of the legislature, we as the 5-star Movement have been calling for a real will to be demonstrated in order to reduce the very serious socio-economic problems affecting citizens' lives and equal access to educational and training opportunities. Concealing reality will only serve to be overwhelmed like a flooded river when it is too late. We cannot confine ourselves to sterile declarations of intent, we cannot continue to sell as a panacea models of economic governance, austerity, initiatives and plans that have already created disasters in half of Europe. For people living in a dark corner of social pain and marginalisation, who are in fact also denied free access to knowledge and knowledge, the empty talk of politics is an unbearable and cruelly mocking exercise. I will continue to denounce this absurd situation relentlessly and to fight for change to take place as quickly as possible.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I am delighted to mention the major differences in situations facing Member States. I agree with the need to improve the status of teachers and teachers, as well as their salaries, given the unbearable pressure of the austerity policies imposed by Brussels. Ditto for the development of quality learning policies or better meeting the specific needs of people with disabilities.  As for the integration of migrants through education, I would remind you that the real humanitarian posture is not to penalise countries undergoing the emigration of human and economic resources. Education partnerships could be created with neighbouring states or countries or conflict zones. For example, establishing educational corridors to allow students from war zones to continue studying as close as possible to their homes.  Despite these divergent points, I greet the rapporteur by quoting his honourable compatriot Saint John Paul II: "Education is more than a profession, it is a mission to help each person to recognize what is irreplaceable and unique so that it grows and flourishes." (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam Member, I have only a brief, brief question for you. Can you please tell us about this plenary session, what is dictating to us in the field of education by the so-called Brussels, as you mentioned in your speech? I'd like to broaden my horizons.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. – ... (inaudible) but I can tell you that in France, Brussels dictates a lot of things to us, especially in the field of education or in the economy of our countries, since you know that you have, for example, - I am not going to talk about seconded workers - laws that are made and which are contrary to what we would like.  You know that not all our countries are equal. We don't have the same way of learning, we don't have the same learning, we are different on many things. Wanting to put everyone in the same basket is a serious problem, and it is precisely Brussels that dictates these problems to us.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Prof. Krasnodębski rightly said that the influence of parents on education must be increased. But there is only one way to increase it, namely to give money back to parents – all the same: in cash or in an educational voucher – so that they pay for a private school, because only then will the school do what parents want. As long as the state pays for the school, it will continue to do what the bureaucracy and teachers' unions demand, and the needs of the student will be completely unnoticed. In addition, I once read a book about education in Switzerland, the author of which said that in this country schools are diverse: two-, three- and four-year, with different languages, etc., and yet Swiss education is the best in the world. It did not occur to this idiot that it is the best because it is diverse, and the Union, unwillingly, will kill this diversity. Moreover, Mrs Costa has made it clear that there is too much diversity in Europe. I would like to dispel illusions: the more money is spent on education, the worse. I remind you that the best level was during the National Socialist occupation, when the education was secret, very little money was spent on it, and the level was very high at the time. More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.
