name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this report, which is fundamental, nevertheless does not cease to show inaccuracies in the language of research and education, and seems to me unambitious with regard to 21st century education.  You can see that you only touch gender issues once. In a Europe united in diversity, it makes no sense to defend aquaculture processes. It makes sense to defend social and cultural inclusion.  The emphasis on teaching and not learning is a symptom of this. The subliminal relationship between pedagogical innovation and information and communication technologies also solidify my perspective. Pedagogical innovation is not commendable by the use of computer tools. Information and communication technologies are mere pedagogical materials, as the typewriter has been in the past.  From a European point of view, it seems to me that there is, at times, a clear split between what we propose and the results. In fact, it is quite a good thing that 40% of young Europeans have a higher education degree. But let us be honest, there are many member states with immense difficulties for the new generation of graduates. In my country, Portugal, this generation is known for the generation of 500 €.  I have no doubt of the importance of the social sciences and humanities, but how far is entrepreneurial Europe available to meet speculative and critical thinking? It was no accident that the brain drain occurred in some countries. In the case of Portugal, this phenomenon was glaring as a result of four years of very hard austerity. Talking about unbalanced mobility is, for me, a forced immigration euphemism.  Demotivation in the field of education has become widespread: we have teachers and educators who have been hit in their dignity by unfair assessments and absurd pay cuts that have had the blessing of the European Union. If education is a public and common good, then do not suggest, as it appears in this report, that it is the bank that secures the future of our young people.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar an gcéad dul síos cuirim fáilte roimh ghnéithe áirithe den tuarascáil seo, go háirithe an tagairt do chiorruithe san oideachas mar aon le moltaí chun coinníollacha oibre do mhúinteoirí a fheabhsú.  É sin ráite, ceann de na gnéithe atáim buartha mar gheall air ná an tagairt d’iasachtaí do scoláirí. Tá sé fíorthábhachtach go mbeadh airgead ar fáil ar ndóigh do scoláirí maidir lena gcuid staidéar ach ní dóigh liom gur chóir a bheith ag cur ualach trom iasachtaí airgid ar ár scoláirí agus iad ag tosú amach ar a saol proifisiúnta tar éis dóibh coláiste a chríochnú.  Tá sé riachtanach go mbeadh scéim níos fearr againn maidir le scoláireachtaí agus deontais chun tacú le scoláirí agus iad i mbun a gcuid staidéar agus iad ag freastal ar an tríú leibhéal. Tá taiscí do chóiríocht, cíos, bia, leabhair agus ábhar ar chuid de na costais atá i gceist maidir le cur chun cinn an oideachais. Agus tá an táille chlárúcháin de EUR 3 000 in Éirinn in aghaidh na bliana ar cheann de na táillí is airde san Eoraip. Bíonn amanna ann a mbíonn ar scoláirí cinneadh a dhéanamh idir bia a cheannach agus iad féin a chothú nó ábhair agus leabhair ar chúrsaí atá riachtanach dá gcuid oideachais a cheannach. Mar sin, tá sé suas chugainne mar reachtóirí rochtain ar oideachas a chinntiú do gach duine agus ní díreach dóibh siúd a bhfuil an cumas airgid acu.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, the revision of the strategic framework is of particular importance, as with it the institutions of the European Union can set new political priorities.  But for lifelong learning, not only is the prism of economic growth and the generation of occupation important: only from comprehensive strategies will we achieve results in terms of employment, social inclusion and citizen participation, including, at the same time, important dimensions such as tolerance and intercultural dialogue.  The report we are debating today does not meet this perspective or the necessary ambition. Issues such as the low performance of students in some fields, the high percentage of adults without chance due to lack of skills, the high dropout rate that leads to social exclusion, low citizen participation and the employability of graduates: these are the issues that our group wanted to address.  The report is insufficient: there are key topics that do not appear or are totally underestimated. That is why we cannot support the report.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I want to be positive in my speech. I personally see the education of every citizen of the European Union as important for acquiring knowledge and expertise. As a result, it gains access to the labour market and thus becomes competitive. However, education has a different role than the pure acquisition of knowledge and skills. Its task is to develop responsibility, impartiality, critical thinking, curiosity, but also empathy in people. And these are the skills of so-called emotional intelligence.  Through cooperation between Member States and between educational institutions, young people have the opportunity to broaden their horizons and gain unique experiences abroad. We must say openly here that ERASMUS and ERASMUS+ are great achievements of European integration.  However, ladies and gentlemen, European education systems have a number of shortcomings and we must admit this. And we must try to correct these errors precisely within the strategic framework of European cooperation on education and training. In particular, these are problems caused by increased mobility and the current refugee crisis. These two phenomena often change the structure of national education systems, but at the same time show a lack of flexibility. How do we respond to the refugee crisis within education programmes?  If you agree with me that we don't, we have to change that. I therefore believe that education, in addition to its main functions, is also the key to integration. The integration that the European Union so badly needs to reduce cultural disparities, combat segregation, radicalisation, extremism and, after all, terrorism.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the strategic framework for European cooperation in the field of vocational education and training needs to be reformed. A new list of priorities is needed, taking into account the challenges posed by new technologies and the high youth unemployment rate. That is why the message of this report must be clear: vocational education and training are not a cost, they are an investment; investment in Europe's human capital, Europe's productivity and competitiveness in the future. That is why I stress four elements for achieving this objective: increasing budget allocations for formal and non-formal education, but also for teacher training, extending the Erasmus programme to include pre-university and vocational education, but also strengthening cross-cutting skills, developing digital skills and including new technologies in education programmes or combating early school leaving through coherent programmes, and reducing inequalities in access to cultural capital , by introducing a system of cultural vouchers for young people. We need to build a Union of Education, and the first step is to overcome differences and use constructively the strengths of every education system in the Member States.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this report, in my opinion, brings nothing or almost nothing, just words to make up a reality, which is that of the idea of a commodified education. There is talk in this report of improving teacher and teacher training, when we see that many of our researchers are going abroad. There is talk of implementing programmes adapted to migrants, to lower classes to promote social cohesion, and at the same time, it is obligated, for example, in my country, in Spain, to cut 8 billion in education. There is talk of the importance of recognizing qualifications, but it is not criticized that there are qualifications, such as those of health technicians in Spain, which are still not approved. And finally, I would like to recall that the problems of low labour absorption of graduates are not so much in an education system that is increasingly rigid and logic-oriented than what they are trying to call the labour market, but are the low diversification of the economy and the public reduction in research and development in the main problems. There is no doubt that the orientation in education needs profound change, both in Europe and in my country, in Spain.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, although education is the responsibility of each Member State and falls within its competence, it is important that objectives for the quality and quantity of education have been set at European level, and that these objectives are compared, and that best practices are sought between the various Member States and, above all, that the free movement of Europeans can also take place in such a way that student exchanges are active and that later students have the opportunity to seek employment elsewhere in Europe as well, thanks to their language skills and cultural knowledge. When we want to build a better Europe, good, high-quality education is, of course, the key to a better future for every person themselves and for Europe as a whole. Especially in these economically tight times, care must be taken not to compromise on the quality of education. One of the things that can best ensure the good quality of education is precisely good, qualified teachers. In other words, there is one way to ensure a good education: to ensure that we have skilled, competent teachers whose working conditions are taken care of.   It is not just a question of pay, although wage levels are also an important factor. It is important that teachers have good working conditions and also have access to continuing education and the development of their own competence. We know that it is very important for every child to have an enthusiastic, motivated and competent teacher who knows how to encourage children to move forward, and that will have an impact on the future of tens, hundreds and thousands of children.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, teachers used to be one of the main pillars of society, valued for their important role in transferring knowledge from generation to generation. Today, the public education system unfortunately treats them too often as ordinary bureaucratic outposts and kills their motivation and creativity. Some Member States, including Croatia, prioritise their form even at the expense of quality. We should not be surprised by the high rates of unemployment among young people, because the education system shapes them in accordance with political decisions, not the needs of modern society and the labour market. I am pleased that the rapporteur recognises these problems and offers certain quality solutions. It is very important to improve the position of teachers within the system and society in general and to facilitate them to acquire new competences, especially in the field of communication and information technologies, so that our children have the best education in the future and are globally competitive.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to highlight three areas of this Framework for European Cooperation in the field of education and training. Namely, the first issue is the mobility of young people and the possibility of exchanging experiences through various programs. An excellent programme has certainly developed, but I point out another one – Euroodiseja – perhaps a little less well known, but which has achieved great results, where young people, thanks to the roles that local and regional communities play in the European Union, are really enabled to exchange experiences and new knowledge, and thus better and easier employment in the economy.  Another thing I want to highlight is the role of regional and local communities. Especially local communities that often manage schools and educational institutions and of course there is an important contact that they then have directly with parents.  And the last thing that may even be the most important issue is the education of migrant children and migrants alone, but especially migrant children, so that we can integrate them into society so that they do not have even bigger problems in 20, 30 or 40 years than we have today.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first let me remind Members that this area which we are talking about belongs to the area of the principle of subsidiarity. That means that even if we can identify common goals and objectives, we have to make coalitions with the Member States. It is not the European Commission that can direct the Member States in those fields. We can generate a critical mass for change, but that is a different dynamic than in other areas. That is why I think it is very important to identify the common problems and define shared responses. That is what we are doing, and in this process the ET2020 monitoring and assessment system is a very important, highly appreciated instrument: highly appreciated by the Member States, because they take part in the working groups, they accept the results of the working groups and they follow the recommendations from the ET2020 mechanism, and that is why I think it is a very important instrument in our hands to generate change in European education and training systems. There is a consensus that European education and training systems have two objectives: to produce employable people and to produce good citizens. Both of them are equally important. We have to change our education systems in order to equip young citizens with better knowledge to make them good citizens and democrats and, at the same time, employable citizens as well. That is why we have to concentrate on all those issues which were raised here, and we have to find a good solution for that. We have tangible and concrete proposals and actions. We are dismantling barriers between countries via the Bologna process, in the framework of Erasmus+, by eTraining systems, by online language courses, by student-mobility programs, by the European qualification framework... these are all instruments that can make the life of the European citizens easier. We also give help to the Member States in handling the refugee crisis, with online courses, with social integration programmes, with funding for NGOs, local communities and teachers and schools. We are taking part in the refugee integration process. Of course we have a lot of problems, but together with you and the Member States I am sure that we can address all those challenges in the future.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski
text: Rapporteur. – Thank you very much to your colleagues for a very interesting discussion. I also have a request before you make your last decision on how to vote tomorrow. Please read this report carefully again, because it seems to me that some of the reservations that you have raised are not covered by this report. For example, we are talking about social aspects clearly in recital Q, where we are talking about educational impoverishment, poor integration of people in social difficulties. The same is true in recitals D and J and paragraphs 42 and 41. Therefore, please note that this problem is being addressed. We are also talking about the fact that education is also a value in itself. For example, recital B already says that education and training must not be aimed solely at meeting market needs, but should be of value in itself. Finally, the same threads appear in recital C and paragraphs 46, 47 and 48. Please read this report a little more carefully.  There is a third point of criticism here. This is what the Commissioner has already said. Some say that we attribute too much competence to the European Commission. On the other hand, Colleague Maragall, who co-authored this report as shadow rapporteur, says that there are no Added European values here. One of you said that this is not ambitious enough for Europe. Well, that's the legal situation. This is an area of education which is not covered by the European Treaties. And it is ET 2020 that seems to be an excellent example of cooperation, in which there is at the same time a European dimension, voluntary, highly flexible cooperation between Member States, respecting the autonomy of the Member States. And in principle, we should appreciate and support this kind of cooperation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Union is looking for solutions and ways to combat unemployment, especially youth unemployment. This problem could be alleviated in the light of the reports presented by the academic community. They show that graduates who are often prepared for the market do not meet the expectations and qualifications of employers, which is why they are having problems or not even vacancies.  We should point out that teaching conditions and quality are often deteriorating, resulting in the fragmentation of university programmes and an undue emphasis on competence in a narrow area of knowledge.  Employers complain about graduate skills and are critical of the new degree structure and note that the duration of bachelor's degrees is not suitable for the needs of the labour market. At the same time, the problems of employability of professionals are caused by insufficient recognition of bachelor's degree professional qualifications and the enormous application of the rules to the solution.  We must therefore call on the Commission to take all necessary measures and to make proposals that will help the academic community to improve and prepare the specialists that employers need. This would make it easier for graduates to find a job and employers to get the desired qualification. Those who already have the necessary qualifications should ensure that the recognition of professional qualifications runs smoothly and does not take long.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. – Education and training are important in helping people to acquire the knowledge and professional skills they need to become competitive and innovative employees. Moreover, they could play important role in nurturing open-minded, empathic, inquiring human beings and responsible citizens with a strong sense of identity, a deep knowledge of their culture and heritage. We should welcome the fact that the Paris Declaration was reflected in the Joint Report and that the recalibration of ET2020 has been done by putting on an equal footing employability goals and the promotion of social cohesion, equality, non-discrimination and civic competences. ET2020 cooperation, while respecting the competence of Member States, should complement national actions and support Member States in their efforts to develop education and training systems. I welcome the ET2020 stocktaking exercise. The ET 2020’s four strategic objectives and current benchmarks remain valid as they were formulated in a comprehensive and forward-looking manner in the ET 2020 Council conclusions of 2009, providing a solid basis for ET 2020 activities up to 2020. However, the policy focus needs to be recalibrated to include both the pressing economic and employment challenges and the role of education in promoting equity and inclusion and in imparting common European values, intercultural competences and active citizenship.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. Over the past ten years, the number of people who have had access to formal education has increased significantly. But Europe is stuck in appalling levels of youth unemployment, even among graduates. It is necessary to increase the efficiency of education and training systems and the general levels of skills and competences, strengthening the link between the world of work and the world of education and ensuring effective communication and the development of partnerships between the relevant policy areas and the sub-sectors of education and training. Education, as well as training, is the sine qua non for real personal and collective growth. A further point in the report that I would like to highlight is support for educators, identified as one of the new priority areas of ET2020. The quality of teacher preparation and the programmes for permanent professional development are, unfortunately, still lagging behind the sudden increase in the multiplicity and complexity of skills essential to teaching. In view of the acceleration of intra-European mobility and the continuing refugee crisis, particular attention should be paid to the needs of the various types of students from ethnic or religious minorities from low-income families and immigrants.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The past decade has meant a significant increase in the number of university-educated people throughout the European Union. At the same time, the number of unemployed increased the most precisely for young university students. Unfortunately, the masses of higher education have, in many cases, come at the expense of its quality. The responses of employers are a clear measure. They talk about the insufficient level of knowledge and skills of university graduates. They draw attention to significant differences between their needs and training at higher education institutions. The mismatch between education and the requirements of practice has a negative impact on the applicability and ability of young people to compete on the labour market. We must also avoid artificially enforcing higher education. There are a large number of professions where the condition for obtaining a diploma is indeed extra. It costs us a lot of money from public funds. The Erasmus exchange programme is a success in European cooperation between higher education institutions. However, the motivation of students to go on a foreign exchange sometimes appears problematic. This is also evidenced by the disproportionately high popularity of some southern countries.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. - Education and training play an important role in developing civic virtues and strengthening the democratic principles underpinning the EU and should not only focus on meeting labour market needs. Increasing access opportunities for lifelong learning can open up new opportunities for the low-skilled and unemployed, people with special needs, the elderly and migrants. As not all Member States face the same level of problems, the proposed education and training recommendations should be flexible and take into account national, economic, social and other factors, with a view to improving the situation across the EU.  Member States must improve links between higher education and vocational education and training, research institutions and the economic sector, ensure the involvement of social partners and civil society, in order to enhance the impact of ET 2020 and the importance of learning systems to increase Europe's innovative capacity. The potentials of digitalisation, information and communication technologies should be better exploited in order to improve the quality and accessibility of learning and in this regard the exchange of best practices and enhanced cross-border cooperation should be encouraged. Education and training in Europe should contribute to EU strategies and initiatives, the Europe 2020 strategy, the Digital Single Market Initiative, the European Agenda on Security and the Investment Plan for Europe, so I supported this report.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the report on the follow-up of the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training ('Education and Training 2020'). I believe that it rightly focuses on the key role of the teacher in the educational process and on the need to take measures to increase the attractiveness and status of the teaching profession. We live in an age where the ever-increasing need for new skills due to changing labour market needs requires more investment than ever in continuing teacher development programmes.  I share the view that not only technological but also pedagogical innovation is needed to modernise education. It is more than clear to all of us that schools have a clear need for adequate equipment. In addition to investing in infrastructure, we must also address the need to increase the digital skills of teachers, for whom the digital revolution is also a major challenge. Our teachers must not only be able to use new technologies in the classroom, but also be able to teach them.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe needs skills and strategic thinking more than ever. Our future, but also our present, belongs to those with the right capabilities, to the innovation- and knowledge-based industries. It is therefore crucial to have an overarching EU-wide strategic framework for cooperation in education and training. The Education and Training 2010 work programme provided a good basis that ET2020 can continue to build on. I particularly support the inclusive model, focused on exchanges of best practice, mutual learning, gathering and dissemination of information and evidence of what works, as well as advice and support for policy reforms. The effective application of this strategy would not only allow us to devise policies advancing the social and professional fulfilment of all citizens, but also to progress further towards sustainable economic prosperity and employability. Fulfilling the four key objectives of ET2020 is instrumental in achieving this vision we have set ourselves. As a Member of the European Parliament working towards enhancing Europe’s innovation and entrepreneurial potential, I am glad to see that ET2020 has as one of its key aims enhancing creativity and innovation, including entrepreneurship, at all levels of education and training. We must indeed boost creativity and innovation, which are crucial for enterprise development and to Europe’s ability to compete internationally.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. – I believe that Europe takes little care of the resources already in its own backyard. There is an excessive and ostentatious concern for the immediate school integration of refugee children. Of course, children have no guilt and caring for children must be above any political considerations. The problem is that students in poorer Member States are not equally encouraged to integrate into the Western education system. How are students in poorer European countries less than immigrants? Why is it desire at all costs to introduce crops into the European area that disturb the balance so difficult to maintain in the EU? Europe must first increase its own teachers and pupils, both before entering the educational process and leaving the school benches. There are many old treaties that need to be reformed and re-discussed. Because of these treaties, which are not in the european way of being, we are all in a historic impasse of the Union. I am surprised that the issue of immigrants is found in all the topics discussed and voted on in plenary, while those agreements that actually led to this crisis are constantly bypassed or ignored by the European Parliament.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – Although education policy is a competence of the Member States, the EU still plays an active role in the development of European education and training systems, supporting Member States in this area, for example under the Education and Training 2020 (ET2020) programme. On the basis of the ET2020 framework programme and other Commission objectives in the field of education and training, Member State governments could fundamentally think that they are all interested in creating a modern education and training system. Unfortunately, this is not the case for all Member States. For months in Hungary, teachers' unions, the teachers' and students' society and parents have been demanding to no avail of the Orban government for the transformation of a centralised education system that has been shown to be harmful. For political reasons, the government refuses to consult professionals and stakeholders.  It follows that the Hungarian Government has deliberately created an education system that excludes independent education experts, maintains segregated schools and sheds a mass of early school leavers. That is why I draw the Commission's attention to the fact that it may be necessary to examine, for example, Hungary the use of funds received under the ET2020 and other European programmes for education and training and their effectiveness.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – We have set ourselves the ET 2020 strategic framework to address the challenges in education and training systems. However, we are still facing major problems in this area. When it comes to the quality and accessibility of education, more ambitious, more coordinated and more effective measures need to be taken at European and national levels. I believe that there is a need to modernise education systems. We need to include in early education the learning of general basic skills, digital literacy, maths, foreign languages, as young people will more easily adapt to a changing labour market by acquiring a wide range of skills. I would also like to emphasise the important role of mobility programmes such as Erasmus+, which promote the development of young people's skills and competences, while helping them to become more independent, accountable and resourceful.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – At a time of high youth unemployment rates, which also affect university graduates, I consider it crucial to review the strategic framework for European cooperation in education and training (ET 2020) in order to optimise their effectiveness. The Evaluation carried out by the European Commission in 2014 presented a number of EC and Council recommendations aimed at critically analysing the complex substrate for the functioning and management of ET 2020. Similarly, the EP report discussed today outlines a number of recommendations and policy priorities to list only the needs of multi-level et 2020 coordination and governance, improving the quality of education and training and responding to the challenges faced by European education systems in relation to migration flows within and outside Europe. In view of the increasing number of people taking up formal education over the last decade, in particular with regard to participation in higher education, while increasing inequalities in education systems, I consider it extremely important to critically evaluate the strategic education and training framework and to pursue benchmarks in terms of education, which should, however, also be accompanied by a strong drive to improve the quality of education at all levels.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I draw attention to an unacceptable situation in the United Kingdom, where two children belonging to the Barbu family, Romanian citizens, were taken from their parents by a decision of a court which we do not comment on. But, in violation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child, they were given up for adoption to a family composed of persons of the same sex, since, in Romania, this would not have been possible. Article 20 of the Convention was thus infringed, where it is expressly stated that, in choosing a solution to protect the child, account will be taken of its ethnic, religious, cultural and linguistic origin, as well as Article 21, where it is made clear that international adoption is possible only if, in the country of origin, it cannot be entrusted for foster care or adoption. Or, in Romania it was and is possible this. The British state must understand that the rights of the child cannot be trampled, as it has done with the children of the Barbu family, without bearing the consequences.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Madam President, Cyprus has been grieving for four days. A fiery lailapa, a nightmare, burned a huge area of forest land and agricultural crops. Due to the fires, two courageous forest rangers were killed in the line of duty and six others are seriously injured. To understand this disaster for Cyprus, it is compared to the extent that Turkey burned down forest land in 1974, during the Turkish invasion. It's about 10% of our forest wealth! The equivalent for Germany would be, in forest area, 1,140,000 hectares.  It is therefore impossible for a small state to bear all these economic costs. There are support mechanisms, but we call on the European Union to help a small state, such as Cyprus, which only a month ago came out of the support mechanism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, it has already been five years since the Memorandum was implemented in Greece. Five stone memorial years that tore the country apart. Five years of social Armageddon, which filled Greece with armies of unemployed and poor. The memorandum eventually increases public debt as a percentage of GDP. From 123% of GDP in 2010 it will reach 200% by the end of the third memorandum in 2018, according to the IMF itself. At the same time, the troika reduced wages and pensions, imposed a tax-free resalto on the pockets and fortunes of the Greek people and mortgages public property for 99 years, launching its sell-off instead of a lentil plate. And as if that were not enough, now the troika is trying to break up industrial relations, creating a modern working jungle. But the Greek people will no longer tolerate the troika and the lenders and will soon throw them out of our homeland, to get Greece back. The fight continues.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we also have years of heightened dependence on gas imports. This is why the strategy on sequestered natural gas and gas storage on the European Parliament's agenda is important. Both, and the sequestered gas and gas storage facilities will allow for a secure supply of gas and diversity and supply which will then lead to us having a greater impact on the market, which then needs to cause price reductions as well. This would achieve that heavy fossil fuels can be replaced with sequestered natural gas, which of course should lead to a positive environmental impact.  Thus, there are multiple advantages of using sequential natural gas and therefore I expect the strategy to be adopted soon and also the creation of a common Energy Union, which will, of course, lead to a common European policy on the use of sequential natural gas.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL).
text: – A Uachtaráin, níl aon cheist ann ach go bhfuil conspóid ann maidir le tuirbíní gaoithe ar fud na hÉireann. Tá buarthaí agus ceisteanna ann faoin bhfothrom agus faoin mbagairt don fhiadhúlra, faoi chúram sláinte agus faoin gcuma atá orthu maidir lenár dtírdhreach álainn.  Cé go dtacaíonn Sinn Féin go huile agus go hiomlán leis an úsáid is mó a bhaint as foinsí fuinnimh nua agus gan a bheith ag brath ar bhreoslaí iontaise, ní mór dúinn a chinntiú go bhfuil aon fhorbairt a dhéantar ar thionscal an fhuinnimh, cosúil le muilte gaoithe, déanta i gcomhpháirtíocht le pobail áitiúla. Caithfear próiseas trédhearcach agus comhairliúchán oscailte poiblí a chur mar thosaíocht ar gach céim d’aon fhorbairt bhonneagair – go háirithe agus sinn ag caint ar ár dtimpeallacht.  Ní tharlaíonn sé seo, is baolach, agus tá sé sin feicthe agam féin i mo thoghcheantar féin mar shampla nuair a thug Comhairle Chontae Chorcaí cead pleanála do thuirbíní gaoithe i gceantar go bhfuil aitheantas faoi leith tugtha dó mar limistéar caomhantais speisialta. Níl sé seo sásúil in aon slí. Ba chóir úinéireacht a roinnt, ar a laghad leis an bpobal, agus gurb é an pobal áitiúil atá ag baint brabúis agus tairbhe fónta as an saghas seo forbairtí. Agus níos tábhachtaí fós, go bhfuil an chumhacht ag an bpobal a bheith bainteach le haon phleanáil.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, a few weeks ago we held in this Parliament a crucial day for two of the formations that I represent here: the Aragonese Chunta and the Castellano Party. Crucial, because they were a fundamental issue for the survival of their territories: depopulation, the terrible depopulation that has caused the Spanish rural environment to lose 75% of its population in one hundred years or that has caused many counties of Aragon to have a population density of less than three inhabitants per square kilometer, which according to international standards equals a desert. Doesn't Castile and Aragon deserve a future? Aren't they Europe? The Spanish state has received more than 300 billion euros for rural development and cohesion funds, and they have been useless, carefree of their duty and condemned Castile and Aragon to permanent bleeding of its people, with no hope or project of life on its land. I call on the Commission to take on this problem, to strengthen and monitor the use of these funds, and to do so quickly, before much of Europe becomes a ghostly territory.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – I will be talking about the referendum that will take place in the UK tomorrow. From the point of view Polish, of course, it would be unfortunate if the United Kingdom left the Union, because only together with the United Kingdom can we block the stupider ideas of the axis states, namely Germany, Paris and Berlin. However, I understand perfectly well that the British people will be guided by their own interests, and since it is indisputably better for Britain to get out of the european Union, I will not worry if they do so, because their interests are more important than my interests. So the fact that Poland is still in the European Union does not mean that others, too, have to endure this yoke.  Furthermore, I believe that the European Union should be destroyed as soon as possible.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, today I will be speaking about the British referendum, so I will speak in English. Tomorrow, the United Kingdom is going to decide about itself, not about the European Union. But if somebody leaves a community, it has some impact. That impact will of course be economic, but also political. Together, we are bigger, stronger and more stable. I agree that that the European Union has to be more effective and more flexible. The four British suggestions for reforming the EU agreed on by the European Council represent steps in the right direction. So if the United Kingdom remains inside our Union, I look forward to cooperation on shaping a better Europe. Before 1989, in my country, people were suffering and dreaming to be free and to be part of free society under the European Union.  Let us recall that we have a new example of sacrifice. Today, Jo Cox, the victim of the hate campaign of Brexit, would have had her 42nd birthday. So, along with our respected Czech theologian Professor Tomáš Halík, let me call on citizens of Britain to ‘opt boldly to reject the temptation to betray Europe, our common homeland’.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to denounce before this House the situation of isolation in the railway communications that my province and the south-west of my region, Andalusia, live. In my province, in Granada, in southern Spain, from April 7 last year – 15 months – connections were closed, all rail connections for high-speed works to Granada. Initially scheduled for six months, it remains closed undated by the Spanish Government. I am talking about an EU-funded project, the tranches of which were modified by the Government of the People's Party in these four years. After the changes of the projects, moving from a connection with the characteristics of the high speed to a conventional connection, to the closure of the connections for fifteen months and to staying outside the Mediterranean corridor. This situation has been caused in these four years of the People's Party in Spain, with the invaluable collaboration of the mayor of Granada. The damage it is causing to citizens and the Granada and Andalusian economic sectors is absolutely incalculable. We are going to denounce this fact here today, in plenary, but also before the European Commission, because we are talking about European funds.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, a large number of Citizens of the European Union live on tourism. We have a huge number of small and medium-sized enterprises operating in the field of tourism. An even greater number of citizens use tourist services. And that's where we get to the problem. We do not have common, uniform standards in the European Union when using tourist services. A big problem, for example, is the standardization of hotel tourist service or services in auto camps. We have a common mark of 2, 3, 4 and 5 stars of quality, but we do not have the same quality in the Member States. It is almost a rule that in the old Member States, in the founding women, the quality of hotel accommodation is lower than in the new Member States, and we have the same stars for hotel service. That's certainly not good, because we have a single market. This is in some ways a bit of a scam on the consumer, i.e. the user of the service. In this context, I expect that tourism, and that the Commissioner in charge of tourism, will really come out with a proposal on how to standardise tourism services in the European Union.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I believe that the British people will make a decision tomorrow in accordance with their best knowledge and conscience, but I must say that I am disappointed with the way the campaign has been going in the UK. There were lies, manipulations and, unfortunately, violence. What struck me most, however, was the statement of Nigel Farage, who described eastern European workers as less able to learn English, understand the common law and feel a sense of belonging to Britain. The people of Central and Eastern Europe are no uncivilized indigenous tribe. These are people who build houses in the UK, look after children, work in industry and services. Migration from these countries helps Britain economically, and only a fool would deny it. Their kids dream of playing football like Rooney or singing like Adele. Dear Mr Farage, stop insulting those who have been paying taxes into the British tax system for years and doing an honest job.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As a member of the European Parliament's Israel delegation, I am following with great concern the israeli Government's actions against a section of civil society in their own country. With a so-called Transparency Act, the government wants to restrict the work of NGOs – the non-governmental organisations. The clear focus on a part of civil society in the country is critical. For example, human rights organisations are disproportionately affected by this law, but some of the German political foundations would also be hindered by excessive identification and reporting requirements. As a result, plurality in the country would be in jeopardy.  Together with other MEPs, I have already written to the Israeli Government to express my concerns. Another example of the increasing pressure on Israeli civil society is the trial of the NGO "Breaking the Silence". This organization publishes anonymous statements by members of the army about their use in the Palestinian territories. If the Israeli prosecutor prevails in demanding that the organization disclose the identity of its sources, this work of "Breaking the Silence" would be de facto impossible. In dialogue with Israel, the European Union is committed to ensuring that the civil societies there must act free of unnecessary restrictions, so that Israel continues to play a pioneering role in plurality and democracy in the Middle East.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I would like to bring here the struggle of the workers of the Lauki and Dulciora companies in Valladolid, for this Parliament to recognise those who fight for their rights, for their work and for their dignity in the face of large multinationals. Lauki and Dulciora are two companies owned by the companies Lactalis and Mondelez (formerly Kraft), companies that threaten to relocate their production despite the profitability of their operations for the sole purpose of increasing their profits and their control over the market. With these closures are at risk industries linked to the territory: ships, brands and knowledge accumulated during years of production.  We will not leave the crisis without supporting our industrial fabric. From here I call on the public administrations, starting with the European Union, to facilitate the continuity of lauki and Dulciora's production beyond the interests of their current owners, and to prevent mass layoffs on profitable companies such as those facilitated by the labour reform of the People's Party, especially when a whole regional economy is put at risk. Lauki and Dulciora don't close.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I have recently received several indignant responses from hauliers from the Czech Republic to measures that, by justifying the setting of equal rules in the field of road freight transport, are being introduced by some Member States, such as Germany or France, and other countries are considering introducing them.  The setting of equal rules must not mean and consequently lead to the fragmentation of the internal market into twenty-eight different national adjustments, accompanied by a totally disproportionate administrative burden on SMEs in particular. I am therefore taking this opportunity to convey their concerns, while calling on the Commissions to respond to clarify the rules governing the operation of international road transport and to prevent the continued fragmentation of the internal market.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in the fight against climate change we must all be on the same boat and moving in the same direction. We must move towards an energy model free of CO2 and pollution, but the transition must be done in an orderly, intelligent and above all, respecting human rights. The European Union intends to end European coal aid, arguing that it is more expensive than that from abroad. It forgets to assess the cost of imported coal on slave labour, child labour, the ecological cost of transport to Europe and the risk of energy dependence, as well as interventionism by countries that subsidize extraction and the socio-economic cost of leaving thousands of families affected by the loss of direct and indirect jobs , without its proper restructuring plan. I call on the European Commission to emphasize CO2 capture and storage research projects and to develop an appropriate labour restructuring plan for the coal sector. We also call on our Government to respect the agreements it has signed until 2018 and to participate in the proposal for future support programmes beyond that date. We need to focus more on people and workers and stop fostering private interests and private businesses.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, recent research carried out by the Guarantor of Children and Adolescence of the Campania Region has found more than two hundred cases of ill-treatment and violence against children. The report accompanying the research reports that there are entire areas, in very critical neighbourhoods, where sexual abuse and incest are elevated to normal. All the media have talked about this research, sometimes even out of turn. It is certainly not a phenomenon of custom, but they are stories of poverty, isolation, degradation and social exclusion. These are neighbourhoods desperately abandoned to themselves, where the underworld manages the territory and illegal activities are the only sources of income. I wanted to speak this evening because the institutions all have a duty to turn the spotlight on this horrific and shameful phenomenon, so that it is not only the subject of studies and in-depth studies, but above all the subject of prevention and law enforcement policies. We must do more and act more efficiently and effectively to help the most vulnerable citizens. The Commission needs to work more closely with the Member States to put in place more effective instruments to ensure growth and work, to protect those who need protection most and to strengthen the system of guaranteeing children's rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Brexit, a short word which, unfortunately, may sound interesting to those who do not want to go into detail. But we must understand that a possible decision to leave the European Union no longer offers the possibility of a way back for Britain. I therefore call on British citizens of Romanian to understand the importance of this vote and to support remaining in the European Union, so that their country of adoption remains close to their country of origin in a united Europe. I also ask the more than 150,000 Romanians who live and work legally in the UK to invite their friends and relatives to support Britons who want to stay in the European Union. The vote of those close to them depends on the right to work, the right to reduced tuition fees, the right to credit, the right to social benefits or even the recognition of old age at work in Europe, but also the United Kingdom. By their active participation, tomorrow they can combat extremist messages against labour mobility in the European Union, show that Romanian citizens act civically, in accordance with democratic principles, and, above all, demonstrate once again that Romanians living in the UK care about the fate of this country and want it strongly, in the European Union, alongside Romania.
